countryCurrency: CFP franc (XPF)
countryOverview: Wallis and Futuna, officially the Territory of the Wallis and Futuna Islands is a Polynesian French island territory in the South Pacific between Tuvalu to the northwest, Rotuma of Fiji to the west, the main part of Fiji to the southwest, Tonga to the southeast, Samoa to the east, the New Zealand-associated state of Tokelau to the northeast and to a more distant north the Phoenix Islands (Kiribati). (However, Wallis and Futuna is not part of, nor even contiguous with, French Polynesia. Wallis and Futuna is located at the very opposite western end of Polynesia.) Its land area is 264 km2 with a population of about 15,000. Mata-Utu is the capital and biggest city. The territory is made up of three main volcanic tropical islands along with a number of tiny islets, and is split into two island groups that lie about 260 km apart, namely Wallis Islands (Uvea) in the northeast, and Hoorn Islands (Futuna Islands) in the southwest, including Futuna Island proper and the mostly uninhabited Alofi Island. Since 2003 Wallis and Futuna has been a French overseas collectivity Between 1961 and 2003, it had the status of a French overseas territory.

countryDriving: Road travel in Afghanistan is generally unsafe.  Poor road maintenance, ongoing high levels of conflict, the risk of highway banditry and poor driving standards add to the risks to travelling by road in Afghanistan. The road travel network often becomes congested due to numerous security checkpoints. Due to the ongoing security risks travellers are advised to hire an experienced driver and travel in secure transport with close protection and or armoured vehicles.
countryCurrency:
Afghani (AFN). The U.S Dollar (USD$) is also widely accepted.

Credit and debit cards are generally not accepted and ATM facilities are extremely limited and unreliable. It is recommend that visitors carry sufficient funds for their trip.

Travellers cheques are not widely accepted.
countryOverview:
AFGHANISTAN, officially the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, is a landlocked and mountainous country in south-central Asia. It is bordered by Pakistan in the south, Azad Kashmir in the east, Iran in the west, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan in the north, and China in the far northeast.

Since the late 1970s, Afghanistan has experienced a continuous state of war, including major occupations in the forms of the 1979 Soviet invasion, a Pakistani military intervention in support of the Taliban in the late 1990s and the October 2001 US-led invasion that overthrew the Taliban government. In December 2001, the United Nations Security Council authorized the creation of an International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) to help maintain security and assist the Karzai administration. There is an on-going Taliban insurgency and widespread political corruption.

countryDriving: Vehicles drives on the right. An international driving permit (IDP) is required. Driving can be very hazardous. Roads are poor, especially (but not only) in rural areas. In winter, mountain roads are snowy and icy. During hot spells, the tarmac can melt and become slippery. Flash flooding is possible throughout the year. Stay alert for large, unmarked potholes. Street lighting in urban areas is subject to power cuts. Elsewhere, except on the major interurban arterial routes, there is no street lighting, so night travel is best avoided. We suggest using four-wheel drive vehicles in Albania. There is no national recovery system, so cars should be self-sufficient, carrying minor repair equipment including jack, spare wheel, fan belts, wiper blades, local phrase book, first aid kit, water and overnight food when in remote areas.Drivers with foreign licensed vehicles draw particular scrutiny from the Road Traffic Police.  Adhere to road traffic law at all times as committing even minor offences may result in a fine.  Albanian driving can often be aggressive and erratic. Fatality rates from road traffic accidents are amongst the highest in Europe. Minor traffic disputes can quickly escalate, especially as some motorists could be armed. If you intend to drive you are advised to avoid reacting to provocative behaviour by other road users. If you are involved in a traffic accident, even a minor one, you are required to wait until the police arrive. This will usually happen quickly in built-up areas.  Expect queues at all border crossings, especially at weekends and during the summer months.
countryCurrency:
Lek (Lek).

US dollars and euros are the most accepted foreign currencies and exchange offices are available in the centre of Tirana. Money-changing in the streets should be generally avoided.

Major debit and credit cards are accepted in most banks and international hotels. ATM's can be found in Tirana and other main cities, but visitors should ensure they have cash when travelling to rural areas.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited and the import of foreign currency is unlimited. The export of foreign currency is permitted up to US$5,000 or equivalent.
countryOverview:
Albania is located in the western part of the Balkan peninsula. It borders the former Yugoslavia (Serbia-Montenegro) and Kosova in the north and the east, (FYR of) Macedonia in the east, and Greece in the south. It has access to the Adriatic and Ionian Seas in the west. From the Strait of Otranto, Albania is less than 100 km (60 miles) from Italy. 

The Albanian republic is a parliamentary democracy established under a constitution renewed in 1998. Elections are now held every four years to a unicameral 140-seat chamber. Albania joined NATO on 1 April 2009 becoming the 27th and 28th members of the alliance.

Prime Minister Sali Berisha's Democratic Party was the first opposition force in Albania following the fall of the first communist regime in the early 1990's. The 1992 elections ended 47 years of communist rule, but the latter half of the decade saw a quick decade saw a quick turnover of presidents and prime ministers. During the Nato bombing of Yugoslavia in 1999, nearly 500,000 Albanian refugees from Kosovo spilled over the border, imposing a huge burden on Albania's economy. Albania is transforming into a market economy, but is poor by Western standards. The major employer and the key sector is agriculture.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right.  Drivers will need an International Driving Permit (IDP). If you are to drive to areas outside the main cities this will carry a heightened risk. Algerian roads are overcrowded, and traffic-related accidents kill a large number of people every year. Drivers will encounter police and military checkpoints on major roads within and on the periphery of Algiers and other major cities. Security personnel at these checkpoints expect full co-operation. Motorists should be aware that terrorists employ false roadblocks as a tactic for ambushes and kidnappings, primarily in the central regions of Boumerdes and Tizi Ouzou and some parts of eastern Algeria. Travel overland, particularly in the southern regions, may require a permit issued by the Algerian government.
countryCurrency:
Algerian Dinar (DZD).

Credit cards are generally only accepted in urban areas. There are two or three functioning ATM's in Algiers, but they cannot be relied upon. Payment in cash is usually preferred.

Travellers' cheques are only accepted in 4 star or above hotels. You should only buy Algerian dinars at bureau de change at international airports, large hotels and banks in major cities. The dinar cannot be exported.

There are no restrictions on the export or import of local or foreign currency. The export of foreign currency must not exceed the amount declared on arrival.
countryOverview:
Algeria, officially the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, also formally referred to as the Democratic and Popular Republic of Algeria is a country in the Maghreb. In terms of land area, it is the second largest country on the African continent and the 10th largest country in the world. It is bordered in the north east by Tunisia, in the east by Libya, in the west by Morocco, in the south west by Western Sahara, Mauritania, and Mali, in the south east by Niger, and in the north by the Mediterranean Sea.

Its size is almost 2,400,000 square kilometres, and it has an estimated population of 37.1 million, most of which is situated near the northern coastal regions of the country. The capital of Algeria is Algiers. Algeria is a member of the Arab League, United Nations, African Union, and OPEC. It is also a founding member of the Arab Maghreb Union.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right-hand side of the road, and traffic signs are the same as those used in the United States.  Caution is advised due to the mountainous terrain and unpaved state of some of the roads and tracks. An International Driving Permit or valid national driving licence is required.
countryCurrency:
US Dollar (USD).

American Express is widely accepted whereas MasterCard has more limited use. ATMs are located at the banking branches of the Amerika Samoa Bank and the Bank of Hawaii.

Travellers cheques in US dollars are easy to cash in most shops and hotels.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview: American Samoa is a group of six Polynesian islands in the South Pacific, halfway between Hawaii and New Zealand. It is the United States' southernmost territory. Western Samoa is a neighbouring independent country that shares the same culture. American Samoa became an unorganised U.S. territory in 1900. The politics of American Samoa are that of a presidential representative democratic dependency and the Governor is head of the government.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  The roads can become icy during winter months and it is advised that all vehicles carry a warning triangle, first aid kit, Spare bulb kit and Fire extinguisher.Snow chains are also be required to negotiate snow and ice covered roads in winter, where driving can be extremely hazardous.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬)

Although most currencies are accepted.

American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted. It is advisable to take travellers cheques in Euros, US Dollar or Pounds Sterling.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Andorra, officially the Principality of Andorra, also called the Principality of the Valleys of Andorra, is a small landlocked country in south western Europe, located in the eastern Pyrenees Mountains and bordered by Spain and France. 

Andorra is a prosperous country mainly because of its tourism industry, which services an estimated 10.2 million visitors annually, and also because of its status as a tax haven. It is not a member of the European Union, but the country does use the euro. The people of Andorra have the 3rd highest human life expectancy in the world.

The country's banking sector enjoys partial tax-haven status.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. Travellers wishing to drive in Angola are advised to acquire an international driving permit (IDP). Ensure that all of your vehicle documentation is available for inspection as police check points are common. The roads are improving but driving standards and some road conditions are very poor.  Outside major urban areas, mines and unexploded ordnance remain a problem.  Even in "cleared" areas, keep to well-established routes.
countryCurrency:
Kwanza (AOA). 

Credit cards are not generally accepted throughout Angola, however Diners Club, Visa and American Express have limited acceptance. A number of the larger hotels and restaurants have started to accept credit cards, however this is extremely limited.

ATM's can be found throughout the major cities, especially in Luanda, however many do not accept foreign cards. 

Travellers cheques are accepted and all imported currency has to be declared on arrival. The import of currency is limited to AOA15,000 and the import of foreign currency is unlimited. The export of foreign currency is limited to US$5,000 or equivalent and it is illegal to carry local currency out of Angola.
countryOverview:
Angola is located on the western Atlantic Coast of Southern Africa between Namibia and the Republic of Congo.

Angola is one of Africa's major oil producers and is a supplier to China and the United States but its people remain poor and it one of the poorest countries in the world. The oil-rich enclave of Cabinda has been embroiled in a long-running independence struggle.

Angola gained independence from Portugal in November 1975.After 16 years of fighting, which killed up to 300,000 people, a peace deal led to elections, however Unita, a rebel group, rejected the outcome and resumed the war, in which hundreds of thousands were killed. Another peace accord was signed in 1994 and the UN sent in peacekeepers. But the fighting steadily worsened again and in 1999 the peacekeepers withdrew, leaving behind a country rich in natural resources but littered with landmines and the ruins of war. The infrastructure of the country has suffered due to the fighting and a peace deal was finally achieved in 2002 after the death of Unita leader Jonas Savimbi. 

President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has been in power for 30 years and oil exports and foreign loans have spurred economic growth and have fuelled a reconstruction boom.

countryDriving: Left hand side of the road.  30mph speed limit on most roads, 20mph near schools and through villages.
countryCurrency:
Eastern Caribbean Dollar (XCD).

But the US Dollar is also widely accepted.

Most hotels and restaurants accept major credit cards but it is advisable to check ahead.

The import or local and forein currency is unlimited provided it is declared upon arrival. The export of local and foreign currency is limited to the amount imported and declared.
countryOverview:
Anguilla lies east of Puerto Rico and the Virgin islands and is part of the Caribbean British overseas territory. It consists of the main island of Anguilla itself and a number of smaller islands, some of which are not permanently inhabited.

Anguilla is noted for its spectacular coral reefs and beaches. The main industries are tourism, offshore banking, incorporation, management and fishing.

countryReligon: Christian (predominantly Anglican and other Protestant, some Roman Catholic)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  In order to be able to drive a car in Antigua and Barbuda a local driving licence needs to be purchased.  A current driving licence is required to obtain this.  Drive with care and attention at all times. The national speed limit is 40 mph and there is a limit of 20 mph in built up areas.
countryCurrency:
Eastern Caribbean Dollar (XCD).

The US Dollar is accepted over the counter. Pound Sterling can be changed at banks on the island.

Major credit cards are usually accepted and ATM's are located at various places on the island. 

There are no limits on the import of local and foreign currency, provided it is declared upon arrival. The export of local and foreign currency is permitted up to the amount imported and declared.
countryOverview:
Antigua and Barbuda is a twin-island nation lying between the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. It consists of two major inhabited islands, Antigua and Barbuda, and a number of smaller islands (including Great Bird, Green, Guinea, Long, Maiden and York Islands and further south, the island of Redonda). Separated by a few nautical miles, Antigua and Barbuda are in the middle of the Leeward Islands, part of the Lesser Antilles, roughly at 17 degrees north of the Equator. Antigua and Barbuda is nicknamed "Land of 365 Beaches" due to the many beaches surrounding the islands. It was formally part of the British Empire and became independent in 1981.

The British Empire has strongly influenced its governance, language, and culture. Tourism is the main industry now but investment banking and financial services also make up an important part of the economy. The population is approximately 85,000 and is mainly made up of people from West African, British and Portuguese heritage.

countryDriving: Traffic drives on the right. Vehicle rental is available at airports and in major cities. Travellers will be required to be no younger than 21 years of age, possess an international driving permit (IDP) and a valid credit card. All motorists in Argentina are required by law to possess liability insurance., which is often requested by security personnel at official roadblocks. Failure to provide this proof of liability insurance will result in a fine.
countryCurrency:
Peso (ARS).

Credit and debit cards are widely accepted and ATM's are available in most major cities. Travellers are advised to exercise caution when using credit cards and ATM's as both these types of fraud is increasingly being reported in the country. ATM's in isolated areas should be avoided, especially after dark.

There is a flourishing black market, but travellers are advised to avoid entering into unofficial exchanges as it is illegal and counterfeit pesos are often used.

Visitors can import up to US$10,000 or its equivalent without having to declare. The export of foreign currency for amounts higher than US$10,000 or its equivalent in other currencies is prohibited.
countryOverview:
Argentina is the second largest country in South America and lies between the Andes mountain range and the Atlantic Ocean. It is Latin America's third largest economy with manufacturing, agriculture, mining and construction accounting for the majority of business. It has an abundance of natural resources including copper, zinc and iron ore.

In recent years Argentina has recovered from years of political turmoil and is now considered politically stable and democratic. Argentina is not currently involved in any internal or external conflict. However, the country is in a long-standing territorial dispute with the British government over the Falkland Islands, which is claimed by both countries. In 1982, Argentina and the United Kingdom fought a 74-day war over control of the Falklands and surrounding South Georgia and the South Sandwich islands, culminating in Argentina's surrender on 14 June 1982. However, while the UK has continued to rule the islands as an overseas territory, Argentina has not surrendered its claim to the islands.

President Cristina Fernandez is the wife of former president Nestor Kirchner. The Argentinian economy has bounced back after hitting rock bottom in 2001, however poverty remains a serious challenge throughout Argentina.

countryDriving: Traffic drives on the right. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required. The local standard of driving is poor. Be prepared for drivers who drive recklessly and flout traffic laws. The roads are also in a poor state, particularly in the coldest months (November to February).
countryCurrency:
Armenian Dram (AMD).

Armenia remains largely a cash-only economy. Credit cards are accepted at some businesses, including major hotels and restaurants in Yerevan, but rarely outside of the capital.

ATM machines are widely available in larger towns; though outside of Yerevan may be more difficult to find. Beware that credit-card skimming is on the rise at ATM machines throughout Armenia. Credit cards are not widely accepted yet, though can be used in some places in Yerevan.

Individuals can import and export the cash equivalent of â‚¬15,000
countryOverview:
Armenia is a landlocked country between Eastern Europe and Western Asia. It is a former republic of the Soviet Union. It is now a multi party state that is an emerging democracy and is in talks with the European Union to become an associate member in the future.

Unemployment and poverty remain widespread. Armenia's economic problems are aggravated by a trade blockade, imposed by neighbouring Turkey and Azerbaijan since the dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh. Despite these problems, Armenia's economy experienced several years of double-digit growth before a sharp downturn set in in 2008. The conflict over the predominantly Armenian-populated region in Azerbaijan overshadowed Armenia's return to independence.

Full-scale war broke out the same year as ethnic Armenians in Karabakh fought for independence, supported by troops and resources from Armenia proper. A ceasefire in place since 1994 has failed to deliver any lasting solution.

Serge Sarkasian won dispute presidential polls in 2008 which ended in deadly clashes. Fraught ties with turkey over the mass killings of Armenians under the Otoomans. A fragile ceasefire is currently in place with Azerbaijan over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region.

countryReligon: Roman Catholic 80.8%, Evangelist 4.1%, Protestant 2.5%, Jehovah's Witnesses 1.5%, Methodist 1.2%, Jewish 0.2%, other 5.1%, none or unspecified 4.6%
countryDriving: Traffic drives on the right.  The minimum age for hiring a car is between 21 and 25 , depending on the firm. Most main roads are in a good condition.  Hiring a car is straightforward and foreign and international driver's licences are accepted.  The terrain is often rugged, especially near the rocky coastal areas.  A four-wheel-drive (4WD) vehicle may be necessary to access all areas of the island.  Aruba uses international road signs but signs are sometimes scarce. The speed limit may be as low as 40 km/h.
countryCurrency:
Aruban Florin (AWG).

The US Dollar is widely accepted.

Major credit cards are widely accepted by many shops and hotels. They can also be used in ATM's if the card bears CIRRUS or Plus System logos.

The export of the Aruban Florin is prohibited. The import and export of foreign currency must be declared with amounts exceeding the equivalent of US$11,000.
countryOverview:
Aruba is a 33 km-long island of the Lesser Antilles in the southern Caribbean Sea, located 27 km north of the coast of Venezuela. Together with Bonaire and Curaao, it forms a group referred to as the ABC islands of the Leeward Antilles, the southern island chain of the Lesser Antilles.

Aruba, which has no administrative subdivisions, is one of the four constituent countries that form the Kingdom of the Netherlands, together with the Netherlands, Curaao, and Sint Maarten whose citizens share a single nationality: Dutch citizen.

Unlike much of the Caribbean region, Aruba has a dry climate and an arid, cactus-strewn landscape. This climate has helped tourism as visitors to the island can reliably expect warm, sunny weather. It has a land area of 180 square kilometres (69 sq mi) and is densely populated with its estimated 103,000 people. It lies outside the hurricane belt.

Aruba is a tourist magnet and a fuel exporter. Away from the beaches, casinos and hotels, much of the island is desert-like.

Aruba's Head of State is HM Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands and its prime minister is Mike Eman.

countryReligon: Roman Catholic 26%, Anglican 21%, other Christian 21%, Buddhist 2%, Islam 2%, other 1%, none 15% (2001)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  Visitors may drive in Australia if they hold a valid overseas drivers licence and are licensed for the class of vehicle they will be driving. Licences must be carried at all times when in control of a vehicle. If the drivers licence is not in the English language then a translation must be carried along with the permit. An International Drivers Permit is not sufficient by itself and must be accompanied by a valid drivers permit. Although there are eight states and territories in Australia, road rules are largely consistent.
countryCurrency:
Australian Dollar (AUD).

Major credit cards are widely accepted throughout Australia and ATM's can be found in all major towns and cities, however there may be limited or no acciess in outback areas. 

Travellers cheques are widely accepted in major currencies at banks and large hotels. However it should be made aware, some banks may charge a fee for cashing travellers cheques. 

The import and export of local and foreign currency is unrestricted. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or equivalent must be declared.

countryDriving: Traffic drives on the right hand side of the road.  The road network is comprehensive and in excellent condition. Tolls have to be paid on major routes.  This takes the form of a toll sticker stuck to the car. There are certain traffic regulations that are strictly enforced.  For example, all drivers are required to have a warning vest that must be worn day or night if getting out of a car on the hard shoulder for any reason. Winter or Mud and Snow tyres are required during the winter months.  Snow chains are not mandatory but must be carried if signposts indicate this. These winter regulations are rigourously enforced and there are frequent checkpoints.  The legal drink driving limit in Austria is 50 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood and penalties for driving under the influence of alcohol are severe.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

Major credit cards are widely available throughout Austria, especially in major cities and towns. Most major credit cards are accepted, including MasterCard, Visa and American Express. 

Travellers cheques are widely accepted. 

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or equivalent must be declared if travelling to or from a country outside the European Union.
countryOverview:
Austria officially the Republic of Austria is a landlocked country of roughly 8.4 million people in Central Europe. It is bordered by the Czech Republic and Germany to the north, Slovakia and Hungary to the east, Slovenia and Italy to the south, and Switzerland and Liechtenstein to the west. The capital and largest city, with a population exceeding 1.6 million, is Vienna.

Austria is one of the richest countries in the world. The country has developed a high standard of living and in 2010 was ranked 25th in the world for its Human Development Index. Austria adopted the European currency, the Euro, in 1999. Austria declared permanent neutrality in the 1955 State Treaty, to which it still adheres.

Under the "grand coalition" tradition, the centre-left SPOe and conservative People's Party have shared power for much of the post-World War ll period. In terms of the Austrian economy, banking and insurance predominate. A string industrial secotr depends on exports, with Germany a key market. An austerity package aims to balance the budget by 2016. Permanent neutralit is a cornerstone of foreign policy. Vienna is home to key international organisations.

countryReligon: Islam 93%, Russian Orthodox 3%, Armenian Orthodox 2%, other 2% (1995 est.)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  Driving can pose many risks in Azerbaijan.   The roads are of a poor quality and are not sufficiently maintained.  Night time travel can be particularly dangerous because poor road condition and inadequate street lighting. Many cars are not properly maintained, and the standard of driving is temperamental.  Driving in Azerbaijan is possible using a licence issued by an EU country or by using an International Driving Licence. Right hand drive cars are prohibited in Azerbaijan, it is not possible to enter or travel through Azerbaijan in a right hand drive vehicle.  Driving under the influence of alcohol is illegal, there is a zero limit on drinking alcohol and driving.
countryCurrency:
Azeri New Manat (AZN) 

Azerbaijan is known to be a cash-only economy, however some major credit cards are accepted in the larger banks, hotels and restaurants in Baku. 

Travellers cheques are generally not accepted and the import and export of local currency for non-residents is prohibited. The import of foreign currency is unlimited but must be declared upon arrival. The export of foreign currency is limited to US$10,000 or equivalent.
countryOverview:
Azerbaijan, officially the Republic of Azerbaijan is the largest country in the Caucasus region of Eurasia. Located at the crossroads of Western Asia and Eastern Europe, it is bounded by the Caspian Sea to the east, Russia to the north, Georgia to the northwest, Armenia to the west, and Iran to the south. The exclave of Nakhchivan is bounded by Armenia to the north and east, Iran to the south and west, while having a short borderline with Turkey to the northwest. Azerbaijan, a nation with a majority Turkic and Shia population, is a secular and a unitary republic with an ancient and historic cultural heritage.

Azerbaijan is one of the six independent Turkic states as well as the active members of the Turkic Council and the TRKSOY community. Azerbaijan became a member of the Council of Europe in 2001. The predominantly Armenian population of the Nagorno-Karabakh attempted to break away from Azerbaijan in 1988 and war broke out. In 1994 a ceasefire was signed. About 15% of Azerbaijan's territory remains occupied.

Azerbaijan gained independence from the Soviet Union in 1991 amid political turmoil. It has been famed for its natural gas sources and oil springs since ancient times. 

President Ilham Aliyev came to power in 2003, succeeding his father Heydar and was re-elected in 2008. A two-term presidential limit was abolished in 2009. Its huge oil export revenues have funded infrastructure projects and have significantly improved the living standards of the population.

countryAirport: Lynden Pindling International Airport on New Providence, Grand Bahama International Airport on Grand Bahama Island and Marsh Harbour International Airport on Abaco Island
countryReligon:
Baptist 35%, Anglican 15%, Roman Catholic 14%, Pentecostal 8%, Church of God 
5%, Methodist 4%, other Christian 15% (2000)
countryDriving: Driving in The Bahamas is on the left hand side and it is possible to drive with a UK or international driving licence.  Although traffic drives on the left-hand side of the road most vehicles are imported from the United States and are left hand drive. Drivers should therefore exercise caution, especially when overtaking.  The country roads can often be narrow, winding, and in need of repair. Drivers should be alert for frequent construction areas throughout the road system in the Bahamas. The roads in both Nassau and Freeport are more than adequate, although traffic congestion is sometimes a problem in busy cities throughout the islands.
countryCurrency:
Bahamian Dollar (BSD).

However the US dollar is widely accepted throughout the Bahamas Islands as both the Bahamian dollar and American dollar are used interchangeably.

American Express, MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted. ATM's can be found in airport terminals, at banks and casinos. 

Permission is required from the Central Bank of The Bahmas to import local currency, which may be exported up to a maximum of BSD70. The import and export of foreign currency are unlimited.
countryOverview:
The Bahamas is a developed, English-speaking Caribbean nation which is an archipelago of 700 islands and islets. It has been independent from the United Kingdom since 1973 and it is a Commonwealth nation with more than a century-old democratic tradition.

The country is a major centre for offshore finance and has one of the world's largest open-registry shipping fleets. The huge growth in the services sector of the economy has resulted in many of the population leaving fishing and farming villages for the commercial centres in New Providence Island, Grand Bahama and Great Abaco. The main exports include pharmaceuticals, cement, rum, crawfish and refined petroleum products.

The Head of State is Queen Elizabeth II and the prime minister is Perry Christie. Critics fear that oil development could harm the ecology and tourism sector. Mr Christie supports exploration, but insists he will protect the vital tourism industry.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Travelling by road in Bahrain is generally safe although erratic driving is common. Major roads in the northern area of Bahrain are well maintained.  Roads in villages and older parts of Manama and Muharraq are narrow and winding.   Bahrain operates a zero tolerance to drink driving. Penalties can be serious.
countryCurrency:
Bahraini Dinar (BHD).

American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are accepted in hotels, major stores and restaurants. Smaller shops may prefer to deal in cash. ATM's are available in major cities.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. The use of travellers cheques in Bahrain is becoming increasingly uncommon. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  Although travellers are able to rent cars in Bangladesh and the road network is adequate, erratic drivers contribute to driving standards being considered some of the worst in the world.  Some cars have bumper bars go around the whole car. Traffic in Dhaka has reached inconceivable proportions, and self-driving is not advised. Parking places are non-existent. Night time driving is substantially more dangerous as trucks/buses often ignore smaller cars. It is advised to get a local driver.  Traffic can be chaotic, local drivers are aggressive and vehicles are often poorly maintained. These factors all contribute to a high accident rate. Travellers to Bangladesh are advised to consider making use of a chauffeur-driven vehicle.
countryCurrency:
Bangladesh Taka (BDT) 

Credit cards are not generally accepted outside of the capital, however ATMs are becoming increasingly more common and can be found in Dhaka, Bogra, Khulna and Sylhet. 

Travellers cheques can be exchanged on arrival at Dhaka airport and US Dollars are the preferred currency. 

The import and export of local currency is limited to BDT100. The import of foreign currency limited to US$1,000 or equivalent, however amounts exceeding US$150 must be declared. The export of foreign currency is limited to US$150 or the amount declared on arrival.
countryOverview:
Bangladesh is a sovereign state located in South Asia bordered by India on all sides except for a small border with Burma (Myanmar). Formerly East Pakistan, Bangladesh was formed in 1971, when the two parts of Pakistan split after a bitter war that drew in neighbouring India.

Bangladesh is one of the world's most densely populated countries living on a delta of rivers that empties into the Bay of Bengal. Poverty is deep and widespread but Bangladesh has reduced population growth and improved health and education. The major employer is agriculture, but it is unable to meet the demand for jobs. The country is trying to diversify its economy, with industrial development a priority. Political tensions have turned violent and hundreds of people have been killed in recent years.

Bangladesh has been criticised for its human rights record, with particular concern about assaults on women and allegations that police use torture against those in custody.

countryReligon: Protestant 67% (Anglican 40%, Pentecostal 8%, Methodist 7%, other 12%), Roman Catholic 4%, none 17%, other 12%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side.  A Barbados driving permit is also required.  This can be obtained from car rental companies, the Ministry of Transport, the airport or police stations in Hastings, Worthing, and Holetown. A registration fee of $10BDS will need to be paid and a valid home country driving licence or an international driving permit will be required. Most of the roads are very good, although there are numerous potholes, especially out into the countryside. Night time driving can be particularly hazardous. Many roads do not have pavements so pedestrians walk on the side of the road where they may be difficult to see.  Roads are generally quite cramped apart from the ABC highway.  Buses and vans go much faster than larger vehicles should.   There is a relatively high rate of accidents on Barbados.  Having a map or a GPS is useful.
countryOverview:
Barbados is an island in the western area of the North Atlantic and 100 kilometres east of the Windward Islands and the Caribbean Sea. Barbados is outside of the principal Atlantic hurricane belt. It was once a Spanish and Portuguese territorial possession known as Los Barbados or Os Barbados. In 1966, Barbados became an independent state and Commonwealth realm, retaining Queen Elizabeth II as Head of State.

It is one of the Caribbean's leading tourist destinations and is the most developed island in the region. Barbados is an independent Caribbean island nation with a developed economy. Recently tourism has overtaken the export of sugar as its main revenue earner. Barbados is one of the more populous and prosperous Caribbean islands. Political, economic and social stability have given it one of the highest standards of living in the developing world. It is a centre for financial services and has offshore reserves of oil and natural gas.

Most Barbadians are the descendants of African slaves who were brought to the island from the 17th century to work the sugar cane plantations. Limestone caverns, coral reefs and a warm climate tempered by trade winds are among the island's natural assets. Barbados is relatively flat, with highlands in the interior.

countryReligon: Eastern Orthodox 80%, other (including Roman Catholic, Protestant, Jewish, and Muslim) 20% (1997 est.)
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  Driving licence holders must possess a valid International Driver's Licence to drive legally in Belarus. When travelling by private vehicle, it is essential to be able to produce ownership documents or a letter of 'power of attorney' at Custom's offices at border crossings. Only originals of these documents are accepted. Third party car insurance is required or an 'on-the-spot' fine may be imposed. This can only be bought when entering Belarus. Motorists should enquire at Customs' border offices for information. Drivers of foreign vehicles must pay a fee to use Belarus' highways. Payments are collected at border checkpoints and will vary according to the length of stay. Violation of the exit deadline may result in confiscation of your vehicle at the Belarusian border or if stopped at an in-country police checkpoint. The standard speed limit is 37 mph (60 kph) in built up areas, 55 mph (90 kph) outside built up areas and 62 mph (100 kph) on motorways (Brest-Moscow). Visiting motorists who have held a driving licence for less than two years must not exceed 43 mph (70 kph). There are frequent radar traps. Vehicles should have lights on at all times from 1 November to 31 March. 
The quality of driving in Belarus is erratic. Belarus' 'A-class' highways are in average to good condition. The condition of 'B-class' roads varies considerably and some are impassable for periods in winter due to severe snow and ice. Drivers should note that road signs are limited and warnings for road works and potholes are usually poorly marked. Pony and trap combinations are a specific hazard for drivers in rural areas as these roads are also usually unlit.
countryCurrency:
Belarusian Rouble (BYR).

Travellers cheques may be accepted at larger banks, but cash is easier to exchange. To avoid exchange rate charges, traveller's cheques should be taken in US Dollars or Euros.

Major international credit and debit cards, including American Express, Cirrus, Electron, MasterCard, Maestro and Visa are accepted in some larger hotels and at foreign currency shops and restaurants. There are several ATM machines in Minsk. ATM scams, such as skimming, do occur. It is therefore best to use ATMs located inside or next to bank.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. All remaining local currency must be reonverted at the point of departure. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, subject to declaration. The export of foreign currency is limited to the amount declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Belarus is officially the Republic of Belarus and it is a landlocked country in Eastern Europe bordered clockwise by Russia to the northeast, Ukraine to the south, Poland to the west, and Lithuania and Latvia to the northwest. The present borders of Belarus were established during of World War II.

As a former Soviet republic it was occupied by the Nazis between 1941 and 1944 and it lost 2.2 million people, including most of its large Jewish population. There are about 400,000 ethnic Poles living in the west of the country. Forty percent of its 207,600 square kilometres (80,200 sqmi) is forested and its strongest economic sectors are agriculture and manufacturing.

In early 2005, Belarus was listed by the US as Europe's only remaining "outpost of tyranny". In late 2008, there were some signs of a slight easing of tensions with the West, though this proved to be only a temporary thaw.

President Lukashenko is seen as 'Europe's last dictator". He's been in power since 1994. Belarus has a soviet-style economy and it is considered to have been subsidised by cheap Russian gas. A key gas and oil pipeline from Russia to Europe runs through Belarus.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  An EU/EEA driving licence, a recognised foreign driving licenceÊor an international driving licence is acceptable.  Licence holders may only drive the category of vehicle for which their licence is valid.  It is a must to carry a driving licence, vehicle registration document (V5), and certificate of motor insurance at all times. If the driving licence does not have a photograph on it, carry your passport to validate the licence.  If the vehicle is not registered in another persons name, carry a letter from the registered owner giving permission to drive.  Seat belts front and rear are obligatory everywhere.  Carrying a fire extinguisher is mandatory in the vehicle.  Headlamp converters are also compulsory.  If it is raining, hailing or snowing, vehicles of 7.5 tonnes or over are not allowed to overtake on motorways, highways or roads with a minimum of four lanes.  Vehicles of 3.5 tonnes or over are not allowed to use the left lane on roads with more than three lanes. An exception is made when traffic approaches a fork in the motorway and vehicles have to move to the left or right hand lanes depending on their destination.  The maximum speed for vehicles of 3.5 tonnes or over is now 90km/hr on motorways and highways of 2 x 2 lanes or more.  In the event of a breakdown, move the car onto the hard shoulder of the motorway and wear a fluorescent jacket.  Speed limits are implemented rigourously. Radar traps are frequent. In Belgium heavy on-the-spot fines can be imposed.  Belgian motorways are toll-free.  Belgium is connected to the rest of Europe by an excellent network of motorways. All roads are well sign posted.
Although frontier formalities between Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg and The Netherlands have now all but vanished, motorists should be prepared to stop when asked to do so by a customs official.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

ATM's are widely accepted with American Express, MasterCard and Visa credit cards are all widely accepted. 

Travellers cheques are widely accepted. 

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or equivalent must be declared if travelling to or from a country outside the European Union.
countryOverview:
Belgium is officially the Kingdom of Belgium and is a federal state in Western Europe. It is a founding member of the European Union and hosts the EU's headquarters, as well as those of several other major international organisations such as NATO and many international diplomats and civil servants.

Belgium has a population of about 11 million people. For such a small country, Belgium has been a major European battleground over the centuries. Occupied by Germany during World Wars I and II, it has experienced an economic boom in the last 50 years to become a model Western European liberal democracy. Tensions between the two main language communities sometimes run high, and the issue has brought down several governments, creating frequent political instability. Opinion polls suggest most Belgians want to maintain the federation, but separatist parties often score well in Flanders.

Socialist PM Elio di Rupo, a French speaker, was appointed in late 2011 to lead a six-party coalition after 18 months of negotiations. Belgium is seen as a bellwether for the wider EU economy. Industries include chemicals, pharmaceuticals and car-making. The IMF says Belgium is vulnerable to eurozone turmoil, partly because of its high public debt. Brussels is the home of the EU and Nato.

countryAirport: Philip S. W. Goldson International Airport
countryReligon: Roman Catholic 50%, Protestant 27% (Pentecostal 7%, Anglican 5%, Seventh-Day Adventist 5%, Mennonite 4%, Methodist 4%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2%), none 9%, other 14% (2000)
countryDriving:
Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  Unless a visitor holds an international licence, a temporary driver's licence will be issued to permit driving for up to 90 days. 
The speed limit is 90kph (56mph) on main roads and 40kph (25mph) on most other roads. Seat belts are compulsory. There must be adequate car insurance covering the vehicle. At police checkpoints, officers have the authority to ask to see proof of insurance and have the power to arrest if proper documentation cannot be produced. There are road links with Chetumal on the Mexican border and Melchor de Mencos in Guatemala. There are only four paved highways in Belize. Theey consist of the Northern Highway between Belize City and the Mexican border town of Chetumal, the Western Highway between Belize City and the Guatemala Border, the Hummingbird Highway from Belmopan to Dangriga and the Southern Highway down to Punta Gorda. All other roads are unpaved single or double-lane roads that get washed out during torrential rains. Local driving standards are extremely poor and road traffic accidents are very common.
countryCurrency:
Belize Dollar (BZD).

Currency can be exchanged at most banks in the larger cities, but facilities are limited in rural areas. Most tourist resorts, hotels, restaurants and tour operators accept US currency, traveller's cheques and major credit cards. When using credit cards, many establishments will add a 5% service charge to the bill.

Although ATMs are available in the main cities, some machines do not accept cards that have been issued outside Belize. The most accepted credit cards include MasterCard, Visa and American Express. 

The import of local currency is limited to BZD$10,000 or equivalent and it must be declared on an entry form. Any form exceeding this must be declared.
countryOverview:
Belize is a constitutional monarchy, and the northernmost Central American nation. Belize is bordered to the north by Mexico, south and west by Guatemala, and to the east by the Caribbean Sea. Belize's mainland is about 180 miles long and 68 miles wide. Belize has more in common with the Caribbean island-states than with its Central American neighbours.

Belize, formerly known as British Honduras, was the UK's last colony on the American mainland. Its independence was delayed until 1981 by long-running tension with neighbouring Guatemala, which claims a large portion of its territory. This is reflected in its major languages, English and Creole, and in its mainly Anglo-Caribbean architecture and its relatively peaceful political culture. Belize has always had strong ties with Britain and the United States, but has recently also forged closer links with Latin American countries such as Mexico and Venezuela.

In common with many Caribbean economies, the service sector has overtaken agriculture, fishing and forestry. Tourism is a major source of foreign currency. Belize's attractions include wildlife, Mayan ruins and one of the longest barrier reefs in the world. More than 200 islands nestle inside the reef.

The head of state for Belize is Queen Elizabeth ll and the Prime Minister is Dean Barrow.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the right hand side of the road in Benin. An international driving permit (IDP) is required for driving in the country. Avoid driving out of the main towns at night as roads in poor condition and often unlit. Take care after dark within cities, avoiding secondary roads and areas where other traffic is light.
Plans are underway to improve conditions in the more rural areas.
The rainy seasons in Benin are March to July and September to November. Heavy rains can cause flooding. Away from the main roads, conditions can become more difficult when some roads can become impassable. Ê Traffic on main roads is fast moving and erratic.
countryCurrency:
Communaute Financiere Africaine Franc (XOF).

American Express, Diners Club, Visa and MasterCard credit cards are all widely accepted throughout Benin. 

Travellers cheques are accepted and to avoid additional charges, travellers should note that travellers cheques should be taken in Pounds Sterling or Euros. 

The import of local currency is unlimited, however it is subject to declaration. The export of local currency is unlimited for EU residents, other nationalities must declare currency. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, subject to declaration and the export of foreign currency is limited to the equivalent of XOF100,000.
countryOverview:
Benin (formerly, Dahomey) is officially the Republic of Benin. It is located in West Africa. It borders Togo to the west, Nigeria to the east and Burkina Faso and Niger to the north. Its small southern coastline on the Bight of Benin is where a majority of the population is located.

The capital of Benin is Porto-Novo, but the seat of government is located in the country's largest city of Cotonou. Benin has a population of approximately 9.05 million. Benin is a tropical, sub-Saharan nation, highly dependent on agriculture, with substantial employment and income arising from subsistence farming. Benin is one of Africa's most stable democracies. It boasts a selection of political parties and a strong civil society.

On the economic side Benin is severely underdeveloped, and corruption is rife. While Benin has seen economic growth over the past few years and is one of Africa's largest cotton producers, it ranks among the world's poorest countries. The economy relies heavily on trade with its eastern neighbour, Nigeria. To the north, there have been sporadic clashes along Benin's border with Burkina Faso. The trouble has been blamed on land disputes between rival communities on either side of the border.

President Yayi won the elections in 2006, replacing Mathieu Kerekou, who was in office for most of the time since he seized power in 1972. Benin are to benefit from G8 commitments to write off their debts. It is pressing Western cotton producing countries to compete more fairly by cutting subsidies to their farmers. Thousands of Togolese refugees are yet to leave Benin and return home.

countryReligon: Anglican 23%, Roman Catholic 15%, African Methodist Episcopal 11%, other Protestant 18%, other 12%, unaffiliated 6%, unspecified 1%, none 14%
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  There is no car rental service available but visitors to Bermuda are able to hire mopeds, scooters or motorbikes.  Visitors do not required driving licence to rent a scooter in Bermuda. However by local law, a minimum age of 18 is required and this may be verified by the rental shop.  It is also mandatory to wear a helmet at all times.  Road conditions are very good throughout the region, but outside larger towns and cities, be aware of  narrow, winding roads that may not have much hard shoulder or pavement.
Speed limits all over the island are low. For example, 15 mph in the main city of Hamilton and 20 mph in the countryside. Pedestrian and bicycle traffic is another hazard and it is advisable to observe speed limits and road signs although locals do not often do this. There is general courtesy shown by native drivers on the roads though.
countryCurrency:
Bermudian Dollar (BMD).

Major Credit/Debit cards, including MasterCard, Visa and American Express, are widely accepted at most hotels, restaurants and shops.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Bermuda is officially The Bermudas or Somers Islands/Sommer Islands and is a British overseas territory in the North Atlantic Ocean. Located off the east coast of the United States, its nearest landmass is Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, about 1,030 kilometres (640 mi) to the west-northwest.

It is one of the world's most prosperous economies. This wealth is largely down to the islands' offshore finance industry; more than 13,000 international companies have made the self-governing territory their nominal base. Internal self-government was guaranteed by the 1968 constitution. Bermuda saw political and racial tensions in the 1970s, culminating in the assassination of the colony's governor and rioting. British troops were despatched to restore order. Independence from Britain is a recurring theme. In a 1995 referendum nearly three quarters of voters rejected the idea, but the issue was revived in 2004 when the colony's premier called for a debate on independence. More recent polls show a large majority remain opposed to independence. The authorities are co-operating with a global OECD initiative aimed at ending "harmful" practices that have plagued the offshore financial industry and given the territory its reputation as a tax haven. In November 2008, in the wake of the global financial crisis, the British government announced a review into offshore financial centres including Bermuda.

countryReligon: Lamaistic Buddhist 75%, Indian- and Nepalese-influenced Hinduism 25%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  A valid driving licence from your own country plus an international driving licence is required. With the exception of the Gasa district, all major towns in the 20 districts of Bhutan are accessible by road. Bhutan has a relatively well developed network of roads.  The majority of roads are sealed but can still be bumpy and are almost always single lane. There are winding routes, high mountains, steep slopes and deep valleys. Steep ascents and descents are characteristic of road travel in Bhutan and this can make travel slow. Average speeds for road travel rarely exceed 30 km/h, with tourist buses making even slower progress.  Bhutanese drivers are very unhurried, calm, and relaxed, because of their Buddhist religion and culture. Night driving is not recommended in Bhutan. Although there are some street lights in Thimphu, much of the road infrastructure is without road markings, and without any reflective studs or signs.  The density of traffic is normally very low.  Older direction signs designed for walkers and animal-drawn traffic were painted on slabs of stone and may be difficult to see or read whilst moving.
countryCurrency:
Ngultrum (BTN).

ATM's only accept Bhutanese bank cards. There is limited acceptance of credit cards. Travellers cheques can be exchanged in any branch of the Bank of Bhutan or at all BTCL hotels.

Travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars. Indian rupees up to the 100 rupee denomination are accepted for purchases in Bhutan.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency, but foreign currency must be declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Bhutan is officially the Kingdom of Bhutan and is a small landlocked state in South Asia, located at the eastern end of the Himalayas and bordered to the south, east and west by the Republic of India and to the north by the People's Republic of China. Bhutan is separated from the nearby country of Nepal to the west by the Indian state of Sikkim and from Bangladesh to the south by West Bengal. Bhutan is a tiny, remote and impoverished kingdom nestling in the Himalayas between its powerful neighbours, India and China. Almost completely cut off for centuries, it has tried to let in some aspects of the outside world while fiercely guarding its ancient traditions.

The Bhutanese name for Bhutan, Druk Yul, means "Land of the Thunder Dragon" and it only began to open up to outsiders in the 1970s. The Wangchuck hereditary monarchy has been in power since 1907. Bhutan became a two-party parliamentary democracy after elections in March 2008. This gave a landslide victory to the pro-monarchy Bhutan Harmony Party of former prime minister Jigme Thinley. The opposition People's Democratic Party also supports the monarchy. Bhutan's ancient Buddhist culture and breathtaking scenery make it a natural tourist attraction. Tourism is restricted though and visitors must travel as part of a prearranged package or guided tour. Backpackers and independent travellers are discouraged.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  As well as a home country driving licence an International Driving Permit is also required, along with adequate insurance.  Car hire is not recommended in Bolivia. Most of the 1000km of the road network is not tarmacced, 25% is gravel or partly paved and roads are pot-holed and poorly maintained.  There is no breakdown service and there are no garages in the more remote areas.  It is easy to become isolated if a breakdown occurs. A 4x4 or off road vehicle with driver is available in the larger cities. There is a lack of adequate lighting and signage. Drivers should be cautious, particularly at night, as roads are often shared with pedestrians and livestock.Traffic rules are a formality in Bolivia, and many local drivers are erratic, aggressive and pay little attention to any sort of road manners. Some Bolivians buy a driving licence without any prior test or exam.  Drink driving is also common.
countryCurrency:
Boliviano (Bs).

There are ATMs in most larger towns and cities. Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are accepted in most mid- to top-range hotels and restaurants, but away from cities there is less acceptance.

US Dollar traveller's cheques are widely accepted but Euro cheques are also increasingly useable. Pound Sterling traveller's cheques are not widely accepted.

There are no import restrictions on local or foreign currencies and export restrictions on local and foreign currencies are up to the amounts imported and must be declared.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  To hire a car in Bosnia and Herzegovina the minimum age limit is 21 years old (age may vary by the car hire category) and the licence must have been held for two years and an international drivers licence is required also. The driver and passengers must wear a seat belt at all times and the driver of the vehicle is prohibited from using a mobile phone whilst driving. Children under the age of 5 must use a suitable child-restraint system.It is advised to stay off the roads in isolated areas, for example in the mountains and remote countryside. This is because the country does still have unexploded landmines remaining. Headlights must be on and dipped at all times. It is advised to have snow chains on your car during winter conditions. Winter tyres are compulsory between the 15th November and the 15th April.Speed limits in the cities are 38mph/ 60km, on main roads 49mph/80km (62mph/100km on dual carriageways) and 80mph/130km on highways or motorways.Exercise extreme caution when driving at night as many roads are badly lit or have no lighting at all. Long-distance travel at night should therefore be avoided. Take care when overtaking and when approaching traffic lights as local drivers have a habit of breaking suddenly when traffic lights change to amber. Traffic police have the power to impose on the spot fines for any traffic offence.  It is advised to keep to surfaced roads and not stray off-road without an experienced local guide as there continues to be a widespread danger of landmines and other unexploded ordnance.
countryCurrency:
Konvertibilna Marka (BAM).

Some Euro notes are accepted but not coins.

Credit cards are generally accepted in top hotels and restaurants, and some gift shops. ATM's are becoming increasingly common in cities like Sarajevo, Mostar and Banja Luka, and even smaller towns. However, an emergency supply of cash is still advisable.

Bosnia and Herzegovina is mostly a cash-only economy and traveller's cheques are exchanged only at select bank.

The import and export of local currency are limited to BAM200,000. There are no restrictions on the import and export of foriegn currencies.
countryOverview:
Bosnia and Herzegovina, sometimes referred to as Bosnia-Herzegovina or simply Bosnia in the West, is a sovereign state in Southern Europe, on the Balkan Peninsula. Bordered by Croatia to the north, west and south, Serbia to the east, and Montenegro to the southeast, Bosnia and Herzegovina is almost landlocked, except for 26 kilometres (16 miles) of Adriatic Sea coastline.

The interior of the country is mountainous centrally and to the south, hilly in the northwest, and flatland in the northeast. Inland is the larger geographic region with a moderate continental climate, marked by hot summers and cold, snowy winters. The southern tip of the country has a Mediterranean climate and plane topography. The country is home to three ethnic groups, or so-called "constituent peoples", a term unique for Bosnia-Herzegovina. Bosniaks are the largest group of the three, with Serbs second and Croats third. Regardless of ethnicity, a citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina is often identified in English as a Bosnian. The terms Herzegovinian and Bosnian are maintained as a regional rather than ethnic distinction, and Herzegovina has no precisely defined borders of its own.

The country was established after devastating three-year war which accompanied the break-up of Yugoslavia in the early 1990s. The 1992-1995 conflict centred on whether Bosnia should stay in the Yugoslav Federation, or whether it should become independent. It is now an independent state, but under international administration. The war left Bosnia's infrastructure and economy in tatters. Around two million people - about half the population - were displaced. International administration, backed at first by Nato forces and later by a smaller European Union-led peacekeeping force, has helped the country consolidate stability.

countryDriving: Driving is on the left side of the road. A home country driving licence is accepted, with an English translation, if necessary. There are 18,482 km of highways in Botswana, of which 4,343 km are paved. Road conditions in the reserves of Botswana are extremely rough and dusty, and the roads can be badly signposted. Four-wheel drive vehicles are essential, as are good driving skills to negotiate these roads in the wild. Botswana is not recommended as a self-drive destination, except as a 4x4 adventure. The national speed limit on tar covered roads is 120 km/h and 60 km/h in towns and villages. Take care and remain vigilant for wildlife on the roads.
countryCurrency:
Pula (BWP).

Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted. ATM's are available in most larger cities and towns.

To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars or Pounds Sterling. Traveller's cheques are accepted in large cities but with a high surcharge.

There are no restrictions on the import of local or foreign currencies, however it must be declared upon arrival. Export of local currency is limited to BWP50 and foreign currencies up to the amount declared.
countryOverview:
Botswana is officially the Republic of Botswana and is a country located in Southern Africa. The citizens are referred to as "Batswana" (singular: Motswana). Formerly the British protectorate of Bechuanaland, Botswana adopted its new name after becoming independent within the Commonwealth on 30 September 1966. It has held free and fair democratic elections since independence.

Geographically the country is flat and up to 70% of Botswana is covered by the Kalahari Desert. It is bordered by South Africa to the south and southeast, Namibia to the west and north, and Zimbabwe to the northeast. It meets Zambia at a single point. Botswana is one of Africa's most stable countries, is the continent's longest continuous multi-party democracy. It is relatively free of corruption and has a good human rights record. It is also the world's largest producer of diamonds and the trade has transformed it into a middle-income nation.

Botswana protects some of Africa's largest areas of wilderness. It is sparsely populated, because it is so dry. The Kalahari desert, home to a dwindling band of Bushman hunter-gatherers, makes up much of the territory and most areas are too arid to sustain any agriculture other than cattle. It is one of the fastest growing economies in the world.

In terms of politics controversy surrounds the forced relocation of San Bushmen from their traditional hunting grounds. The ruling party won all 10 elections since the country gained independence in 1966. Recent economic growth has been high by African standards. The government sees diversification out of diamonds as a priority. Botswana plays an active role in Southern African development community (SADC) economic grouping and has supplied troops for intervention in other parts of Africa.

countryAirport: Philip S. W. Goldson International Airport
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on on the right hand side of the road.  An international driver's licence is not required to drive in Brazil, but it can be useful for police controls. Many roads in Brazil are in very good condition, especially along the coast and in the populated areas in the south. In other regions gravel and dirt roads are common for which a 4WD is the much better option.  The traffic rules are often disregarded by the locals. The maximum speed in Brazil is 60 km/h inside cities, 80 km/h on city outskirts, only 40 km/h on rural roads and 100 km/h on highways.Ê Apart from gasoline, gas stations also sell alcohol because in Brazil, most vehicles can run with both fuels.  Driving behaviour in Brazil can be dangerous, ranging from bad habits such as tailgating to road rage.  Most streets in commercial districts are packed with pedestrians.  There are thousands of stray animals in the streets of Brazil, posing further risks to travellers.
countryCurrency:
Real (BRL).

Most major international credit cards are accepted (Visa more so than other cards), though not universally. There is an extensive network of ATM's around the country.

Travellers cheques are becoming increasingly difficult to cash. Withdrawing cash directly from ATM's is preferable. Banks will not cash travellers cheques into foreign currency, including US Dollars. Some hotels will accept payment in traveller's cheques.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local and foreign currency up to amounts equalling BRL10,000, any amounts exceeding this must be declared.
countryOverview:
The Federative Republic of Brazil is commonly known as Brazil and is the largest country in South America. It is the world's fifth largest country, both by geographical area and by population with over 198 million people. It is the only Portuguese-speaking country in the Americas and the largest lusophone (Portuguese-speaking) country in the world.

It is bordered on the north by Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname and the French overseas department of French Guiana; on the northwest by Colombia; on the west by Bolivia and Peru; on the southwest by Argentina and Paraguay and on the south by Uruguay. Numerous archipelagos form part of Brazilian territory, such as Fernando de Noronha, Rocas Atoll, Saint Peter and Paul Rocks, and Trindade and Martim Vaz. It borders with all other South American countries except Ecuador and Chile.

Brazil is South America's most influential country, an economic giant and one of the world's biggest democracies. It is one of the rising economic powers - otherwise known as BRIC nations - together with Russia, India and China. Over recent years it has made major strides in its efforts to raise millions out of poverty. The discovery of major offshore oil reserves could propel the country into the top league of oil-exporting nations.

The exploitation of the Amazon rainforest, much of which is in Brazil, has been a major international worry, since the wilderness is a vital regulator of the climate. It is also an important reservoir of plant and animal life. A drive to move settlers to the Amazon region during military rule in the 1970s caused considerable damage to vast areas of rainforest. Deforestation by loggers and cattle ranchers remains controversial, but government-sponsored migration programmes have been halted.

Brazils president is Dilma Rousseff

countryCurrency: US Dollar
countryOverview:
The British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT) or Chagos Islands is an overseas territory of the United Kingdom situated in the Indian Ocean, halfway between Africa and Indonesia. The territory comprises the six atolls of the Chagos Archipelago with over 1,000 individual islands (many tiny) having a total land area of 60 square kilometres (23 sq mi). The largest island is Diego Garcia (area 44 km2), and is the site of a joint military facility of the United Kingdom and the United States.

Following the eviction of the native population (Chagossians) in the 1960's, the only inhabitants are US and British military personnel and associated contractors, who collectively number around 4,000 people. To give effect to the decision that the islands should be set aside for the defence purposes of the UK and the USA, the Chagos Archipelago, together with certain islands in the Seychelles group, were detached in 1965 from Mauritius and Seychelles and the settled inhabitants, some 1,200 persons, were subsequently relocated to those two countries.

The islands that had been detached from Seychelles were returned to Seychelles in 1976. There are no economic, industrial or agricultural activities on the islands. Construction projects and other services in support of the US defence facility in Diego Garcia are carried out by UK and US military personnel and civilian contract employees, mostly recruited from Mauritius and the Philippines.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the left hand side of the road.  Holders of foreign driving licenses or an international driving licence are permitted to drive in Brunei for 90 days only.  The roads are of international quality.  There are certain other considerations when driving in Brunei.  Only a driver and a passenger are allowed in the front seats. The passengers in the front seats are required to wear seat belts. There is number of parking areas throughout the country. Drivers can park at multi-storey car parks, covered parks, and areas marked for municipal parking at certain rate. 
Always proceed with caution and adhere to the speed limit of 15 miles per hour (mph) in school zones, 30 mph in business or residential areas and 55 mph on the highways unless road conditions (weather, traffic or accidents) require slower speeds.
Speed limits are posted clearly on signs alongside highways and all major roads.
Travelling beyond the posted speed limit is against the law and drivers are subject to fines in access of $200.00. Traffic police with hidden cameras and Enforcement Officers from Anti-Accident Unit of Land Transport Department will be patrolling the roads to detect any traffic offences. 
Brunei follows international-approved road signs. Some road signs with Malay script are posted in some places. So, travellers and new drivers who are not familiar with Malay must know the signs well before driving. Road users must strictly follow the signs and traffic rules. Black and white striped lane dividers are seen at major junctions in the country. Do not change lanes indiscriminately. Since October 2007, a limit has been imposed on the sale of diesel and petrol for vehicles and vessels not registered in Brunei. There is a problem with vehicles being sometimes driven by unlicensed or uninsured drivers.
countryCurrency:
Bruneian Dollar (BND).

Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are generally accepted by hotels, department stores and major establishments. Credit card purchases may incur a surcharge of 3% to 5%.

ATM's are widely available in cities and towns but not all accept foreign credit/debit cards.

Travellers cheques can be exchanged for a fee at some banks, but few money changers accept them. Cheques denominated in pounds sterling, US dollars and Australian dollars are easiest to exchange. Hotels and many department stores cash traveller's cheques.

The import of local currency is unrestricted. The export of local currency is limited to BND$1,000 in banknotes. Singapore dollars may be imported and exported up to the equivalent of BND$1,000. Indian banknotes may not be brought into the country. The import of other foreign currencies is unlimited, subject to declaration. The export of foreign currencies is unlimited up to the amount imported and declared.
countryOverview:
Brunei is officially the State of Brunei Darussalam or the Nation of Brunei. It is a sovereign state located on the north coast of the island of Borneo, in Southeast Asia. Apart from its coastline with the South China Sea, it is completely surrounded by the state of Sarawak, Malaysia, and in fact it is separated into two parts by Limbang, which is part of Sarawak. It is the only sovereign state completely on the island of Borneo, with the remainder of the island belonging to Malaysia and Indonesia.

Brunei's population is around 400,000. Brunei was the only Malay state in 1963 to choose to remain a British dependency rather than join the Malaysian Federation. It became independent in 1984 and, thanks to its large reserves of oil and gas, now has one of the highest standards of living in the world. Its ruling royal possess a huge private fortune.

A country of dense forests and mangrove swamps whose people enjoy high subsidies and pay no taxes, Brunei is highly dependent on imports. Despite its immense wealth, most of the country outside the capital remains undeveloped and un-exploited. While oil and gas exports account for the bulk of government revenues, reserves are dwindling and Brunei is attempting to diversify its economy. It markets itself as a financial centre and as a destination for upmarket and eco-tourism. About two-thirds of the people of Brunei are ethnic Malays, and these benefit from positive discrimination. The Chinese comprise about 16% of the population. There are also Indians and indigenous groups, of whom the Murut and Dusuns are favoured over the Ibans.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive is on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit allows visitors to drive a private car when accompanied by a valid national driving licence.  Obligatory vehicle documentation consists of registration card, annual technical inspection card and third party liability insurance.  Headlights should be always ON in the period between 01 November and 01 March.
Since Bulgaria joined the European Union in 2007 roads steadily improved. Roads can still be uneven with poor asphalt surface and without markings of the road lanes (especially B roads in the countryside). Motorists should drive with greater attention on countryside roads, especially when driving at night time as potholes or unlit farm carts and animals are a hazard. Winter driving in Bulgaria should be undertaken with caution as some areas of the country experience severe winter conditions. It is highly advisable to use winter-tires (although this is not legally required) and it is the law to carry snow-chains during the winter period (01 November Ð 31 March). It is advisable to drive defensively as sometimes locals may be reckless, travelling at high speed and changing lanes without indicating.
There are no toll roads in Bulgaria. However driving outside the urban areas requires a vignette. This is a road-tax valid for all roads in Bulgaria. It is a sticker that should be put on the right-bottom corner of the windscreen. Keep the receipt and the plastic-sheet left after putting the sticker on in the car at all times. 
Speed limits in Bulgaria 50km/h in built-up areas, 90 km/h on open roads and 130km/h on motorways. Beware of speed cameras or traffic patrol cars with mobile radar's. Speed traps are quite common in Bulgaria, especially on the main roads and during the summer holiday season.
countryCurrency:
Lev (BGN).

ATM's are widespread, although it is best to check with the relevant bank/card provider prior to travel. Not all Bulgarian bank machines accept every overseas credit or debit card and it may take more than one attempt to withdraw cash successfully. Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are accepted in large cities, in larger hotels and car hire offices, and in some restaurants and shops, mainly in Sofia.

However, Bulgaria is still a country that operates mainly on cash. Travellers cheques are accepted in major hotels and restaurants, although cash is far more common. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars, Pounds Sterling or Euros.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, however it must be declared upon arrival. The export of foreign currency is limited to the amount declared upon arrival.

countryReligon: Islam 50%, indigenous beliefs 40%, Christian (mainly Roman Catholic) 10%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  A temporary licence will be issued on presentation of a valid home country driving licence but an International Driving Permit (IDP) is also recommended.  Driving in Burkina Faso can be hazardous. Roads are generally narrow, potholed, and unpaved. There are few streetlights. Pedestrians, bicycles, carts, and vehicles without headlights pose serious hazards. Many trucks transit the country at night. Travel after dark is not recommended.
countryCurrency:
Franc - CFA (Communaute Financiere Africaine).

Credit cards such as Diners Club and MasterCard have limited acceptance. There are no ATMs available.

To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in Euros or US Dollars. Banks often require proof of purchase; so all receipts should be kept as a precautionary measure. It is advised to take at least some Euros in cash.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency, however it must be declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Burkina Faso is also known by its short-form name Burkina and is a landlocked country in west Africa. It is surrounded by six countries: Mali to the north, Niger to the east, Benin to the southeast, Togo and Ghana to the south, and Cote d'Ivoire to the southwest. It is a poor country even by West African standards and has spent many of its post-independence years under military rule.
