Pa'anga (TOP).

ATMs are available in the capital city Nukuâ€™alofa and in the main towns of â€˜Eua island and the Haâ€™apai island group. Visa and Diners Club can be used on the island; the numbers of places that will accept them are very limited.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency.

Travellers cheques are accepted mainly at banks, but will also be accepted in tourist shops and major hotels. It is advised that travellers cheques should be taken in Pounds Sterling or Australian Dollars.
countryOverview:
Tonga, officially the Kingdom of Tonga, is a state in the South Pacific Ocean, comprising 176 islands scattered over 700,000 square kilometres of ocean. The island stretches over a distance of around 800 kilometres. In 2009 the population was estimated at around 104,000. 

Tonga is the last Polynesian monarchy. It is a former British protectorate and became fully independent in 1970. A deeply conservative country, Tonga voted in its first elected parliament in 2010, ending 165 years of feudal rule. 

Agriculture is the key sector for Tonga, however unemployment is severely high.

countryReligon:
Roman Catholic 26%, Anglican 8%, Baptist 7%, Pentecostal 7%, Seventh-Day 
Adventist 4%, other Christian 6%, Hindu 22%, Islam 6%, none 2%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Trinidad & Tobago. Many motorways that are available are four-laned and of good standard however rural roads tend to be winding, narrow and potholed. Local drivers tend to use hand signals to indicate, which can pose a threat to visiting drivers. Congestion is common, especially in and around major cities. Many accidents have occurred on the main North/South motorways and East/West motorways, some of which have led to fatalities.
countryCurrency:
Trinidad and Tobago Dollar (TTD).

Many ATM's take credit and debit card throughout the country. Credit cards that are widely accepted include American Express, MasterCard, Visa and Diners Club.

The import of local currency is unlimited, provided it is declared upon arrival. The export of local currency is limited TTD$200. There is free import of foreign currency, subject to declaration and the export of foreign currency is limited to the amount declared upon arrival.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted and it is advised that cheques be taken in US Dollars, as to avoid any additional exchange charges.
countryOverview:
The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is an archipelagic state in the southern Caribbean, lying just off the coast of north-eastern Venezuela and south of Grenada in the Lesser Antilles. It shares maritime boundaries with other nations including Barbados to the north-east, Guyana to the south-east, and Venezuela to the south and west.

The country is one of the wealthiest countries in the Caribbean, primarily due to its large oil and gas reserves, the exploitation of which dominates its economy. 

The president of Trinidad and Tobago is Maxwell Richards. He was elected president in 2003 and won a second term in 2008.

countryAirport: Habib Bourguiba International Airport & Zarzis Airport
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Driving is dangerous in Tunisia. Local driving standards are very poor, with ignorance towards regulations and traffic lights, both posing a threat to visiting drivers. Lane markings are ignored and bicycles and motorcycles travel with insufficient lighting, making it difficult for drivers. Travel in the desert areas of southern Tunisia also poses challenges. Roads are not paved and visibility tends to be poor.
countryCurrency:
Tunisian dinar (TND).

There are ATM's in most tourist resorts and major towns. Credit cards that are largely accepted include MasterCard, and Visa and American Express and Diners Club.

Travellers cheques are not widely accepted, but can be cashed in banks and other authorised establishments. US Dollars or Euros are generally the most convenient.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, however large amounts, must be declared. Traveller's cheques can be cashed in banks and it is advised that cheques be taken in Euros or US Dollars.
countryOverview:
Tunisia, officially the Tunisian Republic, is the northernmost country in Africa. It is a Maghreb country and is bordered by Algeria to the west, Libya to the south-east, and the Mediterranean Sea to the north and east. Its has an estimated population of just over 10.4 million.

Politically motivated civil unrest in late 2010 and early 2011 led to the resignation of long-serving president Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali on 14 January 2011. In October 2011 he first democratic elections in Tunisia were held, and passed peacefully. Progress is being made towards reforming the political system. 

Tunisian security forces have noted the increased availability of small arms and other weapons in Tunisia since 2011. There have been occasional clashes between armed groups, resulting in casualties and the declaration of temporary curfews.

countryAirport: Atatürk International Airport & Sabiha Gökçen International Airport
countryReligon: Islam (mostly Sunni) 99.8%, other 0.2% (mostly Christians and Jews)
countryLanguage: Turkish. The other language is Kurdish.
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Local drivers pose a threat to travellers, as they are likely to drive at excessive speeds, ignore regulations and ignore traffic lights. These local habits cause many traffic accidents per year. It is advised to avoid driving in rural areas after dark, as local drivers are likely to drive without their headlights on. It is not uncommon to witness large rocks, dead and roaming animals and large potholes when driving throughout Turkey.
countryOverview:
Turkey, known officially as the Republic of Turkey, is bordered by eight countries: Bulgaria to the north-west; Greece to the west; Georgia to the north-east; Armenia, Azerbaijan and Iran to the east; and Iraq and Syria to the south-east. The Mediterranean Sea and Cyprus are to the south; the Aegean Sea to the west; and the Black Sea is to the north. The Sea of Marmara, the Bosphorus and the Dardanelles demarcate the boundary between East Thrace and Anatolia; they also separate Europe and Asia. 
In 2010 the population was estimated at around 73.7 million, making it the 18th most populated country.

Turkey has long been at odds with its close neighbour, Greece, over the divided island of Cyprus and territorial disputes in the Aegean.

Turkey became an EU candidate country in 1999 and, in line with EU requirements, went on to introduce substantial human rights and economic reforms. The death penalty was abolished, tougher measures were brought in against torture and the penal code was overhauled. Reforms were introduced in the areas of women's rights and Kurdish culture, language, education and broadcasting.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit, or national licence with authorised translation, is required.  Car hire is available from a few large hotels. The main road in Turkmenistan runs along the route of the Trans-Caspian Railway.There is also a road that runs north from Ashgabat to Tashauz and Kunya-Urgench before crossing into Uzbekistan. This road crosses 500km (311 miles) of the Kara-Kum desert. Conditions can be hazardous.Road travel at night outside of the cities is dangerous because of the poor condition of the roads.  Driving standards are poor.  Seat belts should be worn at all times but be aware that many taxis do not have them.
countryCurrency:
New Manat (TMT).

Credit cards are not generally accepted and there are no ATM's.

Travellers cheques should be in US currency, but are generally not accepted.  The preferred hard currency is US Dollars and carrying other currencies may find it hard to change them. Foreign currency can be changed at banks and major hotels. Foreigners are expected to pay all travel and hotel bills in hard currency.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited for foreigners. Import of foreign currency is unlimited subject to declaration and export is limited to the amount declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Turkmenistan is also known as Turkmenia and is one of the Turkic states in Central Asia. Until 1991, it was a constituent republic of the Soviet Union, the Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic (Turkmen SSR). Turkmenistan is one of the six independent Turkic states. It is bordered by Afghanistan to the southeast, Iran to the south and southwest, Uzbekistan to the east and northeast, Kazakhstan to the north and northwest and the Caspian Sea to the west. 

Turkmenistan is the most ethnically homogeneous of the Central Asian republics. There are some Uzbeks in the east, as well as small populations of Russians, Kazakhs, Tatars and others.  In contrast to other former Soviet republics, it has been largely free of inter-ethnic hostilities. However, strong tribal allegiances among the Turkmen can be a source of tension.

With foreign investors keeping away, the Turkmen economy remains underdeveloped.  The country has been unable to benefit fully from its gas and oil deposits because of an absence of export routes and a dispute between the Caspian Sea littoral states over the legal status of offshore oil.

Turkmenistan produces roughly 70 billion cubic metres of natural gas each year and about two-thirds of its exports go to Russia's Gazprom gas monopoly. A protracted dispute between the two countries over the price ended in September 2006 when Gazprom agreed to pay 54% more.

Turkmenistan has since made efforts to break out of Russia's hold on its exports. It has opened major gas pipelines to China and Iran, and is considering taking part in the Nabucco pipeline - an EU-backed project designed to provide an alternative to Russian gas supplies to Europe.

countryDriving: Driving is on the left hand side of the road.  A local licence is available for a fee if holding a National Driving Licence or an International Driving Permit (IDP).Car hire is available from some local firms on Providenciales, Grand Turk, and North, Middle and South Caicos.  Most hire cars and jeeps are left-hand drive. Accidents, sometimes serious, are on the increase on the Leeward Highway (Providenciales), especially at night. A tax is levied on all rentals.  Seat belts must be worn at all times. Speed limits are 32kph (20mph) in town and 64kph (40mph) elsewhere.
countryCurrency:
US Dollar (US$).

Credit cards such as MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted.

Travellers cheques are accepted by most hotels, shops, restaurants, banks and taxi services.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
The Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) are a British Overseas Territory consisting of two groups of tropical islands in the West Indies, the larger Caicos Islands and the smaller Turks Islands, known for tourism and as an offshore financial centre.

The Turks and Caicos Islands lie southeast of Mayaguana in the Bahamas and north of the island of Hispaniola. Cockburn Town, the capital since 1766, is situated on Grand Turk Island about 1,042 kilometres (647 mi) east-southeast of Miami in the United States. The islands have a total land area of 430 square kilometres (170 sq mi). The islands are geographically contiguous to the Bahamas, but are politically a separate entity. The total population is about 45,000, of whom approximately 22,500 live on Providenciales in the Caicos Islands.

In August 2009, the United Kingdom suspended the Turks and Caicos' self-government after allegations of ministerial corruption. The prerogative of the ministerial government and the House of Assembly are vested in the islands' incumbent governor, Gordon Wetherell, for a period of up to two years. Thousands of overseas companies are registered in the islands. In 2002 Turks and Caicos was removed from a list of countries and territories considered to be uncooperative tax havens by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), which seeks to end harmful tax practices around the globe. However, by 2009 it remained on the OECD's grey list of those who say they will comply with rules on sharing tax information but have yet to act.

Upmarket tourism is centred on Providenciales, or Provo. Coral reefs and 200 miles of beaches draw holidaymakers and divers, mostly from the US and Canada. But over-development is a concern; some fragile eco-systems, including wetlands and lagoons, are designated as protected areas. There is little agriculture, though the territory is home to the world's only conch farm. The molluscs are exported. Independence moves in the 1980s ended when a pro-dependency government was elected. Islanders have British citizenship. The territory enjoys strong links with Canada and politicians have occasionally mooted a political and economic union. Once a dependency of Jamaica, the Turks and Caicos Islands became a crown colony upon Jamaican independence in 1962.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. The main roads on Funafuti have been paved, but other roads are generally unpaved. Pedestrians and animals are known to walk on the road at night, these factors along with unlit roads, create hazards for drivers.
countryCurrency:
Tuvaluan Dollar & Australian Dollar.

MasterCard may be used at the National Bank of Tuvalu, but on whole credit cards are not accepted. There are no ATM's in Tuvalu and traveller's cheques in Australian Dollars are recommended.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency.
countryOverview:
Tuvalu, formerly known as the Ellice Islands, is a Polynesian island nation located in the Pacific Ocean, midway between Hawaii and Australia. It nearest neighbours are Samoa, Fiji, Nauru and Kiribati. It population stands at around 11,000.

Tuvalu gained independence from Britain in 1978. The country does not have many resources and is heavily dependent on imports for food and resources. It is currently protesting and campaigning against global warming as it has a worries due to it being a low-lying country.

countryReligon: Roman Catholic 33%, Protestant 33%, Islam 16%, Indigenous beliefs 18%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  An International Drivers Licence or international Driving Permit is accepted in place of a Ugandan license. Driving standards are poor as vehicles are often poorly maintained. The accident rate reported in Uganda is high. Main roads are generally in good condition, although secondary roads and dirt roads in rural areas can become dangerous especially after rain spells. Rental cars are available and rental companies usually provide a driver; which is recommended. Speed limits in Uganda in built-up areas are generally 50km/h and out of town 80km/h. The police enforce this law and breaking speed limits can result in a fine, imprisonment or both.
countryCurrency:
Uganda Shilling (UGX)

MasterCard, Visa, Diners Club and American Express are all credit cards that are accepted throughout Uganda, however it must be noted that their acceptance is limited but restaurants, large hotels and shops situated in urban regions are known to accept cards on a regular.

Travellers cheques are not widely accepted outside Kampala. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take travellers cheques in US Dollars or Pounds Sterling.

The import and export of local currency is prohibted. Import of foreign currency is unlimited if declared upon arrival. Export of foreign currency must not exceed the amount declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Uganda, officially the Republic of Uganda, is a landlocked country in East Africa. Uganda is also known as the "Pearl of Africa". It is bordered on the east by Kenya, on the north by Sudan, on the west by the Democratic Republic of the Congo, on the south-west by Rwanda, and on the south by Tanzania. The southern part of the country includes a substantial portion of Lake Victoria, which is also bordered by Kenya and Tanzania.

Uganda gained independence from Britain on 9 October 1962. It is a member of the African Union, the Commonwealth of Nations, Organisation of the Islamic Conference and East African Community.

Terror of Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) over two decades has spread to neighbouring countries. Allied Democratic Forces, a rebel group trying to set up an Islamic state in Uganda, is active in DR Congo. 

Uganda is vulnerable to changes in the world price of coffee, its main export earner. Oil discoveries have boosted prospects.

countryReligon: Ukrainian Orthodox (Kiev Patriarchate 19%, Moscow Patriarchate 9%, no particular division 16%), Ukrainian Greek Catholic 6%, Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox 2%, Protestant, Jewish, none 38% (2004)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Ukraine. Roads outside the major cities are of a poor standard and are poorly lit. Local drivers are known to disregard roads laws, therefore they may ignore traffic signals, and drive at excessive speeds. In Kyiv congestion occurs regularly, leading to many accidents. Fuel may be difficult to acquire in rural areas and spare parts may be unavailable in local villages.
countryCurrency:
Hryvnia.

ATM's are becoming increasingly popular in Ukraine. Credit cards are also becoming more widely accepted in most major establishments and hotels. Cheaper hotels and restaurants may not accept credit cards however.

Traveller's cheques are not recommended as they are very difficult to exchange, however, if travellers wish to take them, they should be made out in US Dollars.
countryOverview:
Ukraine is a country in Eastern Europe. It borders the Russian Federation to the north-east and east, Poland, Slovakia, and Hungary to the west, Belarus to the north-west and Moldova to the south-west, and the Black Sea and Sea of Azov to the south and south-east.

The country has an estimated population of around 46 million.

countryReligon: Islam 96% (Sunni 80%, Shiite 16%), Christian, Hindu, and other 4%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in the UAE. The road network is excellent, however driving standards are very poor throughout the country, with local drivers known to drive at excessive speeds and to tailgate. It was reported that in 2008 there were 2,022 pedestrians hit by vehicles. This, along with roaming animals (especially in rural areas) and drifting sands, all pose a threat to visiting drivers.
countryCurrency:
UAE Dirham.

ATM's do accept foreign credit and debit cards including, Maestro, Cirrus and Switch. ATM's can be found throughout the UAE, especially in petrol stations and hotels.

Credit cards that are widely accepted include MasterCard, Visa, American Express and Diners Club.

Travellers cheques are accepted but not often used. It is advised that travellers cheques should be taken in Pounds Sterling or US Dollars.
countryOverview:
The United Arab Emirates is a country situated in the south-east of the Arabian Peninsula in Southwest Asia on the Persian Gulf, bordering Saudi Arabia and Oman. It shares sea borders with Iraq, Bahrain, Qatar, Iran and Kuwait.

The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is a federation of seven states formed in 1971 by the then Trucial States after independence from Britain. The country has an estimated population of around 8.3 million inhabitants.

Islamic ideals and beliefs provide the foundation of the country's conservative customs, laws, and practices. The UAE has a modern and generally well-developed infrastructure, and tourist facilities are widely available.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the left hand side of the road.   An International Driving Permit is required by nationals of countries whose official language is not English. International, foreign or national driving permits are generally valid for three months. An International Driving Permit is only valid in conjunction with a valid national licence. Permits must be carried at all times while driving.
Few roads on the Island are sealed, and even though the terrain is not extremely rugged, a small four wheel drive provides access to all the popular island sights.
countryCurrency:
Australian Dollar.

Currency can be converted on the island. Major Credit/Debit cards are accepted in some establishments.
countryOverview:
The Territory of Christmas Island is a territory of Australia in the Indian Ocean. It is located 2,600 kilometres (1,600 mi) northwest of the Western Australian city of Perth, 360 km (220 mi) south of the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, and 975 km (606 mi) ENE of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

It has a population of 1,403 residents who live in a number of "settlement areas" on the northern tip of the island: Flying Fish Cove (also known as Kampong), Silver City, Poon Saan, and Drumsite. Named in 1643 for the day of its discovery, the island was annexed and settlement began by the UK in 1888. Phosphate mining began in the 1890s. The UK transferred sovereignty to Australia in 1958. In 2010, Christmas Island had an estimated population of less than 1,500 people. Most of the island is a national park.

English is the official language, although the majority of the population is Chinese. The island's economy consists of tourism and a dwindling phosphate extraction industry. Phosphate, deposited originally as dead marine organisms (not guano as often thought), has been mined on the island for many years.

countryLanguage: Dutch, English, Hindi, Javanese, Sranang Tongo
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. Unpredictable, local driving habits, poorly maintained roads and vehicles and no regard for driving regulations all pose a threat to travellers. The major roads in Paramaribo are mainly paved. In rural areas it is common to find animals and slow moving farm vehicles. Petrol (fuel) stations are few and far between and during the rainy season, impassable sinkholes develop along the road.
countryCurrency:
Surinamese Dollar (SRD).

The most widely accepted credit cards include MasterCard and American Express.

Travellers cheques are accepted but must be changed at banks. And travellers are advised to take travellers cheques in US Dollars and Pound Sterling.

When importing local or foreign currency, amounts exceeding US$10,000 must be declared on arrival and exported currency must not exceed the amount declared on arrival.
countryOverview:
Suriname, officially the Republic of Suriname, is a country in northern South America. At 64,000 sq miles Suriname is the smallest state in South America. Population figures are estimated at 490,000. 

Suriname gained independence from the Netherlands in 1975 and later it endured coups and a civil war. 

The country has the potential to thrive from its tourism, as it has numerous, dense rainforests and colonial architecture. However, the sector is undeveloped and lack the infrastructure.

Suriname has been engaged in a long-running dispute with Guyana, over the territory of a potentially oil-rich offshore region. However a UN tribunal settled the feud in 2007, giving both countries access to the basin and the ruling is expected to bring a surge of exploration by major oil companies.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. The road network provided is good; however at night poorly lit roads pose a threat to travellers. This, along with poor local driving standards, roaming animals and pedestrians, all pose a threat to drivers. The road between Mbabane and Manzini reports the most number of accidents. When entering Swaziland from South Africa, roads are notorious for car jacking.
countryCurrency:
Lilangeni (SZL).

Only a few ATM's can be found throughout Swaziland and only a limited number will accept foreign credit and debit cards. MasterCard, American Express and Visa are accepted at upmarket shops, hotels and restaurants.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted and visitors re advised to take traveller's cheques in Euros and Pounds Sterling.
countryOverview:
Swaziland, officially the Kingdom of Swaziland, is a landlocked country in Southern Africa, bordered by South Africa to the north, south and west. It is one of the world's last remaining absolute monarchies. Its king rules by decree over his million subjects, most of whom live in the countryside and folow traditional ways of life. King Mswati lll, who has been on the throne since 1986, is upholding the tradition of his father King Sobhuza ll, who reigned for almost 61 years and had scores of wives. King Mswati has shown no enthusiasm for sharing power, but banned opposition parties and trade unions have been vocal in their demands for greater democracy and limits on the kings power. 

Thousands have lost their jobs as garment and sugar exoirt industries have lost trading concessions and Swaziland has diplomatic ties with Taiwan rather than China.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Sweden. Roads throughout the country are well maintained and headlights must be on at all times. During the winter season, severe weather conditions can make roads impassable and therefore makes driving hazardous. When driving in many rural areas, travellers may find that there are a large number of cyclists, which pose an extra threat. In 2009 there were 358 road deaths.
countryCurrency:
Swedish Krona (SEK).

ATM's are widely available and credit and debit cards that are accepted include, Diners Club, MasterCard, American Express and Visa, however may shops require ID when paying by credit card.

When importing or exporting local or foreign currency there are no restrictions, however if visitors wish to export or import amounts greater than â‚¬10,000 to a country outside the EU, must be declared.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted, however a charge has to be paid when in use. Visitors are advised to take travellers cheques in Euros or Pounds Sterling.
countryOverview:
Sweden, officially the Kingdom of Sweden, is a Nordic country on the Scandinavian Peninsula in Northern Europe and it is one of the world's most highly developed post-industrial societies. Sweden shares borders with Norway to the west and Finland to the east, and is connected to Denmark by the Oresund Bridge. In terms of Sweden's economy engineering is the key sector in the export-led economy. 

Sweden is the third largest country in the European Union by area, with a total population of approximately 9.4 million. Compared to continental Europe, Sweden has a relatively low population density of 21 inhabitants per square km. 

Sweden is known and highly regarded for its neutrality. With the ending of the Cold War, Sweden joined the European Union in 1995, however it stills refuses to become a Nato member. 

Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt from the centre-right Alliance for Sweden heads a coalition goverment.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is not required to drive in this country. Swiss roads tend to be narrow and winding and, especially in the winter months, road conditions can deteriorate fast due to heavy snowfalls, although road safety standards are high. If visitors wish to drive on the motorways a vignette (car sticker) must be purchased, they can be found in Swiss post offices and border crossings points. In 2009 there were 349 road deaths throughout the country,
countryOverview:
Switzerland, officially the Swiss Confederation, is a federal republic consisting of 26 cantons. The country is situated in Western Europe and is bordered by Germany to the north, Austria and Liechtenstein to the east and France to the west.

Switzerland has a collective head of state, the Federal Council and each year a member of the council is chosen to fill the post of Federal President. Currently, the Federal President is Eveline Widmer-Schlumpf. She will president until 1 January 2013. For decades, the Federal Council was made up by a grand coalition of all the main parties in parliament, in an effort to ensure stability and promote consenus.

The population is estimated at 7.9 million people. There are economic centres in Zurich and Geneva.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Foreign drivers in Syria require an international driving permit (IDP), insurance and a customs certificate. Road conditions are fair to poor overall. Main roads are generally safe but secondary roads can be unreliable, especially during the winter months and during heavy periods of rain. Travellers should avoid driving at night.
countryCurrency:
The national currency is the Syrian Pound.

American Express, Diners Club and Visa cards are widely accepted, but some retail outlets or hotels may refuse to accept Mastercard. ATM services are available in all major cities and accept a range of cards, including Mastercard and Visa. Cash-points are likely to charge a transaction fee that is a percentage of the withdrawal.

Travellers cheques can be difficult to exchange and are not generally recommended.

The country's banking system is state-owned, and there is at least one branch of the Commercial Bank of Syria in every main town. Hard currency can be exchanged for local currency in these branches.
countryOverview:
Syria, officially the Syrian Arab Republic is a country in Western Asia, bordering Lebanon and the Mediterranean Sea to the West, Turkey to the north, Iraq to the east, Jordan to the south, and Israel to the south-west.

Since the 1960s, Alawite military officers have tended to dominate the country's politics. The modern Syrian state was established as a French mandate and attained independence in April 1946, as a parliamentary republic. The post-independence period was tumultuous, and a large number of military coups and coup attempts shook the country in the period 1949-1970. Syria was under Emergency Law from 1962- 2011, effectively suspending most constitutional protections for citizens, and its system of government is considered non-democratic.

Bashar al-Assad is the current president, and is preceded by his father Hafez al-Assad, who was in office since 1971. The country is currently experiencing a period of acute political instability as a result of widespread civil unrest and conflict that began in March 2011. The unrest has affected numerous towns and cities across the country resulting in thousands of fatalities.

countryLanguage: Mandarin Chinese, Min Nan Chinese, Hakka
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. In International Driving Permit (IDP) is required. The motorway system is Taiwan is very good, with traffic signs in international symbols, but some street signs may show places in Chinese. Cities may become congested and many scooters and cycles will be present. People who use scooters may not take into account travel regulations, therefore posing an extra threat to visiting drivers.
countryCurrency:
New Taiwan Dollar.

Credit cards including MasterCard, Diners Club and American Express are accepted in the main hotels shop and restaurants.

Travellers cheques can be cashed in many, shop, hotels and restaurants and to avoid any charges it is advised travellers take cheques in US Dollars.
countryOverview:
Taiwan, also known as Formosa, is an island of East Asia in the western Pacific Ocean and located off the south-eastern coast of mainland China. The island forms over 99% of the current territory of the Republic of China (ROC) following the Chinese Civil War in 1950.

To the north-east are the main islands of Japan and the East China Sea, and the southern end of the Ryukyu Islands of Japan is directly to the east; the Batanes Islands of the Philippines lie to its south across the Bashi Channel. The mountainous island spans the Tropic of Cancer and is covered by tropical and subtropical vegetation. The population is estimated at around 23 million.

It is a major producer of computer technology. Taiwan has few diplomatic ties, however relations with China have improved since President Ma Ying-jeou took tension and this is clear as the main export market for Taiwanese goods is China, however tensions are still present.

countryDriving: Colombian Peso (COP).  Visa and MasterCard are widely accepted, American Express and Diners Club less so. There are ATM’s throughout the main cities; some will allow cash withdrawals using Visa, MasterCard or Cirrus. Traveller's cheques can be exchanged at banks, hotels or bureaux de change. They are generally not accepted as a form of payment, other than at major hotels.
countryCurrency:
Colombian Peso (COP). 

Visa and MasterCard are widely accepted, American Express and Diners Club less so. There are ATM's throughout the main cities, some will allow cash withdrawals using Visa, MasterCard or Cirrus. ATM's that are available are known to be extemely temperamental and tend to run out of money. 

Travellers cheques can be exchanged at banks, hotels or bureaux de change. They are generally not accepted as a form of payment, other than at major hotels.

The import and export of both foreign and local currencies is unlimited, however amounts greater than the equivalent of US$10,000 must be declared.
countryOverview:
Colombia is officially the Republic of Colombia and is a constitutional republic in northwestern South America and its capital is Bogota. Colombia is bordered to the east by Venezuela and Brazil to the south by Ecuador and Peru; to the north by the Caribbean Sea; to the northwest by Panama; and to the west by the Pacific Ocean. Colombia also shares maritime borders with Venezuela, Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica. It is the only South American country having coasts in the Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. It is a middle power and has the fourth largest economy in Latin America. Colombia is famous for producing coffee, coal, oil, flowers and emeralds. 

With a population of over 46 million people, Colombia has the 29th largest population in the world and the second largest in South America, after Brazil. Colombia has the third largest population of any Spanish-speaking country in the world, after Mexico and Spain.

Since the 1960's, government forces, left-wing insurgents and right-wing paramilitaries have been engaged in the continent's longest-running armed conflict. Fuelled by the cocaine trade, this escalated dramatically in the 1980's. Nevertheless, in the 2000's the violence has decreased significantly. Many paramilitary groups have demobilized as part of a controversial peace process with the government, and the guerrillas have lost control in many areas where they once dominated. Furthermore, the strength of these left-wing insurgent groups has decreased dramatically in recent periods. For example, on the 27th December 2013 Colombian military forces killed dozens of members, including a regional commander, of the FARC guerrilla group in the central province of Meta. Colombian Air Force planes are reported to have located a FARC camp situated within the province and subsequentlyneutralized it.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive is on the right hand side of the road.  A home country driving licence and an International Driving Permit for up to three months is required to drive.  On Grande Comore, the main round-island road is of a reasonable standard, but some other roads are in a poor condition.
The police occasionally stop vehicles and carry out random checks, in the hope of detecting any of the 1001 possible (and probable) infractions of the vehicle code. Occasionally foreigners will be asked for their passport, but as long as your visa is in order there should be no problem.
There are many hazards such as pedestrians, animals, broken-down cars and slow-moving zebu carts on the road. It is particularly hazardous to drive at night, as there is no lighting.
Petrol stations of some kind can be found in all cities and in most major towns. Not all have pumps Ð particularly in the Comoros, petrol stations usually consist of a person stationed at the roadside with an array of old Coke bottles full of opaque fuel. For longer trips, and for travel in remote areas, carry extra fuel. Spare parts and repairs of varying quality are available in most towns. Make sure to check the spare tyre of any car you rent before setting out.
countryCurrency:
Comoros Franc (KMF).

Credit cards have a limited acceptance but some hotels do accept them. Some hotels and restaurants will accept foreign currencies, mostly Euros and US Dollars. Change may be given in local currency.

The Banque d'Industrie et Commerce (BIC) (also known as the Banque Internationale des Comores) is the only bank that will change traveller's cheques. There is no blanket policy on hotels accepting traveller's cheques and travellers are advised to contact hotels individually.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
The Comoros is officially the Union of the Comoros and is an archipelago island nation in the Indian Ocean, located off the eastern coast of Africa, on the northern end of the Mozambique Channel, between north-eastern Mozambique and north-western Madagascar. Other countries near to the Comoros are Tanzania to the northwest and the Seychelles to the north-east.

The capital is Moroni on Grande Comore. The country officially consists of the four islands in the volcanic Comoros archipelago: north westernmost Grande Comore or Ngazidja, Moheli or Mwali, Anjouan or Nzwani, and southeasternmost Mayotte or Maore, as well as many smaller islands. At 1,862 km2 (719 sq mi) (excluding Mayotte), the Comoros is the third-smallest African nation by area. With a population estimated at 798,000 (excluding Mayotte), it is the sixth-smallest African nation by population, although it has one of the highest population densities in Africa. The Comoros is the only state to be a member of all of the following: African Union, Francophonie, Organisation of the Islamic Conference, Arab League, and Indian Ocean Commission.

A history of political violence has left the Comoros desperately poor. At times, the country has teetered on the brink of disintegration. The three Indian Ocean islands have experienced more than 20 coups or attempted coups, beginning just weeks after independence from France in 1975 when President Ahmed Abdallah was toppled in a coup assisted by French mercenary Colonel Bob Denard. Colonel Denard featured in several power struggles over the years.

After coups and secession bids, the Comoros gained some stability under a 2001 constitution granting the islands of Grande Comore, Anjouan, moheli greater autonomy within a federation. Comoros is heavily reliant on aid and remittances from the diaspora. The African Union and South Africa have been involved in helping to stabilise the Comoros politically.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  A national driving licence is required to drive for up to three months.
Car hire is available. It is advisable to make advance reservations, especially in the high season. The minimum age is 21. Petrol is approximately a third more expensive than in Europe. There is a speed limit of 65kph (40mph) on the open road, decreasing to 40kph (25mph) in built-up areas and throughout Praslin.
There are paved roads only on La Digue, Mah and Praslin; elsewhere the roads are sandy tracks.
Visitors should be aware that Mah is mountainous with narrow, winding roads, rarely with safety barriers. Take care when driving and avoid more remote roads, particularly at night.  When returning hired vehicles, obtain an acknowledgement that the vehicle has not been damaged during the period of hire.
countryCurrency:
Seychelles Rupee (SCR).

Tourists must pay hotel bills in foreign currency (in the form of cash, traveller's cheques, credit or debit cards). Payment in local currency is only allowed if an exchange receipt can be shown as proof of the conversion from foreign currency into local currency.

Credit cards such as American Express, MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted. Diners Club has more limited use. ATM's are available in Mah and Praslin.
countryOverview:
Seychelles is officially the Republic of Seychelles and is an island country spanning an archipelago of 115 islands in the Indian Ocean, some 1,500 kilometres (932 mi) east of mainland Africa, northeast of the island of Madagascar. Other nearby island countries and territories include Zanzibar to the west, Mauritius and Reunion to the south, Comoros and Mayotte to the southwest.

Seychelles, with an estimated population of 86,525, has the smallest population of any African state. The country's economy depends heavily on a fishing industry and upmarket tourism; the latter is vulnerable to downturns in the global travel market.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Roads in Sierra Leone tend to be winding and extremely narrow, this is also the case in Freetown, where most roads are unpaved and have potholes. It is advised that visitors to the country hire a four-wheel drive vehicle, as many roads tend to be impassable. 
Poor local driving standards and poorly maintained cars, pose a large threat to drivers, and vehicle-related accidents are common. Locals also tend to ignore traffic regulations, traffic lights and may drive without a valid driving license and without proper training. 
During the months of May to September, which is known as the rainy season in Sierra Leone, makes roads impassable, and can increase travel times significantly. 
Roadblocks are common on major roads leading in and out of major cities and towns. The roadblocks are generally made by local police forces, however it is common for police officers to demand money for eligible pass.
The main road from Makeni and Mile 91 to Freetown is suitable for most types of vehicles and is tarmacked.
countryCurrency:
Leone (SLL).

ATM's are extremely limited throughout Sierra Leone. A number of ATM's can be found in Freetown and Kenema and Koidu. There are no MasterCard cashpoints available throughout the country and many ATM's are not internationally connected, which increases the risk from fraud. Only Visa credit cards are accepted, and they are only accepted in some shopping centres, restaurants and hotels in Freetown.

The export and import of local currency is limited to SLL50,000 and the import of foreign currency is limited to $10,000 in cash. Foreign currency being brought into the country must be declared upon arrival and the export of foreign currency must not exceed the amount declared upon arrival.

Travellers cheques are not recommended, as it is very difficult to cash them, however a small number of banks can exchange them.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Singapore. Road conditions throughout the country are in very condition, however local visitors may deem driving standards poor. Motorcyclists are known to ignore lane markings and this can be hazardous for drivers.
countryCurrency:
Singapore Dollar (SGD).

ATM's are widespread and can be found in most major cities and towns. Credit cards that are accepted include, Diners Club, MasterCard, Visa and American Express. 

Traveller's cheques are accepted and travellers are advised to take cheques in Pounds Sterling or US Dollars. A passport is also required when cashing travellers cheques.

The import and export of foreign or local currency is limited to SGD$30,000 .
countryOverview:
Singapore, officially the Republic of Singapore, is a Southeast Asian city-state off the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula, 137 kilometres north of the equator. It is separated from Malaysia by the Straits of Johor to its north and from Indonesia's Riau Islands by the Singapore Strait to it south.

The country is a wealthy city-state, known for the conservatism of its leaders and its strict social control. It has become on of the world's most properous places, with a thriving port and numerous, eye-catching skyscrapers. It has a strong economy, fuelled by its financial services and the manufacturing of electronic goods. 

Since Singapore's independence from Malaysia in 1965, the People's Action Party has been the dominant party. 

It has an estimated population of around 5.1 million.

countryDriving: Vehicles in Slovakia drive on the right hand side of the road. People intending to drive in Slovakia are required to have an International Driving Permit (IDP).The roads are safe and well maintained.  Around Bratislava four-lane roads exist. Drivers in Slovakia are known to be aggressive and therefore pose a serious hazard. Night time driving is not recommended due to poor lighting and narrow, winding roads. Throughout the months of November and March there is known to be heavy snowfall, which is not cleared adequately. Headlights must be used at all times, both throughout the day and night. The legal speed limit is 78mph on the main roads and the limit in towns is 31mph. Mobile phones are prohibited whilst driving.
countryOverview:
The Slovak Republic is a landlocked state in Central Europe. It has a population of over five million.Slovakia is a landlocked country bordered by the Czech Republic and Austria to the west, Poland to the north, Ukraine to the east and Hungary to the south.

Slovakia is a member state of the European Union, NATO, United Nations, OECD and WTO among others. Slovakia is a high-income advanced economy with one of the fastest growth rates in the European Union and the OECD.

The Prime Minister of Slovakia is Robert Fico who leads the leftist Smer party. He won the general elections in March 2012 and was a critic of the former givernment's austerity programme. Slovakia has seen rapid growth in recent years, driven by the exports of cars and electronic cars.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. In International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in this country. In 2009 there were 171 road deaths in Slovenia. The road network is very well maintained and extensive. It uses a 'vignette' system when driving on motorways. These permits can be purchased at petrol stations and in motorway offices. Smaller roads are likely to be narrow and throughout the winter months (December-March) will be very hazardous. Dimmed headlights must be used at all times.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

Credit cards that are accepted throughout Slovenia include MasterCard, Visa, Diners Club and American Express and credit cards can be used to get cash advances from banks.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted and it is advised that travellers cheques be taken in US Dollars, Pounds Sterlings or Euros. 

There are no restrictions on the imports or export of foreign of local currency. Although, amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 must be declared if travelling to a country outside the EU.
countryOverview:
Slovenia, officially the Republic of Slovenia, is a country in Central Europe and Southeastern Europe touching the Alps and bordering the Mediterranean. Slovenia borders Italy to the west, Croatia to the south and east, Hungary to the northeast, and Austria to the north, and also has a small portion of coastline along the Adriatic Sea.

The Prime Minister is Janez Jansa and he leads a centre-right coalition,  Slovenia is an export-dependent economy and it was badly affected by the global economic crisis and the government has mooted spending cuts to balance public finances. 

It has a population of around 2.1 million. The capital and largest city is Ljubljana.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side. International Driving Permits (IDP) are required The number of roads on the island are limited and the roads that are available are often potholed and will have debris on them, due to collapsed bridges. Local driving standards are very poor and poorly maintained cars can pose a threat to travellers. When driving at night, poorly lit roads also pose a threat and drivers must be careful as not to trespass on communal land. Drink driving is a problem on the island and contributes greatly to the number of roads accidents incurred yearly.
countryCurrency:
Solomon Islands Dollar (SBD).

Only three ATM's can be found in the capital. All major credit cards are widely accepted in hotels and tourist resorts.

As long as the currency is declared upon arrival, the import of local and foreign currency is unlimited. The export of foreign currency is unlimited, however the export of local currency must not exceed $250 (Solomon Islands).

Travellers cheques can be exchanged at banks and it is advised that cheques are taken in Pounds Sterling.
countryOverview:
Solomon Islands are a sovereign state in Oceania, east of Papa New Guinea, consisting of almost one thousand islands and it is known to be one of the poorest countries in the region.

The country gained independence from the UK in 1978 and since then it has strived to recover from a civil conflict that brought it to the brink of collapse. Fighting broke out in 1998 when the Isatabu Freedom Movement began to force Malaitans out, accusing them of taking land and jobs. It was reported that around 20,000 people abandoned their homes. A rival militia group, the Malaitan Eagle Force, staged a coup in June 2000 and forced the then prime minister to resign, saying he had failed to deal with th crisis that left 100 people dead. 

It must be stated, that the country appears to have settled since then and Australia currently leads a mission which aims to ensure security. Australian forces arrived in 2003 when violence between ethnic militias threatened to spiral into anarchy.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. International Driving Permit (IDP) is required. Driving in Somalia is dangerous due to the poor road conditions throughout the country.
countryCurrency:
Somali Shilling (SOS), however the US Dollar is widely accepted.

Credit cards are not accepted in Somalia. 

Travellers cheques are not recommended but may be accepted in a number of establishments. 

The import and export of Somali Shilling is limited to S200. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, however it must be declared upon arrival and exchanged at the national banks within five days of arrival. 

US dollars tend to be the easiest currency to exchange and visitors to Somalia will find that hotels tend to be the safest and easiest place to exchange.
countryOverview:
Somalia officially the Somali Republic and formerly known as the Somali Democratic Republic under communist rule, is a country located in the Horn of Africa. Somalia covers the eastern-most portion of Africa. It is bordered by Djibouti to the north-west, Kenya to the south-west, the Gulf of Aden with Yemen to the north, the Indian Ocean to the east, and Ethiopia to the west.

Since the outbreak of the Somali Civil War in 1991 there has been no central government control over most of the country's territory. The internationally recognised Transitional Federal Government controls only a small part of the country.

The population of Somalia is estimated to be around 10.1 million. 

Somalia has been characterised as a failed state and is one of the poorest and most violent states in the world.

countryAirport: Cape Town International Airport & OR Tambo International Airport
countryLanguage: 11 Official languages including English, Afrikaans , Sesotho, Setswana, Xhosa and Zulu
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. 
UK and US driver's licenses are accepted when driving in South Africa. Roads standards a very good in regions, but the road conditions may vary in rural areas. Local drivers tend to ignore driving regulations and traffic lights, and there have been many fatalities every year. Thieves have been known to use methods, that cause the driver to stop, enabling them to rob and take their possessions. Traffic lights throughout the country are known to be out of order regularly, posing another threat to drivers, especially at junctions. 
There are many car rental outlets stationed in many regions of South Africa, and it may be preferable for visitors to hire a car, if on trips lasting several days. 
Car jacking is a serious problem, especially in Johannesburg and Pinetown. To avoid the potential of this occurring, it is advised to hire cars that have central locking systems and to avoid stop signs at night. 
Car jacking and murders occur regularly on the N14 motorway, which connects Northern Cape to Pretoria. A German businessman was killed, in 2009, after leaving his vehicle.
countryCurrency:
Rand (ZAR) 

ATM's can found in many cities and towns, petrol stations and shopping centres, cards that are accepted include MasterCard and Visa, Diners Club and American Express.

The import and export of local currency is limited at ZAR5,000 and the export and import of foreign currency is unlimited, as long as it is declared upon arrival.

Travellers cheques can be used in banks and restaurants and hotels. It is advised that traveller's cheques be taken in Pounds Sterling or US Dollar.
countryOverview:
The Republic of South Africa is located at the southern tip of Africa. Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe border the country to the north and Swaziland and Mozambique to the east.

Throughout South Africa, diversity is a major feature, with 11 official languages. This has not always been the case. Until 1994 South Africa was ruled by a white minority government which was so determined to hang on to power that it took activists most the of the last century before they succeeded in theor fight to get rid of apartheid and extend democracy to the rest of the population. 

In 2009, the ANC scored its fourth election victory, with Jacob Zuma being chosen as the country's president. 

South Africa is one of the continents biggest economies. Even though this is the case, poverty remains widespread and high unemployment rates fuel criminal activity and in 2009 the country entered into recession.
Uninhabited Islands

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Spain. The road network is fairly good, however major cities may suffer large traffic congestion, especially during national holidays and the summer months. On some motorways, there are only two lanes present, which can lead to long queues once more. Driving can be very frantic in Madrid and Barcelona; this can be very hazardous to visiting drivers. In rural areas, other factors can pose a threat to drivers, including poorly marked roads and roaming animals. On major motorways, travellers may also encounter toll roads, which have to be paid at certain payment points.
countryCurrency:
Euro.

ATM's can be found throughout the country and all major cards are generally accepted.

Traveller's cheque can be used in major hotels and can be exchanged in banks branches and exchange bureaux.
countryOverview:
Spain, officially the Kingdom of Spain, is a country and member state of the European Union (EU), located in south-western Europe on the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered by the Mediterranean Sea to the east and south, except for a small land boundary with the British Overseas Territory of Gibraltar; France and Andorra to the north and by the Atlantic Oceana and Portugal to north-west and west.

The population is an estimated 46 million.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Sri Lanka.  Many roads, especially those outside the major towns are in very poor condition, which can make journey times very long and uncomfortable. Road accidents occur on a regular basis, die to erratic local driving standards, pedestrians appearing on the road without notice and roaming animals. Driving, at night, outside Colombo is hazardous. Roadblocks are common throughout the country and police officers may stop vehicles to check the car and luggage. It should be noted that local buses are known for not giving way and for driving at excessive speeds. Many motorways will have only one lane going in each direction, making journeys very inefficient. There is also a risk of landmines in northern and eastern regions of the country.
countryCurrency:
Sri Lankan Rupee (Rp).

ATMs can be found in many major cities, although not all will accept international cards, especially the national bank. Credit cards that are accepted include MasterCard and visa and American Express.

In terms of travellers cheques the rate of exchange for the cheques can be better than the rate of exchange for cash, however they are not always accepted. 

The import and export of local currency is limited to Rp5,000. The import of notes from Pakistan is not permitted. Otherwise, the import of foreign currency is not restricted, however amounts exceeding US$5,000 or equivalent are subject to declaration and the export of foreign currency is limited to the amount declared upon import.
countryOverview:
Sri Lanka is a country off the southern coast of the Indian subcontinent. The country is surrounded by the Indian Ocean, the Gulf of Mannar and the Palk Strait and lies in the vicinity of India and the Maldives. The country has an estimated population of around 21 million inhabitants.

Sri Lanka gained independence from the United Kingdom in 1972. 

In 1983 Sri Lanka entered a civil war, that lasted over 25 years (2009). In that time it is believed that over 70,000 people were killed. Most of the fighting took place in the northern regions of the country, but the conflict also penetrated the heart of Sri Lankan socitey, with the Tamil Tiger rebels carrying out devastating suicide bombings in the capital, Colombo, throughout the 1990's.

There have been ongoing talks between the Sri Lankan government and the biggest Tamil party which may lead to constitutional reforms including substantal regional devolution, which the Tamil party wants, given that the northern and eastern regions are largely Tamil-inhabited.

countryReligon:
Islam (Sunni) 70% (in the North), Indigenous 25%, Christian 5% (mostly in the South 
and Khartoum)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Roaming animals and poor local driving standards pose the largest threat to visiting drivers. Local drivers are known to ignore traffic lights and ignore signals. Only motorways and some roads in major cities are paved, meaning road standards are very poor, with many potholes posing a threat to drivers. It is advised that driving at night be avoided, as many cars do not have functioning car lights. In western and northern regions of the country, sand storms are known to occur on a regular basis, reducing the visibility of drivers.
countryCurrency:
Sudanese Pound (SDG).

ATM's are very limited throughout the country, including in Khartoum. It is advised that, due to ongoing conflicts in Sudan, visitors should take enough cash, so as not to have to use credit/debit cards.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited, however the import and export of foreign currency is unlimited.

Traveller's cheques are not recommended.
countryOverview:
Sudan, officially the Republic of the Sudan is a country in North Africa. It is also considered part of the Middle East politically and geographically. It is bordered by Egypt to the north, the Red Sea to the north-east, Eritrea and Ethiopia to the east, South Sudan to the south, the Central African Republic to the south-west, Chad to the west and Libya to the northwest.

While the population of Sudan predominately descends from both indigenous African groups and Arabs, today most tribes in the country have been Arabized and Arabic and Arab culture predominates. Over 97 percent of the population of Sudan adheres to Islam. The world's longest river, the Nile, divides the country between east and west sides. The country has an estimated population of around 31 million.

Sudan was once the largest and one of the mose geogrphically diverse states in Africa. However, it split into two countries in July 2011 when the people of the south voted for independence. 

Sudan has large areas of cultivatable land, as well as vast amounts of cotton and gold and its oil reserves are ripe for further exploitation.

countryReligon: Roman Catholic 50%, Protestant 20%, Kimbanguist 10%, Muslim 10%, other 10%
countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit is required.  There are several car hire firms represented in Brazzaville.Roads are mostly earth tracks, sandy in dry season and impassable in the wet, suitable for 4-wheel drive vehicles only.There are around 1,200km (750 miles) of paved roads. Poorly marked army checkpoints, often manned by undisciplined soldiers, exist throughout the country.Driving can be extremely hazardous due to poor road conditons and the risk of kidnapping or banditry.
countryCurrency:
CFA (Communaut Financire Africaine) Franc (XAF).

Congo is part of the French Monetary Area. Only currency issued by the Banque des tats de l'Afrique Centrale (Bank of Central African States) is valid. Currency issued by the Banque des tats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest (Bank of West African States) is not. The CFA Franc is tied to the Euro. However, US Dollars are the preferred currency.

Credit cards such as Diners Club and MasterCard have limited use. Hotels in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire accept major credit or debit cards, although prefer cash. One bank in Brazzaville has an ATM.

To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in Euros or Pounds Sterling. These are accepted only in the larger cities.
countryOverview:
The Republic of the Congo is a state in Central Africa. It is bordered by Gabon, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (formerly known as Zaire), the Angolan exclave province of Cabinda, and the Gulf of Guinea.

The Republic of Congo, a former French colony in central West Africa, gained independence in 1960. The country has since been plagued by years of political instability and various security concerns.

A five-year civil war from 1998 to 2003 resulted in the deaths of around 3 million people, not only through the fighting itself, but also through hunger and disease.   There have been no serious episodes of unrest or violence since the March 2003 peace accord. However, heightened caution should be exercised in several regions of the country and continued security awareness remains a key consideration for all visitors.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side.  A home country driving licence and an International Driving Permit is required.  There is a limited availability of rental vehicles at the airport.  Owing to poor maintenance, the roads are among the worst in Africa and only achieve a fair standard around the main towns.??It is wise to check that bridges are safe before crossing.??Vehicle thefts, including hijackings at gunpoint can occur.There is a lack of signage and lighting.  It is not advisable to drive at night.
countryCurrency:
Franc Congolais (CDF).

Credit cards such as MasterCard and Visa are limited to Kinshasa's major hotels. Credit cards cannot be used to obtain cash advances at banks.

Travellers cheques are not recommended. Commission fees are very high, and they are not accepted

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. The import of foreign currency is limited to US$10,000 and the export of foreign currency is unlimited. Because of the parlous state of the economy, the only true repository of value is the US Dollar. Free circulation of foreign currencies is now allowed within the country. Note that purchase of airline tickets within the country can be made only with money exchanged officially.
countryOverview:
The Democratic Republic of the Congo, formerly Zaire, is a state located in Central Africa, with a short Atlantic coastline (37 km). It is the third largest country in Africa by area after Sudan and Algeria and the twelfth largest in the world. With a population of nearly 71 million, the Democratic Republic of the Congo is the eighteenth most populous nation in the world.

In order to distinguish it from the neighbouring Republic of the Congo to the west, the Democratic Republic of the Congo is often referred to as DR Congo, DROC, DRC, or RDC (from its French abbreviation), or is called Congo-Kinshasa after the capital of Kinshasa (in contrast to Congo-Brazzaville for its neighbour). It also borders the Central African Republic and Sudan to the north; Uganda, Rwanda, and Burundi in the east; Zambia and Angola to the south; the Atlantic Ocean to the west; and is separated from Tanzania by Lake Tanganyika in the east. The country has access to the ocean through a 40-kilometre (25 mi) stretch of Atlantic coastline at Muanda and the roughly 9 km wide mouth of the Congo River which opens into the Gulf of Guinea.

The Democratic Republic of the Congo was formerly, in chronological order, the Congo Free State, Belgian Congo, Congo-Lopoldville, Congo-Kinshasa, and Zaire. Though it is located in the Central African UN subregion, the nation is economically and regionally affiliated with Southern Africa as a member of the Southern African Development Community (SADC). This has left it in the grip of a humanitarian crisis. The five-year conflict pitted government forces, supported by Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe, against rebels backed by Uganda and Rwanda. Despite a peace deal and the formation of a transitional government in 2003, people in the east of the country remain in terror of marauding militia and the army.

The war claimed an estimated three million lives, either as a direct result of fighting or because of disease and malnutrition. It has been called possibly the worst emergency to unfold in Africa in recent decades. The war had an economic as well as a political side. Fighting was fuelled by the country's vast mineral wealth, with all sides taking advantage of the anarchy to plunder natural resources.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the left hand side.  Foreign and international driving licences are not accepted in the Islands. A Cook Islands licence is required and can be bought from police headquarters. Drivers must be over 21 and show a current licence from their own country.
Expect to queue up, fill in a form and then wait for an officer to take a head and shoulders photo. To drive a motorbike or scooter, there is the requirement to take a short test which involves riding successfully around the only roundabout on Rarotonga. 
Several companies offer cars for hire from a number of shops and hotels. Motor scooter and bicycle hire is also popular.
Driving in the Cook Islands can be dangerous, particularly at night, due to poor visibility and road conditions. The most significant number of traffic accidents resulting in hospitalisation involves motorcycle riders.
countryCurrency:
New Zealand Dollar (NZD).

Credit cards that are generally accepted include American Express, Diners Club, Visa and MasterCard. 

Travellers cheques are accepted in hotels and some shops.

There are no restrictions on the import of local of foreign currency. Local currency can be exported up to NZD$250. Foreign currency can be exported up to the amount imported and declared.
countryOverview:
The Cook Islands is a self-governing parliamentary democracy in free association with New Zealand. The 15 small islands in this South Pacific Ocean country have a total land area of 240 square kilometres (92.7 sq mi), but the Cook Islands Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) covers 1,800,000 square kilometres (690,000 sq mi) of ocean.

The main population centres are on the island of Rarotonga (14,153 as of 2006), where there is an international airport. There is also a much larger population of Cook Islanders in New Zealand, particularly the North Island. In the 2006 census, 58,008 self-identified as being of ethnic Cook Island Mori descent. With over 90,000 visitors travelling to the islands in 2006, tourism is the country's main industry, and the leading element of the economy, far ahead of offshore banking, pearls, marine and fruit exports.

Defence and foreign affairs are the responsibility of New Zealand, in consultation with the Cook Islands. In recent times, the Cook Islands have adopted an increasingly independent foreign policy. Although Cook Islanders are citizens of New Zealand, they have the status of Cook Islands nationals, which is not given to all New Zealand citizens.

The Cook Islands are prone to tropical storms. Hurricane Martin devastated the northern islands in 1997 causing substantial losses for the black pearl industry. Named after Captain Cook, who explored them in 1773, the islands were once an autonomous home to tribes of mixed Polynesian ancestry. Governments still seek advice on matters of culture, custom and land ownership from a council of hereditary leaders known as the House of Ariki.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  On presentation of a national driving licence or International Driving Permit, a local licence will be issued by the police or car hire firm for a fee.  Seat belts must be worn at all times. Hire cars can be obtained either in Castries, Soufrière and Vieux Fort.All major centres are served by a reasonably good road network. The main cross-island route runs from Vieux Fort in the south of the island to Castries in the north. Roads are narrow and mountainous roads are steep, often with hairpin bends which are not marked.  Four-wheel drive vehicles with automatic gearboxes are popular, and in some areas essential. Driving standards are variable.  Negotiate roundabouts with extreme care. Given local conditions, drive slowly and cautiously. It is common for pedestrians to flag down vehicles in an attempt to get a lift. Do not stop to do so. It is advisable to keep car doors locked when driving. Care should be taken on a number of roads including the main east coast road to/from Hewanorra International Airport, which are still being repaired following damage during Hurricane Tomas in October 2010.
countryCurrency:
Eastern Caribbean Dollar (XCD). 

US Dollars are also accepted as legal tender. The Eastern Caribbean Dollar is tied to the US Dollar.

Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are accepted at all large shopping centres, restaurants and hotels. Most banks have ATM's.

Travellers cheques are accepted. US Dollar cheques are preferred avoids additional exchange rate charges.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Saint Lucia is an island country in the eastern Caribbean Sea on the boundary with the Atlantic Ocean. Part of the Lesser Antilles, it is located north/north-east of the island of Saint Vincent, north-west of Barbados and south of Martinique. It has an estimated population of 173,765 (2009 census). Its capital is Castries.

The island nation has been the home of two Nobel laureates, Arthur Lewis and Derek Walcott. It is the nation with the second most such honourees per capita after the Faroe Islands. Saint Lucia has a legal system based on British common law. The judiciary is independent and conducts generally fair public trials. The financial sector has weathered the global financial crisis, but the recession has affected tourism.

The Head of State is Queen Elizabeth II and the Prime Minister is Kenny Anthony who took office in December 2011.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  A national driving licence or International Driving Permit is required.  There are very few rental cars on the island so it is essential to book in advance. Roads are in good condition with the majority covered with good road markings and signage.
countryCurrency:
Euro (EUR).

It is also common for Canadian & American dollars to be accepted.

ATM's are available in banks and several businesses in Saint-Pierre. One ATM is available at the Banque des les in Miquelon.

Banking establishments will provide currency exchange services, however Canadian and American dollars are accepted widely.

Major credit cards and traveller cheques are commonly accepted.
countryOverview:
The Territorial Collectivity of Saint-Pierre and Miquelon is a group of small French islands in the North Atlantic Ocean. The islands are as close as 10 kilometres from Green Island, part of Newfoundland.

The archipelago has the status of overseas collectivity within France. It is the only remnant of the former colonial empire of New France that remains under French control. In 1992, a maritime boundary dispute with Canada over the delineation of the Exclusive Economic Zone belonging to France was settled by an arbitration court that was set up by Canada and France to resolve the dispute. In the decision, France kept the 12 nautical miles (22.2 km; 13.8 mi) territorial sea surrounding the islands.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. A local driving licence is essential and can be obtained on presentation of a valid national or international licence either at the airport or at the police station in Bay Street, Kingstown, or at the Licensing Authority in Halifax Street, Kingstown. The road infrastructure is generally of a poor standard. Mountain roads can be very narrow and with few guard-rails.
countryCurrency:
Eastern Caribbean Dollar (XCD).

To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars.

All major credit and debit cards are widely accepted.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency, provided declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is an island-country in the Lesser Antilles chain, which lie at the southern end of the eastern border of the Caribbean Sea. To the north of Saint Vincent lies Saint Lucia, to the east Barbados. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has a population of around 120,000 people.

The country has a French and British colonial history and is now part of the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States, CARICOM, the Commonwealth of Nations and the Bolivarian Alliance for the Americas.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. A Samoan driving licence is required to drive in the country and cars can be rented from outside the main airports. Road conditions and maintenance are good but roads outside Apia are often, steep, poorly lit and narrow, all posing a threat to visitors. Roaming animals and pedestrians tend to walk on the roads, again posing another threat. In 2009 Samoa changed from driving on the right to driving on the left, however cars remain left-hand drive
countryCurrency:
Tala (WST).

ATM's are located in and around Apia and the credit cards that are accepted, albeit on a limited basis include, Cirrus, MasterCard, Visa and American Express.

Traveller's cheques are accepted in major hotels, tourist shops and banks. It is advised that travellers take cheques in Pounds Sterling and US Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import and export of foreign currency. The import of local currency is unlimited but the export of local currency is prohibited.
countryOverview:
Samoa, officially the Independent State of Samoa, formerly known as Western Samoa is a country encompassing the western part of the Samoan Islands in the South Pacific Ocean. It became independent from New Zealand in 1962.

The two main islands of Samoa are Upolu and one of the biggest islands in Polynesia, Saval'i. Samoa was admitted to the Untied Nations on 15 December 1976. It has a population of approximately 179,000.

Since 1982 the governing Human Rights Protection Party has been the dominant party. The economy of Samoa is heavily dependent on tourism, agricultural exports and financial assistance from Samoans living abroad.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  A national driving licence is sufficient.  It is a legal requirement for motorists travelling within San Marino to carry one red warning triangle to be placed, in the event of an accident or breakdown, behind the vehicle. In addition, drivers are advised to keep in the car a spare pair of glasses (if needed for driving), a spare wheel, and a full set of spare bulbs plus the tools to change them. If  leaving the vehicle due to accident or breakdown, or whilst awaiting the arrival of the emergency services, it is obligatory to wear a reflective jacket. Failure to do so could result in a heavy fine.   Carry a certificate of car insurance which must be valid for more than three months.San Marino has similar drink driving laws to Italy. The legal limit is 0.05%, also defined as 0.5 grams of alcohol per litre of blood (50 mg/100 ml of blood); this rule also applies to newly licensed drivers and to professional drivers. San Marino authorities are serious about drink driving and have strict penalties. A blood alcohol level below 0.08% will result in administrative sanctions; over this limit, criminal penalties will apply: the driver’s licence and sometimes the vehicle will be confiscated.Talking on mobile phones when driving is forbidden by San Marino law. The speed limit is 70 km/h on some stretches of the highway, while in residential areas the speed limit is 30 and 50 km/h.  The roads are of a high standard but can be narrow.
countryCurrency:
Euro (EUR).

Credit cards are widely accepted. ATM's are available.

Travellers cheques should be taken in Euros to avoid extra commission charges.
countryOverview:
San Marino, officially the Republic of San Marino and is a state situated on the Italian peninsula on the eastern side of the Apennine Mountains. It is an enclave surrounded by Italy. Its size is just over 61 km2 (24 sq mi) with an estimated population of over 30,000. Its capital is the City of San Marino. San Marino has the smallest population of all the members of the Council of Europe.

San Marino is the oldest surviving sovereign state and constitutional republic in the world, as the continuation of the monastic community founded on 3 September 301, by stonecutter Marinus of Rab. Legend has it that Marinus left Rab, then the Roman colony of Arba, in 257 when the future emperor, Diocletian, issued a decree calling for the reconstruction of the city walls of Rimini, which had been destroyed by Liburnian pirates.

The country's economy mainly relies on finance, industry, services and tourism. It is one of the wealthiest countries in the world in terms of GDP (per capita). San Marino is considered to have a highly stable economy, with one of the lowest unemployment rates in Europe, no national debt and a budget surplus. As one of Europe's tax havens, San Marino has traditionally attracted a large inflow of cash from non-residents, but in the wake of the global financial crisis of 2008-9 this status has come increasingly under threat, and the republic has pledged to make its banking system more transparent.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit is not legally required but is recommended.
