Car hire can be arranged through the Miramar Hotel in the capital.  There are over 380km (236 miles) of roads, although in general these are deteriorating. Some of them are asphalted around Sao Tome town, but 4-wheel drive vehicles are necessary to get further afield.  Animals on the road and potholes can be hazardous. There is street lighting only in the capital.  During periods of heavy rainfall there is the possibility of landslips and mudslides. The driving standard of local can be erratic and hazardous.
countryCurrency:
Dobra (STD).

Some hotels accept Visa and MasterCard. Credit cards are accepted in a very limited number of places. Confirm with the hotel or restaurant that they will accept credit cards before incurring expenditure.

There are no ATMs. Cash is available from the main bank in Sao Tome with a Visa card. Travellers cheques can also be exchanged there but are not generally accepted elsewhere.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Local driving standards are very poor, and pose a large threat to visiting drivers. Many of the roads throughout Saudi Arabia are large and open, encouraging drivers to travel at excessive speeds. Accidents involving vehicles driven by minors are not uncommon. The minimum age for drivers is 25 in Saudi Arabia and it is illegal for women to drive.
countryCurrency:
Saudi Arabian Riyal (SAR).

ATM's are widely available throughout Saudi Arabia and tend to be reliable, with widely accepted credit cards being MasterCard and Visa, however some restaurants and shops will accept Discover and America Express credit cards.

There are no restrictions on the import and export of local or foreign currency, however amounts exceeding SAR 60,000 must be declared.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted, and it is advised that visitors take traveller's cheques in Pounds Sterling or US Dollars, so as to avoid any additional exchange charges.
countryOverview:
The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, commonly known, as Saudi Arabia is the largest country in the Middle East by land area, constituting the bulk of the Arabian Peninsula, and the third-largest Arab country. Jordan and Iraq border it on the north and north-east, Kuwait, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates on the east, Oman on the south-east, and Yemen on the south.

The King Fahd Causeway also connects it to Bahrain. The Persian Gulf lies to the north-east and the Red Sea to its west. Saudi Arabia has an estimated population of 25.7 million of which 5.5 million are non-citizens.

It is one of the most devout and insular countries in the Middle East and it has emerged from being an underdeveloped desert kingdom to become on of the wealthiest nations in the region thansk to its vast oil resources. 

After the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington on 11 September 2001, which was carried by many Saudi nationals, the Saudi authorities were further torn between their natural instincts to step up internal security and pressure to allow a greater degree of democracy. 

The Al Saud dynasty holds a monopoly of power, political parties are banned and the opposition is orgainsed from abroad. 

It is the world's dominant oil producer and owner of the largest hydrocarbon reserves.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Some roads are of good quality, however some roads can be poor especially during the months from July to October, which is deemed rainy season. Traffic in the Dakar area is heavy and there are hazards that pose threats to drivers. Poor lighting of streets and other vehicles, the presence of pedestrians and animals, along with bad driving habits makes local driving difficult. Police roadblocks are common and if stopped identification must be presented.
countryCurrency:
Communaute Financiere Africaine (CFA) Franc (XOF).

There are ATM's in the capital but they are limited in rural areas and may not accept foreign cards. American Express is the most accepted and Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa have limited use. If a credit card is used commissions are added.

Travellers cheques are easy to cash in Dakar. It is advised that travellers take them in Euros.

Import of local and foreign currency is unlimited but must be declared. Export of local currency is restricted to XOF20,000 and export of foreign currency is limited to XOF50,000.
countryOverview:
Senegal, officially the Republic of Senegal, is a country south of the Senegal River in western Africa.Senegal is externally bounded by the Atlantic Ocean to the west, Mauritania to the north, Mali to the east, and Guinea and Guinea-Bissau to the south.

Macky Sall won presidential elections in 2012, replacing Abdoulaye Wade who controversially ran for a third term in office. Tourism is the main source of foreign exchange and the agriculture sector drives the economy. 

Senegal has sent peacekeeping troops to Liberia, Kosovo and DR Congo. 

Senegal has an estimated population of about 14 million. The climate is tropical with two seasons: the dry season and the rainy season.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Drivers must own an International Driving Permit (IDP) when travelling to Serbia. The standard of roads ranges from poor to adequate and driving at night is ill advised. Drivers and pedestrians frequently ignore road rules; pedestrians and farm animals can be a problem in rural areas. Special care should be taken in south Serbia, especially in the mountains around the Presevo Valley, as there is still some danger from mines and unexploded ordnance left over from a conflict in 1999. It is advised to keep to main roads unless accompanied by an experienced guide. Many car hire firms will not allow their vehicles to be driven in Kosovo, Albania or Bulgaria due to security concerns. Road works on the main highways across Serbia may cause delays and there are several toll booths along motorways that charge 1,900-18,800 dinars, depending on the size of your vehicle. Serbian drivers sometimes use the middle' lane to overtake, forcing oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder. Drivers should beware of the Balkan bicycle Ð a car with only one functional headlight that might look like an ordinary bicycle in the dark.
countryCurrency:
Serbian Dinar (RSD).

ATM's can be found throughout the country. International credit cards including, MasterCard and Visa are accepted in most shops, restaurants and hotels, however, Diners Club and American Express are not so widely accepted.

Travellers' cheques are not widely accepted, as they are hard to exchange, therefore it is advisable to take hard currency.

The import and export of local currency must not exceed RSD10,000, however, the import and export of foreign currency is unlimited.
countryOverview:
Serbia, officially the Republic of Serbia, is a landlocked country located at the crossroads of Central and Southeast Europe, covering the southern part of Carpathian basin and the central part of the Balkans.

Serbia borders Hungary to the north; Romania and Bulgaria to the east; the Republic of Macedonia to the south; and Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Montenegro to the west; additionally, it borders Albania through Kosovo, whose status as part of Serbia is disputed. The capital of Serbia is Belgrade.

Unemployment is high throughout Serbia, primarily due to eurozone crisis and global recession. 

Tomislav Nikolic, the Serb nationalist leader, won the presidential poll in a run-off against Boris Tadic.

countryDriving:
Traffic drives on the right hand side of the road.  Drivers must have a national licence or International Driving Permit. Drivers must be 25 years of age to rent from most car rental agencies.
The quality of the roads in Costa Rica is quite poor. Stretches of the Pan-American Highway leading to and from the major cities tend to be adequate, but the rest is a mix of dust, gravel, potholes and perilously mountainous roads. Drive cautiously at all times. During the wet season landslides are common. Ensure that the vehicle comes with a good spare tyre and a jack, as it is highly likely that the road condition will result in a puncture.
countryCurrency:
Costa Rican Colone 

Credit cards such as Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are all accepted; American Express slightly less so. Many banks will only process MasterCard for cash credits.

Cash may be the only form of payment in smaller towns and rural areas. ATM's are available and usually accept foreign cards. Travellers can avoid additional exchange rate charges by taking travellers cheques in US Dollars but fewer and fewer businesses in Costa Rica are willing to accept them, and it is better to use the ATM's.
countryOverview:
Costa Rica is officially the Republic of Costa Rica and is a country in Central America, bordered by Nicaragua to the north, Panama to the south, the Pacific Ocean to the west and south and the Caribbean Sea to the east Costa Rica, which means "Rich Coast", constitutionally abolished its army permanently in 1949.  Its citizens enjoy one of the highest life expectancy levels in the Western hemisphere and better living standards than most of Central America. 

In 2007, the Costa Rican government announced plans for Costa Rica to become the first carbon-neutral country by 2021. According to the New Economics Foundation, Costa Rica ranks first in the Happy Planet Index and is the "greenest" country in the world. For decades Costa Rica has stood out for its stability and has benefited from the most developed welfare system in the region.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Local driving standards are poor, with discipline being very poor and excessive speeding occurring often. Qatar is known to have the highest fatality rates among developed and developing nations. In rural areas wandering animals and poor lighting make driving hazardous, especially after dark. The minimal driving age in Qatar is 21 and local laws have increased penalties for driving crimes. Road rage and drunk driving may result in heavy fines.
countryCurrency:
Qatari Riyal (QAR).

Credit cards that are accepted in Qatar include, Diners Club, Visa, MasterCard and American Express.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency, however Israeli currency is prohibited.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted and it is advised that travellers cheques are taken in Pounds Sterling or US Dollars.
countryOverview:
Qatar, also known as the State of Qatar, is an Arab emirate, in the Middle East, occupying the small Qatar Peninsula on the northeasterly coast of the much larger Arabian Peninsula. Its sole land border is with Saudi Arabia to the south, with the rest of its territory surrounded by the Persian Gulf.

It was one of the poorest Gulf states, but it now boasts as one of the richest countries in the region, primarily due to the exploitation of large oil and gas fields. 

Qatar is ruled by the monarch Sheikh Hamad, who became emir when he ousted his father. He advocated greater political openess. He has stated that Qatar will hold its first national legislative elections in 2013. 

In 2010 the population was estimated at around 1.7 million.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required in Reunion. Driving standards are poor and the road system is also poor. There is one main road that runs around the island, this can lead to traffic jams at peak hours. Car hire is very popular and rates are reasonable.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬). 

Diners Club, Visa and American Express are all accepted, however acceptance of MasterCard is limited. There are a small number of ATM's available throughout Reunion.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 must be declared if travelling from or to a country outside the EU.
countryOverview:
Reunion is a French island with a population of around 800,000 located in the Indian Ocean, east of Madagascar about 200 kilometres south west of Mauritius, the nearest island.

Sugar cane was introduced during a brief period of British rule in the early 19th century and it provides the raw material for reunion's main exports, as does tourism. The wealth gap between the population is significantly wide and it has subsequently fuelled social tensions. Unemployment is high and migration is extremely common.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. In International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Romania. Main roads are mainly well maintained, however roads throughout rural areas may be of poorer standard, with poorly lit roads, roaming animals and horse-drawn carts all posing threats to travelling drivers. Roads in the mountains can be particularly hazardous when covered in snow or are wet. Pedestrians and cyclists also share roads with vehicles and it therefore may be difficult to see, especially as roads can be very narrow throughout the country. Traffic laws are very strict and the police may carry out random car checks.
countryCurrency:
New Leu (RON).
 
ATM's accepting Visa and MasterCard can be found in main banks, shopping centres and airports but should not be relied upon. Car hire firms, shops, hotels and restaurants accept all American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa.

The export and import of local currency is prohibited and the export and import of foreign currency is limited to US$10,000 or its equivalent. 

Travellers cheques are only useful for obtaining cash at the bank. It is advised that travellers cheques be taken in Euros or US Dollars.
countryOverview:
Romania is a country located at the crossroads of Central and South-eastern Europe, on the Lower Danube, within and outside the Carpathian arch, bordering on the black sea. The country shares a border with Serbia and Hungary to the west, Moldova and Ukraine to the north-east and east, and Bulgaria to the south.

The economy of Romania suffered greatly during the global financial crisis of 2008. After this occurred the government launched a draconian austerity programme, leading to intense street rallies and clashes with security forces in January 2012. This brought down the government of Prime Minister Emil Boc and brought in a period of political instability. 

Since 2004, Romania's president has been Traian Basescu. In May 2012, Victor Ponta became the country's third prime minister in less than six months.  

Romania has a population of around 21.5 million.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit and a national licence with authorised translations are necessary. Visitors travelling in their own cars must also possess the following documents at all times: passport and visa; car registration number and full details of itinerary; form provided by Customs on arrival guaranteeing that the car will be taken out of the Russian Federation on departure; and insurance cover documents. A road tax is payable upon entry to the country. Motor insurance for travel within the Russian Federation should be arranged prior to departure, or upon entry to the Russian Federation.  Available from local and international firms. Chauffeured cars are available in major cities.Speed limits are to 60kph (37mph) in built-up areas, 90kph (55mph) in non-built-up areas and 100kph (62mph) on highways. Visiting motorists who have been driving for less than two years must not exceed 70kph (43mph). Beeping the horn is forbidden except when to do so might prevent an accident. Every car must display registration plates and stickers denoting the country of registration and be fitted with seat belts, a first-aid kit, a fire extinguisher and an emergency sign (triangle) or red light. In case of an accident, contact the nearest traffic inspection officer and make sure all participants fill in written statements, to be witnessed by a militia inspector. All repairs will be at the foreign motorist's expense.Road users often drive dangerously and erratically. Ice and snow make driving in winter especially hazardous. Roads in Siberia and further east are impassable during the winter.  Road conditions can be poor in rural areas. Routine police checks in public and tourist spots are common. Carry passport, originals of the registered visa and migration card. Photocopies are not acceptable. Failure to provide travel documentation can result in detention and/or substantial fines. If possible, it is not advisable to drive in Russia as harassment from traffic police is endless. It is advisable to pre-plan the itinerary and accommodation requirements.
countryCurrency:
Rouble (RUB).

Major European and international credit and debit cards, including Visa and MasterCard, are accepted in the larger hotels and at foreign currency shops and restaurants, but cash (in Roubles) is more reliable. American Express cards are rarely accepted outside Moscow and St Petersburg. ATM's are widely available.

If using travellers cheques, major currencies are accepted in big cities, but US Dollars and Euros are preferred elsewhere.

The import and export of local currency is prohibted. The import of foreign currency is limited to the equivalent of RUB10,000, but sums greater than the equivalent of RUB63,000 must be declared. The export of foreign currency is limited to the amount imported.
countryOverview:
Russia is officially known as both Russia and the Russian Federation and is a country in northern Eurasia. It is a federal semi-presidential republic, comprising 83 federal subjects. From northwest to southeast, Russia shares borders with Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland (both via Kaliningrad Oblast), Belarus, Ukraine, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, the People's Republic of China, Mongolia, and North Korea. It also has maritime borders with Japan by the Sea of Okhotsk, and the United States by the Bering Strait.

Russia is the largest country in the world, covering more than one eighth of the Earth's inhabited land area. Russia is also the ninth most populous nation with 143 million people. It extends across the whole of northern Asia and 40% of Europe, spanning nine time zones and incorporating a wide range of environments and landforms. Russia has the world's largest reserves of mineral and energy resources. It has the world's largest forest reserves and its lakes contain approximately one-quarter of the world's fresh water.

Following the Russian Revolution, Russia became the largest and leading constituent of the Soviet Union, the world's first constitutionally socialist state and a recognized superpower, that played a decisive role in the Allied victory in World War II. The Soviet era saw some of the greatest technology achievements of the 20th century, such as the world's first human spaceflight. The Russian Federation was founded following the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, but is recognized as the continuing legal personality of the Soviet state. It is one of the five recognized nuclear weapons states and possesses the largest stockpile of weapons of mass destruction.

Russia is a great power and a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, a member of the G8, G20, the Council of Europe and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation. During Mr Putin's presidency Russia's booming economy and assertive foreign policy bolstered national pride. In particular, Russia promoted its perceived interests in former Soviet states more openly, even at the cost of antagonising the West. The tensest moment came in August 2008, when a protracted row over two breakaway regions of Georgia escalated into a military conflict between Russia and Georgia. Russia sent troops into Georgia and declared that it was recognising the independence of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, sparking angry reactions in the West and fears of a new Cold War. At the same time, Moscow threatened to counter plans by the US Bush administration to develop an anti-missile system in Eastern Europe with its own missiles in Kaliningrad Region on Poland's borders. President Obama later withdrew the plan, in a move seen in Russian official circles as a vindication of the assertive foreign policy. Another source of irritation between Russia and the US is Moscow's role in Iran's nuclear energy programme. Russia agreed in 2005 to supply fuel for Iran's Bushehr nuclear reactor and has been reluctant to support the imposition of UN sanctions on Iran. A gradual warming in relations between Russia and the US early in 2010 culminated in the signing of a new nuclear arms treaty designed to replace the expired Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (Start) of 1991.

 Moscow believes any loosening of its grip on Chechnya would result in the whole of the North Caucasus falling to anarchy or Islamic militancy. Human rights groups at home and abroad have accused Russian forces in Chechnya of widespread abuses against the public. Since the 11 September attacks on the US Moscow has tried to present its campaign as part of the global war against terrorism. In a sign of growing confidence that peace might be returning, the Russian authorities called a formal end to the military operation against the rebels in 2009. Sporadic violence continues, however, with a major suicide bomb blast in September 2010 reigniting the debate about the efficacy of the counter-terror campaign.

countryReligon:
Roman Catholic 56.5%, Protestant 26%, Adventist 11.1%, Islam 4.6%, 
indigenous beliefs 0.1%, none 1.7% (2001)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Rwanda. The road infrastructure to all major towns is good, but during the rainy seasons landslides may affect these main roads. Unlit roads and poor driving standards may pose a threat to travelling drivers, especially at night. Motorways are often not marked and may lack hard shoulders. Pedestrians and animals are also a threat, as they may move onto the road without warning. Travellers may be stopped at police roadblocks throughout the country and their luggage may be searched.
countryCurrency:
Rwandan Franc (RWF).

International Visa cards are accepted at Ecobank and Access Bank head offices in Kigali and at Kigali airport. Some banks will not accept sterling. MasterCard and Visa credit cards are only accepted at a few hotels.

It may be difficult to change travellers cheques outside Kigali.

The import and export of local currency is limited to RWF5,000. The import and export of foreign currency is unlimited, but must be declared upon arrival and exchanged within 8 days.
countryOverview:
Rwanda, officially the Republic of Rwanda, is a country is central and eastern Africa with a population of around 11.4 million.

The country is located a few degrees south of the Equator, and is bordered by the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Burundi, Uganda and Tanzania. Mountains in the west, numerous lakes throughout the country and savanna in the east dominate the country. 

Rwanda experienced Africa's worst genocide in modern times, and the countrys recovery was marred by its internetion in the conflict in neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo. The government is trying to shake off its image associated with said genocide and they have claimed the country is now stable. 

Economy growth exceeded 5% in the five years since 2001, driven by coffee and tea exports and expanding tourism. Poverty, however, is still widespread and Rwanda is still heavily dependent on aid. 

The UN International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) have recently convicted 27 people for their involvement in the 1994 genocide.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the left hand side on the road.  Visitors must hold a valid driving licence with no endorsements for dangerous driving or drunken driving in the last 5 years and must be 21 years and over. Before driving, the hirer must also register at the Police Station in Jamestown where they record details of the national driving licence.   It is recommended to book in advance as it can be difficult to book a car once on the Island because of the great demand not only from visitors but returning St Helenians as well. 
Most roads are single lane. Etiquette requires the driver coming downhill to make way for up-coming traffic. The drink drive laws are strictly applied with a limit of 50µg of alcohol per 100ml of breath. 
Unless otherwise stated, normal speed limits are 30mph. Road signs are shown in miles per hour and not kilometres per hour. In Jamestown the speed limit is 20mph.
Petrol and diesel can be bought from Solomon's Fuel Station, Jamestown; Half Tree Hollow Supermarket and Longwood Supermarket.
countryCurrency:
Saint Helena Pound. It is linked at parity to the British Pound (Sterling).

Banking services on St Helena and Ascension Island are provided by the Bank of St. Helena.

Credit Cards are not widely used on the island, although a few outlets and business will accept them. Commission (variable rate) will be charged for using a credit card. Bank of St. Helena can advance cash against Credit or Debit Cards. Please note that all cash advances are subject to charges and must be accompanied by identification bearing a photograph and signature. The Bank of St. Helena also offers foreign exchange facilities.

Travellers' cheques are recommended for visitors and can be cashed at the Bank. St Helena currency can be used on Ascension Island and on the RMS St Helena.
countryOverview:
Saint Helena is named after St Helena of Constantinople, is an island of volcanic origin in the South Atlantic Ocean.

It is part of the British overseas territory of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha. Apart from Ascension, the islands are only accessible by sea. Saint Helena was discovered in 1502 after which it became a busy way station for sea farers up until the late 1800's. After this period, steam trains replaced sail, and the opening of the Suez Canal changed the pattern of sea routes. 

The RMS St Helena is the only method of transport to gain access to the island, however there is a plan put in place to build an airport in 2012.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  A local driving licence must be purchased before driving.  These are usually bought from the car hire company, at a cost of around EC$ 100.  A current national driving licence or International Driving Permit is required to obtain this.  A selection of cars and mopeds can be hired from several companies. It is best to book cars through the airline well in advance. When hiring scooters safety equipment is not included in the price; those hiring these must bear this in mind as other road users do not usually give scooters due consideration. A good road network on both islands makes any areas easily accessible. Extra care must be taken at night as roads are not well lit.  Main roads are generally well maintained but many follow winding routes so careful driving is necessary.  Be alert for stray livestock and speed bumps in some areas that are not well marked.
countryCurrency:
Eastern Caribbean Dollar (XCD).

US Dollars are also legal tender on the islands. The Eastern Caribbean Dollar is tied to the US Dollar.

All major cards are widely accepted. ATMs are widely available.

To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take travellers cheques in US Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency, however it must declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
The Federation of Saint Kitts and Nevis is located in the Leeward Islands and is a federal two-island nation in the West Indies. It is the smallest sovereign state in the Americas, in both area and population.

The capital city and headquarters of government for the federated state is Basseterre on the larger island of Saint Kitts. The smaller state of Nevis lies about 2 miles (3 km) south-east of Saint Kitts.

By 2003, Nevis was home to around 17,000 offshore businesses operating under strict secrecy laws, making the islands a target for drugs traffickers and money launderers. Laws have been introduced to crack down on the problem.

The Head of State is Queen Elizabeth II and the Prime Minister is Denzil Douglas, who won a fourth consecutive term in office in January 2010.

countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road. A national driving licence is required but must be accompanied by verification from the embassy of the issuing country that it is genuine.   Insurance is compulsory for the driver.  Cars can be hired in Abidjan, main towns and at the airport.Cote d'Ivoire has a good road system by West African standards, with 68,000km (42,250 miles) of roads, 5,600km (3480 miles) of which are surfaced.However, drivers should be aware of potholes and poorly lit vehicles.Petrol stations are frequent except in the north.Drivers should be aware that grass or leaves on the carriageway often means an accident or other hazard ahead.  Road quality can vary considerably and broken down vehicles may be almost invisible after dark.  Many vehicles driving on rural roads will not have any working lights.From May to November torrential rains can cause floods and landslides making driving hazardous.
countryCurrency:
CFA (Communaute Financiere Africaine) Franc (XOF). Currency can be exchanged at the airport as well as at main banks and hotels.

Cote d'Ivoire is part of the French Monetary Area. Only currency issued by the Banque des Etats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest (Bank of West African States) is valid; currency issued by the Banque des Etats de l'Afrique Centrale (Bank of Central African States) is not. The CFA Franc is tied to the Euro.

Credit cards such as American Express and MasterCard are widely accepted; Diners Club and Visa have more limited use.

Travellers cheques are accepted in hotels, restaurants and some shops.
countryOverview:
The Republic of Cote d'Ivoire is a country in West Africa. It is commonly known in English as Ivory Coast. It borders the countries; Liberia, Guinea, Mali, Burkina Faso and Ghana; its southern boundary is along the Gulf of Guinea.

The country is still recovering from a period of severe political stability, which prevailed following the November 2010 presidential elections, when incumbent President Laurent Gbagbo refused to cede power to the internationally recognized winner Alassane Ouattara.

The situation was marked with violence and instability, and prompted the temporary ordered departure of non-essential personnel from diplomatic missions in Abidjan.

Following Gbagboâ€™s capture in April 2011 and President Ouattaraâ€™s inauguration in May, violence and instability have subsided. The new government faces significant challenges in terms of security, the economy, national reconciliation, and humanitarian needs. The security situation in Abidjan could deteriorate at short notice. Policing presence in Abidjan, which disappeared in March during the political crisis, is returning but is still not fully deployed.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the right hand side.  A national or International Driving Permit is required. All motorists should also carry a valid passport or national identity card as proof of identity at all times. A Green Card should be carried by visitors (except EU nationals) taking their own car into Croatia. Third party insurance is mandatory when hiring a car and a valid credit card is also needed.  International and local car hire firms have offices in Croatia's airports, cities, bigger towns and leading resorts.
There is a good motorway network but it doesn't extend down the coast to Dubrovnik. In some areas the road quality decreases somewhat, and the main coastal highway gets extremely congested during peak season. Motorways are designated ÔA', highways as ÔE'. The A1 is the main artery. Take care when overtaking and use caution around other road users who may unexpectedly overtake repeatedly in slower traffic. Minor roads are usually unlit at night.
_Croatia has laws stating that it is illegal to drive with more than 0.5% of alcohol in the system, to drive without dipped headlights on Êduring daylight saving period or to use a mobile phone whilst driving. It is obligatory to carry a fluorescent vest in the car whilst driving in Croatia. The vest must be in the car and not in the boot. The vest must be worn whilst attending to a breakdown, e.g. Êchanging a tyre. All passengers must wear seat belts.
countryCurrency:
Kuna (HRK).

Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted.

ATM's are widespread.

Travellers cheques are accepted. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars, Pounds Sterling or Euros. Foreign currency can be exchanged in banks, by authorised dealers and post offices.

The import and export of local currency is limited to Kn15,000. The import and export of foreign currency is unlimited but it is compulsory to declare upon arrival the amounts that exceed the equivalent of â‚¬10,000.
countryOverview:
Croatia is officially the Republic of Croatia and is a country in Central Europe and Southeastern Europe at the crossroads of the Pannonian Plain, the Balkans, and the Adriatic Sea. Its capital and largest city is Zagreb. Croatia borders Slovenia to the north, Hungary to the northeast, Bosnia and Herzegovina to the southeast, Serbia to the east, and Montenegro to the southeast.

On 25 June 1991, Croatia declared independence and became a sovereign state. Croatia is a member of the United Nations, the Council of Europe, NATO, the World Trade Organisation and CEFTA. The country is a candidate for membership in the European Union, which it is expected to join in 2013, and is a founding member of the Union for the Mediterranean. Croatia is classified as an emerging and developing economy by the International Monetary Fund and a high income economy by the World Bank.

The centre-left government of PM Zoran Milanoviv took over in December 2011, riding a tode of anger over corruption and economic stagnation. Service industries throughout Croatia predominate and shipbuilding is a mainstay of manufacturing. Croatia is set to join the EU in 2013 after voters approved accession in January 2012. There is a dispute with Slovenia over an area of land and sea in the northern Adriatic.

countryDriving: Driving is on the left hand side of the road.  A national driving licence is sufficient to hire a car.  The speed limit is 50km/hr; 40km/hr in the shopping centre and 30km in the heritage area at Kingston. Cows, chickens, ducks and other livestock roaming the roads have right of way.  Locals give a friendly ÔNorfolk Wave' to all passing vehicles. It is polite to wave back.
countryCurrency:
Australian Dollar (A$).

Travellers cheques and most credit cards are widely accepted.

Banking can be carried out at Commonwealth and Westpac branches at Burnt Pine. There is a Commonwealth Bank ATM.
countryOverview:
Norfolk Island is a small island in the Pacific Ocean located between Australia, New Zealand and New Caledonia.

The island is part of the Commonwealth of Australia, but it has a large degree of self-governance. In 1979, Norfolk was granted limited self-government by Australia, under which the island elects a government that runs most of the island's affairs. As such, residents of Norfolk Island are not represented in the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia, making them the only group of residents of an Australian state or territory not represented there.

In 2006, a formal review process took place, in which the Australian government considered revising this model of government. The review was completed on 20 December 2006, when it was decided that there would be no changes in the governance of Norfolk Island. Financial problems and a reduction in tourism led to Norfolk Island's administration appealing to the Australian federal government for assistance in 2010. As a result Islanders will pay income tax for the first time but will be eligible for greater welfare benefits.

countryReligon: Autonomous religious activities now almost nonexistent; government-sponsored religious groups exist to provide illusion of religious freedom
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  An International driving licence is not accepted and in order to drive within the country it is necessary to sit a local driving test and obtain a local licence.  The quality of major roads is good and many are dual carriageways.
All roads leading out of Pyongyang have police security checkpoints where identity documents must be produced before continuing the journey. Fuel constraints and the near absence of private cars have relegated road transportation to a secondary role. The road network was estimated to be around 31,200km but only 7.5 percent is paved. The rest of the roads are of dirt, crushed stone, or gravel, and are poorly maintained. There are three major multilane highways: a 200-kilometre expressway connecting P'yongyang and Wonsan on the east coast, a 43 kilometre expressway connecting P'yongyang and its port, Namp'o, and a four-lane 100- kilometre motorway linking P'yongyang and Kaesong.
countryCurrency:
Won (KPW).

Hotels tend to only accept cash payments in local currency whilst shops prefer US Dollars. Main hotels in Pyongyang will accept credit and debit cards such as Mastercard and Visa. However, American Express is not usually accepted.

Travellers cheques are generally not accepted. However, US Dollars are often accepted as an alternative method of payment.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. The import and export of foreign currency is unrestricted, subject to declaration on arrival.

countryDriving:
Traffic drives on the right hand side of the road.  International Driving Permit or national licence accepted.  There are good roads in and around major island centres.
Self-drive cars are available in towns. US driving laws are followed.
countryCurrency:
US Dollar (US$).

Major credit cards are accepted at most retailers and restaurants.  In Saipan, the major banks, and some restaurants and stores have ATM machines. The Bank of Guam has branches on Tinian and Rota, complete with ATMs.
countryOverview:
The Northern Mariana Islands, is a commonwealth in political union with the United States, occupying a strategic region of the western Pacific Ocean. It consists of 15 islands about three-quarters of the way from Hawaii to the Philippines. The Northern Mariana Islands has an estimated population of 80,362 (2005 estimate). The islands of Agrihan and Alamagan have fewer than ten residents each, and the remaining islands are unpopulated. The regions saw some of the heaviest fighting in the Pacific during World War II. After the war, the Northern Marianas were governed by Washington as a UN-mandated Pacific trust territory. 

The Commonwealth's center of government is in the village of Capital Hill on Saipan. As the island is governed as a single municipality, most publications name Saipan as the Commonwealth's capital.

Gregorio Sabian, in November 2008, was elected as the first nonvoting delegate to the US House of Representatives.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit or national driving licence and log book are required.  A Green Card is strongly recommended (for those with more than third party cover on their domestic policy).  Without it, visitors with motor insurance in their own countries are allowed the minimum legal cover in Norway; the Green Card tops this up to the level of cover provided by the visitor's own policy.  The minimum age to drive is 18.
Tolls are charged on certain cross-country roads, underwater tunnels and in certain cities such as Bergen, Oslo and Trondheim. There are severe penalties (usually involving imprisonment) for drink driving, and fines for illegal parking are high. Fines for speeding are high. Seat belts are compulsory. 
It is obligatory for all vehicles to drive with dipped headlights at all times. Carrying spare headlight bulbs is recommended. Speed limits are 80, 90 and rarely 100kph (50, 56 and 61mph) outside built-up areas and 50kph (31mph) in built-up areas. Snow chains or winter tyres are advised during the winter (however, most urban areas now levy a toll on vehicles with studded tyres). 
Distances are great and driving can often be slow. Narrow and winding roads may be hazardous and impassable, especially in winter. The road system is of variable quality (especially under freezing winter conditions in the north), but supplemented by numerous car ferries across the fjords.
Roadside checks for alcohol are frequent, and submission to a breathalyser is mandatory. Penalties for driving under the influence are severe and can lead to a prison sentence. The 0.20ml limit means in effect no alcohol 12 hours before driving.
countryCurrency:
Norwegian Krone (NOK).

All major credit and debit cards are widely accepted, with Visa, MasterCard and American Express being the most popular. ATM's are widely available. Bank opening hours are quite restrictive, especially in summer, though cashpoints are widely available.

Travellers cheques are accepted in banks, hotels, some shops and by airlines.

The import and export of local and foreign currency is restricted to NOK25,000, amounts exceeding this must be declared.
countryOverview:
Norway is officially the Kingdom of Norway and is a Nordic unitary constitutional monarchy occupying the western portion of the Scandinavian Peninsula, as well as Jan Mayen, the Arctic archipelago of Svalbard and Bouvet Island. Norway has a total area of 385,252 square kilometres (148,747 sq mi) and a population of about 4.9 million. It is the second least densely populated country in Europe.

The majority of the country shares a border to the east with Sweden; its northernmost region is bordered by Finland to the south and Russia to the east; in its south Norway borders the Skagerrak Strait, across which Denmark is situated. The capital city of Norway is Oslo. Norway was a founding member of NATO. Discovery of oil and gas in adjacent waters in the late 1960's boosted Norway's economic fortunes.

In referenda held in 1972 and 1994, Norway rejected joining the EU. Key domestic issues include immigration and integration of ethnic minorities, maintaining the country's extensive social safety net with an ageing population, and preserving economic competitiveness.

Labour Party leader Jens Stoltenberg heads a centre-left government. Parliamentary elections are due in 2013. Norway enjoys large gas and oil wealth and any surplus revenue is invested in a sovereign wealth fund.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Certain nationalities can use their national driver's licence.  Driving standards are not to a high level in Oman. Roaming animals, poorly maintained roads and speeding local drivers all pose threats to visitors when travelling at night. Off road driving can be hazardous and should be undertaken in a convey of four-wheel-drive vehicles with an experienced drive.
countryCurrency:
Omani Rial (OMR).

ATM's are available throughout the country. All major credit cards are accepted.

Traveller's cheques are accepted and it is advised that travellers take traveller's cheques in US Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Oman, officially called the Sultanate of Oman, is an Arab state in southwest Asia on the southeast coast of the Arabian Peninsula. It is bordered by the United Arab Emirates to the northwest, Saudi Arabia to the west, and Yemen to the southwest. The coast is formed by the Arabian Sea on the southeast and the Gulf of Oman on the northeast.

The Madha and Musandam enclaves are surrounded by the UAE on their land borders, with the Strait of Hormuz and Gulf of Oman forming Musandam's coastal boundaries. Oman has a population of around 2.8m.

Sultan Qaboos seized power in 1970 and rules by decree, he has recently moved to increase popular participation in decision making. The country is heavily dependent on oil and the policy of Omanisation aims to replace expatriate workers with locals.

countryReligon: Islam 97% (Sunni 77%, Shiite 20%), Christian, Hindu, and other 3%
countryCurrency:
Pakistani Rupee.

There are numerous ATM's throughout Pakistan, with many located in the major cities of the country. Credit cards are widely accepted, especially MasterCard, American Express and Visa, however Diners Club have limited use.

Export and import of local currency is limited to PKR100 and the import and export of foreign currency is unlimited.

Travellers cheques are accepted in Pakistan, especially in major hotels, banks and shops.
countryOverview:
Pakistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan is a sovereign state in South Asia. It is bordered by Afghanistan and Iran in the west, India in the east and China in the far northeast. In the north, Tajikistan lies adjacent to Pakistan but is separated by the narrow Wakhan Corridor. In addition, Oman is also located in maritime vicinity and shares a marine border with Pakistan. Strategically, Pakistan is located in a position between the important regions of South Asia, Central Asia and the greater Middle East.

Pakistan is a federal parliamentary republic consisting of four provinces and four federal territories, with a population exceeding 182 million people. Since gaining independence, Pakistan's history has been characterised by periods of military rule, political instability and conflicts with neighbouring India. The country faces challenging problems including terrorism, poverty, illiteracy and corruption.

Pakistan has the seventh largest standing armed forces in the world and is a declared nuclear weapons state, being the first and only nation in the Muslim world.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Most roads on the main island of Koror are in good condition, but the conditions of roads in rural areas may cause problems to travelling drivers. Local drivers usually ignore the speed limit (25mph) and local drink drivers and roaming animals, at night pose a threat. Road signage is poor throughout the country and vehicle safety regulations are rarely enforced. There is still unexploded ordinance left over from World War II, particularly in Peleliu.
countryCurrency:
US Dollar (US$).

ATM's can be found in Koror but are limited throughout the rest of the country. Credit cards, including MasterCard, American Express and Visa, are widely accepted in Koror state, but are not accepted in any of the other smaller islands.

US travellers cheques are advised and there is no limit on the amount of foreign or local currency to be imported or exported. On some islands large amounts may need to be declared.
countryOverview:
Palau, officially the republic of Palau, is an island nation in the Pacific Ocean, 500 miles east of the Philippines and 2,000 miles  south of Tokyo.

Having emerged from United Nations trusteeship in 1994, it is one of the world's youngest and smallest sovereign states. It is heavily dependent on US aid, partly on tourism and income from foreign fleets fishing in Palau's waters.

countryCurrency:
Balboa (PAB)

Credit cards generally accepted throughout Panama, with MasterCard and Visa beIng the most commonly used and accepted. 

ATMs are plentiful throughout Panama, especially throughout the main cities of the country. They are found in or next to banks, or in streets marked by the red 'sistema clave' sign. Banks are known to charge for withdrawals, however it is a relatively small payment.
countryOverview: Panama, officially the Republic of Panama, is the southernmost country of Central America and connects the North and South America. It is bordered by the Caribbean to the north, Costa Rica to the west and Colombia to the southeast and the Pacific Ocean to the south. It was reported the Panama City, the capital of the country, is the city with the happiest people in the world. As of January 2013 the population was estimated at over 3.5 million inhabitants.

countryReligon:
Roman Catholic 22%, Lutheran 16%, Presbyterian/Methodist/London Missionary 
Society 8%, Anglican 5%, Evangelical Alliance 4%, Seventh-Day Adventist 1%, 
other Protestant 10%, indigenous beliefs 34%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is needed to drive in Papua New Guinea. Roads, throughout the country are in very poor condition. Local drivers are known to drive whilst drunk and at excessive speeds. In Port Moresby, roadblocks are common, which can cause delays to travel. Vehicle-related accidents are common.
countryCurrency:
Papua New Guinean kina.

ATM's are limited throughout the country. Credit cards that are accepted include, MasterCard, Visa and American Express.

There are no restrictions on the import of local or foreign currency. The export of local currency is restricted to K200 and foreign currency to the equivalent of K10,000 travellers cheques are accepted in most shops and it is advised that visitors take cheques in Pounds Sterling or US Dollars, so as to avoid any additional exchange charges.
countryOverview:
Papua New Guinea, officially the Independent State of Papua New Guinea, is a country in Oceania, occupying the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and numerous offshore islands. It is located in the south-western Pacific Ocean, in a region defined since the early 19th century as Melanesia. The capital is Port Moresby.

Papua New Guinea has strong ties with its southern neighbour, Australia, which administered the territory until independence in 1975. 

Papua New Guinea is one of the most culturally diverse countries on Earth, with over 850 indigenous languages and at least as many traditional societies, out of a population of just under seven million.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. The quality of roads throughout Paraguay differs from town to town. Local drivers may pose a threat to visitors due to their aggressive style of driving and lack of recognition of traffic regulations. When driving after dark, unlit cars and animals may be present on the roads and there have been reports of assaults against motorists. Travellers have been killed and injured in traffic accident throughout recent years.
countryCurrency:
Guarani (PYG).

ATM's are can be found throughout the country with MasterCard, Visa, American Express and Diners Club are widely accepted. When purchasing a product by credit card, ID may be required.

Travellers cheques in US Dollars are not widely used and there are no import or export restrictions of foreign or local currency.
countryOverview:
Paraguay, officially the Republic of Paraguay, is a landlocked country in South America. It is bordered by Brazil to the east and north-east, Argentina to the south and south-west and Bolivia to the north-west.

The country experienced over three decades of dictatorship under Alfredo Stroessner, who was ousted in 1989 and died in exile in 2006. This did not bring politcal stability and Stroessner's party, the National Republican Association-Colorado Party, survived his departure and remained in power until 2008. During the elections in April 2012, it was defeated by the centre-left Patriotic Alliance for Change, led by Fernando Lugo. On 21 June 2012 the Paraguayan congress initiated impeachment proceedings against President Fernando Lugo, which led to his resignation on the 22 June 2012.

The population is estimated at 6.2 million. Up to 95% of Paraguayans are mestizos, people of mixed Spanish and native American descent.

countryReligon:
Roman Catholic 81%, Seventh-Day Adventist 1%, other Christian 1%, 
Unspecified or None 16% (2003 est.)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Peru. Local driving standards are very poor, with drivers likely to drive at excessive speeds and with ignorance for regulations are traffic lights. This threat causes many accidents and fatalities yearly. Protesters tend to create roadblocks, which can cause delays to travel. Intercity bus crashes are common, especially in mountainous regions. It is advised that travellers do not drive in rural areas, even throughout the day, due to the high levels of vehicle crime, including car jacking. Foreigners driving at night, especially women travellers are considered an east target for assault at traffic lights.
countryCurrency:
Nuevo Sol (PEN).

ATM's can be found throughout the country and all major credit cards, including MasterCard and Visa are accepted. Outside Lima, the changing of travellers cheques can be slow and it is advised tat visitors take travellers cheques in US Dollars. Use may be limited in certain areas.

Amounts greater than US$10,000 must be declared when exporting and importing local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Peru, officially the republic of Peru, is a country in western South America. It is bordered on the north by Ecuador and Colombia, on the east by Brazil, on the southeast by Bolivia, on the south by Chile, and on the west by the Pacific Ocean. Peru is a representative democratic republic divided into 25 regions and an estimated population at 29 million.

It is rich in silver, copper, lead, zinc, gold and oil. Peru experienced an economic boom throughout the 2000's and in 2011 the country was said to have one of the fastest-growing economies. Foreign investors, attracted by the government and encourages by favourable conditions, have been keen to get involved in exploiting the country's mineral wealth. 

Ollanta Humala took over as president in 2011. Although the country has seen growth, much of the population is poor and the US and Peru have agreed a free trade deal. Peru is seen as the world's top producer of coca, used to make cocaine and Peru and Chile dispute their maritime border.

countryReligon:
Roman Catholic 81%, Evangelical 3%, Iglesia ni Kristo 2%, Aglipayan 2%, 
other Christian 5%, Islam 5% (2000)
countryDriving:
Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  A foreign driving licence can be used for up to three months after arrival, after which an International Driving Permit is required. The license or permit must be carried when driving.  The minimum driving age is 17. Seat belts are compulsory, although this is widely ignored by locals.  Car hire is available in Manila and in major cities, with offices in airports and occasionally in large business hotels. It's common to hire a car with a driver, particularly to drive through Manila's busy traffic.
Road conditions and traffic make driving in much of the country (particularly the cities) stressful and sometimes hazardous. Defensive driving is essential and patience is required for dealing with queues of traffic in urban areas.
Roads are spread among the islands, with highways on the Mindanao, Visayas and Luzon island groups.
Further roads are currently being constructed.
Driving off the main highway at night is dangerous and should be avoided.
Private vehicles are banned from most roads in the city between 7am and 7pm for one day a week. This procedure depends on the vehicles license plate (for example, plates ending in 1 or 2 are banned on Mondays).
countryCurrency:
Philippine Peso (PHP).

Credit cards such as MasterCard and Visa (and to a lesser extent American Express and Diners Club) are accepted in major establishments throughout the larger cities of the Philippines. Elsewhere acceptance is less reliable. ATM's are widely available in cities and major tourist areas, but may not be present on smaller islands or in mountain areas. It is best to check ahead before relying on the presence of ATM's.

Travellers cheques may be cashed at most banks, and are accepted by some tourist-oriented hotels, restaurants and shops. This process can, however, be long-winded and frustrating. To reduce the difficulties, visitors are advised to take travellers cheques in US Dollars and to carry their receipt of purchase as well as their passport when cashing them.

The import and export of local currency is limited to PHP10,000, any amount above this must be authorised by the Central Bank of the Philippines. The import and export of foreign currency is limitied to equivalent of US$10,000
countryOverview:
The Philippines is officially known as the Republic of the Philippines and is a country in Southeast Asia in the western Pacific Ocean. To its north across the Luzon Strait lies Taiwan. West across the South China Sea sits Vietnam. It is bounded on the east by the Philippine Sea. Its location on the Pacific Ring of Fire and its tropical climate make the Philippines prone to earthquakes and typhoons.

An archipelago comprising 7,107 islands, the Philippines is categorized broadly into three main geographical divisions: Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. Its capital city is Manila. With an estimated population of about 94 million people, the Philippines is the world's 12th most populous country.

Since 1969, the government has faced a protracted guerrilla campaign across much of the country by the communist New People's Army (NPA). A serious effort at talks in February 2011 resulted in an agreement with the NPA to work towards a peace deal by 2012, although mutual distrust remains a problem.

The Philippines has the highest birth rate in Asia, and forecasters say the population could double within three decades. Governments generally avoid taking strong measures to curb the birth rate for fear of antagonising the Catholic Church, which opposes artificial methods of contraception.

Millions of Filipinos live in extreme poverty, with the country being heavily dependent on money sent home by overseas workforce. 

The Philippines maintains close ties with the US, which has provided military aid to help combat Muslim and communist insurgencies.
TBC Population less than 100

countryAirport: John Paul II International Airport Kraków-Balice
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. In International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Poland. Polish roads can be hazardous, particularly as the country is a major east-west transit route for heavy vehicles. Major roads between cities can be narrow posing another threat. Overall, roads throughout the country are poorly lit, winding, frequently under repair and are often used by cyclists and pedestrians. Drink driving is a contributing factor to accidents and fatalities throughout the country. Vehicle rental is available throughout the country.
countryCurrency:
Zloty (PLN).

Maestro and visa debit and credit cards can be used to withdraw money from ATM's, which are widely available. In larger establishments American Express, MasterCard, Visa and Diners Club cards are all accepted.

The export and import of foreign currency is unlimited, however amounts over 10,000 must be declared if travelling to and from countries outside the EU.
countryOverview:
Poland, officially the Republic of Poland, is a country in Central Europe bordered by Slovakia to the south, Germany to the west, Belarus, Lithuania and Ukraine to the east and he Baltic Sea to the north.

Prime Minister Donald Tusk's governing coaltion won a second term in October 2011. Since EU accession 2004, the economy has boomed, making Poland one of the region's better-performing regions. Although this is the case, unemployment is very high. Germany is Poland's biggest trading partner and there was a massive movement of workers to western Europe in the years after joining the EU.

The population is estimated at around 38 million people, making it the 34th most populous country in the world.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Travellers may drive with foreign drivers licences for 90 days accompanied by an International Driving Permit (IDP). The road network is relatively modern, however some roads in the Algarve are old, poorly maintained and narrow and may pose a threat to travelling drivers. Aggressive local driving habits, excessive speeds, poor lighting, narrow streets, roaming animals and blind spots all pose a threat to drivers and are the cause of many driving accidents and fatalities throughout Portugal.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

MasterCard, Visa and American Express are all widely accepted credit cards.  ATM's can be found at most of the shopping areas and supermarkets situated in the urban cities of the country. 

There are no restrictions on the import and export of local and foreign currencies.

Traveller's cheques are readily exchanged and it is advised that travellers take traveller's cheques in Euros.
countryOverview:
Portugal, officially the Portuguese Republic, is a country situated in southwestern Europe in the Iberian Peninsula. It is the westernmost country in Europe, and is bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the south and west and by Spain to the north and east.

In 2011 Portgual, a eurozone member, was bailed out by the IMF and EU with a â‚¬78bn bailout package. 

Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho of the Social Democrats, heads a coalition with the Popular Party.

In 2011 the population was estimated at around 11 million.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  US or foreign licence accepted for 120 days of stay, after which a national licence will be required.  Car hire is available at the airport and city agencies. International and local firms are represented.  Traffic in all major cities is bad during rush hour (8am-10am, 4pm-6pm), allow extra time during these periods.
Road signs are Spanish language versions of their U.S. counterparts. Note that distances are in kilometres, while speed limits are in miles. Fuel is also sold by the litre, not by the gallon.
In addition to the regular free highway network, there are three toll roads on Puerto Rico. They're much faster and less congested than the highways. 
Away from the main roads, conditions can be narrow with many twists and turns, especially in the mountains. Roads that are only one-and-a-half lanes wide are common, so it is advisable to beep before driving into blind bends. Signage is often minimal, although intersections do almost always show the road numbers
countryCurrency:
US Dollar (US$).

All international credit cards, and many leading debit cards are accepted. All major ATM services are also available.

Travellers cheques in various currencies are accepted, but US Dollar cheques are preferred.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. However, amounts exceeding US$10,000 or its equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
Puerto Rico is officially the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and is an unincorporated territory of the United States, located in the north-eastern Caribbean Sea, east of the Dominican Republic and west of both the United States Virgin Islands and the British Virgin Islands. 

Puerto Rico comprises an archipelago that includes the main island of Puerto Rico and a number of smaller islands, the largest of which are Vieques, Culebra, and Mona. Under American administration Puerto Rico has seen growth and development. But nationalist sentiment sometimes spills over into violence, notably in the 1930's and 1940's. Nationalists staged an armed attack in the US Congress in 1954.

A series of bombings and killings in the 1970's and 1980's were blamed on a pro-independence group, the Macheteros, or Cane Cutters. The group's fugitive leader was killed by federal agents in 2005. The once substantial US military presence has been scaled down with the closures of a major naval base and a bombing range. Tourism is an important source of national income; the island receives up to two million visitors each year and is a port-of-call for cruise liners.

Puerto Rico's Head of State is President Barack Obama and it's Governor is Luis Guillermo Fortuno, who began his term in January 2009.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the right hand side.  A valid national driving licence is required to hire a car.   The road conditions are generally adequate.  All major routes are well maintained although there are sometimes small patches on long routes that haven't been recently repaired and caution is advised while driving on these bumpy parts.Ê Cuba uses internationally recognised driving and traffic symbols although roads are not always signposted.Ê Cuba has a lot of cyclists who sometimes ride in the middle of the road.
There is a lack of street lighting and potholes are common on Cuban roads. In the countryside, drivers will share the road with horse drawn carriages, bicycles, and various farm equipment and animals.
Very few Cubans own cars, and outside of major cities almost the only vehicles on the road are agricultural deliveries.
With heavy goods traffic concentrated on the motorway, many provincial primary roads are in fairly good condition.
The use of seat belts while driving is optional. The speed limit for driving on freeways in Cuba is 100km p/h, while the driving limit in urban areas is 50km p/h.Ê
countryCurrency:
Convertible Peso (CUC).

US Dollars are no longer accepted in Cuba and visitors will be charged 10% commission on exchanging them.

Credit cards such as MasterCard and Visa are increasingly accepted, provided they are not issued by a US bank, or a bank with links to the US, but hefty fees are often added.

ATM's are more common but not universal. Cash can be obtained in banks and Cadecas with non-US Visa credit and Visa debit cards.

Travellers cheques in US Dollar, Pounds Sterling and other major currencies are accepted. US Dollar cheques issued by US banks are not accepted but American Express travellers cheques issued by non-US banks can be exchanged, though not everywhere. It is recommended to take cheques in a currency other than US Dollars.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, subject to declaration of funds exceeding US$5,000 on arrival. Export is allowed up to the amount imported and declared.
countryOverview:
The Republic of Cuba is an island nation in the Caribbean. The nation of Cuba consists of the main island of Cuba, the Isla de la Juventud, and several archipelagos. Havana is the largest city in Cuba and the country's capital. Santiago de Cuba is the second largest city. To the north of Cuba lies the United States and the Bahamas, Mexico is to the west, the Cayman Islands and Jamaica are to the south, and Haiti and the Dominican Republic are to the southeast.

Cuba is home to over 11 million people and is the most populous island nation in the Caribbean, as well as the largest by area. Its people, culture, and customs draw from diverse sources, such as the aboriginal Tano and Ciboney peoples, the period of Spanish colonialism, the introduction of African slaves and its proximity to the United States.

Cuba has survived more than 40 years of US sanctions intended to topple the government of Fidel Castro. It also defied predictions that it would not survive the collapse of its one-time supporter, the Soviet Union. Since the fall of the US-backed dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista in 1959 Cuba has been a one-party state led by Mr Castro and - since February 2008 - by his anointed successor, younger brother Raul.

US economic embargo has been in force since 1961 and since the collapse of USSR and loss of Soviet aid, there have been several tentative moves towards economic liberalisation. EU and US have pressed for democratic change and criticise the state of human rights. Venezuela under Hugo Chavez is an import ally.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive throughout the country. Morocco has a poor road safety record. In 2009, 3,946 people died due to road accidents in the country and 103,180 people were wounded. Road travel should be avoided at night in urban areas due to the risk of motor accidents with other drivers and animals. Road conditions in desert and mountainous areas are often treacherous, with roads only the width of one car in many stretches. Local drivers also pose a threat, as they do not adhere to road safety rules.
countryOverview:
Morocco, officially the Kingdom of Morocco, is a country located in North Africa. It has a population of more than 36 million and an area of 710,850km, and also primarily administers the disputed region of the Western Sahara.

It is a part of the Maghreb region, in addition to Tunisia, Algeria, Mauritania, and Libya, with which it shares cultural, historical, and linguistic ties. Its rich culture is a mix of Arab, European, Berber and African influences. 

The status of Western Sahara remains unresolved and Morocco annexed the territory in 1975 and a guerilla war with Algerian-backed pro-independence forces ended in 1991. 

After numerous, deadly suicide bombings in Casablanca in 2003, Morocco launched a crackdown on suspected Islamic militants.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit is recommended.
Cars can be hired from international and local agencies in Maputo and Beira. Only cash is accepted.
Seat belts are obligatory. Drivers should look out for pedestrians and livestock, especially in rural areas. During the rainy season (November to April) travel by four-wheel drive vehicle is recommended for most road travel outside Maputo. 
There are reports of pedestrians deliberately causing accidents in order to extort money from foreign drivers.
Checkpoints are common throughout Mozambique and drivers should obey police signals to stop. There have been reports of police soliciting bribes from tourists. Fuel (petrol and diesel) is often only available in larger towns.
Third party insurance cover is compulsory in Mozambique. This can be purchased at most land border crossings where there are insurance company offices.
Road safety regulations (introduced in December 2009) require all motorists to carry two reflective triangles and a reflective vest in their vehicle at all times. It is compulsory for all motorists to wear the reflective vest when repairing, loading or unloading a vehicle on a public highway. Not having these items in your vehicle could incur a penalty.
countryCurrency:
Mozambique Metical (MZN).

The new Metical replaced the old Metical (MZM) on 1 July 2006. 1 MZN = 1,000 MZM. The old notes ceased being legal tender on 31 December 2006.

Credit cards are increasingly accepted in Maputo, but not generally beyond the capital.

Travellers cheques are not commonly accepted, and where accepted are slow to process and often attract high rates of commission.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, subject to declaration. The export of foreign currency is limited to the amount declared on arrival.
countryOverview:
Mozambique is officially the Republic of Mozambique and is a country in south-eastern Africa bordered by the Indian Ocean to the east, Tanzania to the north, Malawi and Zambia to the north-west, Zimbabwe to the west and Swaziland and South Africa to the south-west. The capital city is Maputo.

Mozambique became independent in 1975, and became the People's Republic of Mozambique shortly after. It was the scene of an intense civil war lasting from 1977 to 1992.

Mozambique's present day economy is considered one of huge potential. The country's economy is based largely on agriculture but with industry, mainly food and beverages, chemical manufacturing, and aluminium and petroleum production, growing fast. The country's tourism sector is also growing. Foreign investors are showing interest in Mozambique's untapped oil and gas reserves, and titanium mining is a growing source of revenue. Most of the population works the land, however, and infrastructure nationwide still suffers from colonial neglect, war and under-investment.

The economy suffered serious setbacks when in 2000 and 2001 Mozambique was hit by floods which affected about a quarter of the population and destroyed much of its infrastructure. Furthermore, in 2002 a severe drought hit many central and southern parts of the country, including previously flood-stricken areas. Poverty remains widespread, with more than 50% of Mozambicans living on less than $1 a day.

Frelimo party has been in power since independence from Portugal in 1975. Mozambique was one of the world's poorest countries in 1975, but has emerged as one of the fastest growing economies. It is expected to become one of the world's largest exproters of coking and thermal coal, as well as liquefied natural gas.

countryReligon:
Buddhist 89%, Christian 4% (Baptist 3%, Roman Catholic 1%), Islam 4%, 
Animist 1%, Other 2%
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  International Driving Licences and foreign licences are not accepted. Those wishing to drive must apply for a Myanmar licence at the Department for Road Transport and Administration in Yangon (Rangoon).  There has been some modernisation of Myanmar's once antiquated vehicles.
Roads are poorly maintained and can become impassable in the rainy season.
Visitors must remember that, under Myanmar law, the driver of a car involved in an accident with a pedestrian is always at fault.
Overland travel can be hazardous, particularly in the rainy season (May to October). Roads can become impassable and bridges damaged. Travel by road between many areas outside the key destinations of Rangoon, Mandalay, Bago and Irrawaddy regions is restricted.
countryCurrency:
Kyat (MMK).

To combat the black market and limit the financial power of dissident groups, currency denominations are occasionally declared invalid without prior notice. Limited refunds are usually allowed for certain sectors of the population. The import and export of local currency is prohibited.

It is unlikely that credit or debit cards will be accepted. Check with the card company prior to travel. There are no ATM's. Travellers cheques are not currently accepted, although this may change. Take plenty of US Dollars in cash.

The import and export of local currency is prohibited. There are no import limits on foreign currencies, but any amounts must be declared on arrival and must be converted within one month of arrival and the declaration certificate kept for departure. There are no limits on the export of foreign currency for visits up to six months, up to the amount imported and declared.
countryOverview:
Myanmar is officially the Republic of the Union of Myanmar (also known as Burma) and is a country in Southeast Asia. The country is bordered by the People's Republic of China on the north-east, Laos on the east, Thailand on the south-east, Bangladesh on the west, India on the north-west, and the Bay of Bengal to the south-west, with the Andaman Sea defining its southern periphery.

Since independence in 1948, the country has been in one of the longest running civil wars among the country's myriad ethnic groups that remains unresolved. From 1962 to 2011, the country was under military rule and in the process has become one of the least developed nations in the world. The military junta finally dissolved in 2011 following a general election in 2010 and the subsequent inauguration of Myanmar's civilian government.

Myanmar is a resource rich country. However, since the reformations of 1962, the economy has become one of the least developed in the world. Myanmar's GDP stands at $42.953 billion and grows at an average rate of 2.9% annually the lowest rate of economic growth in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Among others, the EU, United States and Canada, have imposed economic sanctions on Myanmar. Myanmar's health care system is one of the worst in the world: World Health Organisation ranked Myanmar at 190th, the worst performing of all countries. The United Nations and several other organisations have reported consistent and systematic human rights violations in the country, including child labour, human trafficking and a lack of freedom of speech.

Due to the recent unrest there is a dusk to dawn curfew imposed in the towns of Kyauktaw, Minbya, Mrauk-U, Sittwe, Buthidaung, Maungtaw, Kyaukphyu, Ramri and Thandwe.

countryLanguage: English, Herero, Nama, German, Oshivambo, Afrikaans
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Namibia and it must be carried at all times. Drivers must also be aware of any presence of landmines in the border area of Katwitwi. Roads between major towns are generally of a high standard. During the months of January to April, many roads become impassable due to the heavy rain showers. There is also a high level of road accidents throughout the country. Many of the roads are gravel and salt roads, posing a threat to drivers, therefore speeds should not exceed 50 mph. certain hazards exist, including, wild animals, reckless motorists and poorly maintained vehicles. It is also advised not to drive at night, as there have been reports of banditry.
countryCurrency:
Namibian Dollar (NAD).

ATM's can be found in most towns, however distances between the towns can be vast. Credit cards that are accepted include, MasterCard, Diners Club, American Express and Visa. Credit cards are not accepted at petrol stations; therefore hard cash should be used.

Travellers cheques can be used in Namibia and it is advised that travellers take travellers cheques in South African Rand or US Dollars.

The import and export of local currency is limited to NAD50,000 and the import and export of foreign currency is unlimited, however it must be declared on arrival.
countryOverview:
Namibia, officially the Republic of Namibia, is a country in southern Africa whose western border is the Atlantic Ocean. It shares land borders with Angola and Zambia to the north, Botswana to the east and South Africa to the south and east. Its capital and largest city is Windhoek.

It gained independence from South Africa on 21 March 1990, following the Namibian War of Independence. Namibia is a member state of the United Nations (UN), the Southern African Development Community (SADC), the African Union (AU), and the Commonwealth of Nations. 

Much of the country is covered by desert and their dunes take on shapes and colours according to the elements. 

President pohamba took over from independence fighter Sam Nujoma, who led the ruling SWAPO party until 2007. The opposition has only minor representation in parliament. Namibia's main trading partner is South Africa and the government is keep to step up land acquisitions from white farmers.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. The main road circling the island is paved and the remaining roads are unpaved. Pedestrians and animals walking on the road make driving at night on unlit roads hazardous. Care hire is available, but should be organised though a hotel.
countryCurrency:
Australian Dollar (A$).

There are no ATM's in Nauru and credit cards are not accepted.

There are no restrictions on the import of local or foreign currencies, however they must be declared on arrival. There are no restrictions on the export of local currency up to A$2,500.
countryOverview:
