Dalia Grybauskaite is the country's first female president and Prime Minister Andrius Kubilius heads a centre-right government. Lithuania is aiming to be a part of the eurozone by 2014, taking a tough austerity drive to tackle the impact of the global recession.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  A valid national driving licence is sufficient.  The minimum age for driving is 18.  Third Party insurance is necessary. A Green Card is not obligatory but is strongly recommended. Without it, visitors have only the minimum legal cover in Luxembourg (if they have motor insurance at home). The Green Card tops this up to the level of cover provided by the visitor's domestic policy. All the main hire car agencies operate in Luxembourg.
As in the rest of Western Europe, there is an excellent network of roads and motorways in Luxembourg.
The wearing of seat belts is compulsory in the front seat and in the back, where seat belts are fitted. The speed limit is 50kph (31mph) in built-up areas, 90kph (56mph) outside built-up areas, and 120kph (74mph) on motorways.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard, Visa and others are all widely accepted, as well as Eurocheque cards. Many retailers require a minimum (e.g. 10-25) before accepting credit/debit cards.

ATM's are common.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take travellers cheques in Euros, Pounds Sterling or US Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the export or import of foreign or local currency if travelling to or arriving from a country in the European Union. If travelling to or from a country outside the EU, amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or its equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
Luxembourg is officially the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. It is a landlocked country in western Europe, bordered by Belgium, France, and Germany. Luxembourg has a population of over half a million people.

Luxembourg is a member of the European Union, NATO, OECD, the United Nations, Benelux, and the Western European Union, reflecting the political consensus in favour of economic, political, and military integration. The city of Luxembourg, the capital and largest city, is the seat of several institutions and agencies of the European Union.

Luxembourg's prosperity was formerly based on steel manufacturing. With the decline of that industry, Luxembourg diversified and is now best known for its status as Europe's most powerful investment management centre. But the country's strict laws on banking secrecy produced a system that was open to exploitation for the purposes of tax evasion and fraud.

Concern over Luxembourg's reputation as a tax haven - especially in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis - prompted the G20 group of countries to add it to a "grey list" of nations with questionable banking arrangements in April 2009. Luxembourg responded by taking steps to improve the transparency of its financial arrangements. By July 2009 it had signed agreements on the exchange of tax information with a dozen countries, and was commended by the OECD for its prompt efforts to implement the internationally agreed standard.

Jean-Claude Juncker has been the country's prime minister since 1995 and he served on the European Council twice. Luxembourg's politics are characterised by stability and long-serving administrations.

countryDriving: Driving is on the left hand side of the road.  Unlike in mainland China, international driving permits (IDP's) are accepted in Macau. Car rental is not a popular option in Macau given the territory's high population density and small size. There are car rental services in Macau and the option is available of renting the car with or without a driver.Roads are generally well maintained and directional signs are in both Chinese and Portuguese.
countryCurrency:
Pataca (MOP).

It is currently pegged to the Hong Kong dollar.

Major credit cards are widely accepted. ATM's can be found on nearly every street. Holders of a debit card on the international networks will have no issues withdrawing money.

Changing your currency into patacas outside of Macau is just about impossible. Change enough Hong Kong Dollars for the interim, and then change the rest into patacas after arriving. The money changers at the Barrier Gate provide good exchange rates. Do leave Macau with a lot of patacas. Unlike the HKD, they are quite hard to exchange in most countries.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Macau is also spelled Macao and is, along with Hong Kong, one of the two special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China. It lies on the western side of the Pearl River Delta, bordering Guangdong province to the north and facing the South China Sea to the east and south.

Under the policy of "one country, two systems", the PRC's Central People's Government is responsible for the territory's defence and foreign affairs, while Macau maintains its own legal system, police force, monetary system, customs policy, and immigration policy. Macau participates in many international organisations and events that do not require members to possess national sovereignty. Its economy revolves around tourism.

Macau has capitalised on its long history as a gambling centre, drawing many thousands of visitors from China and Hong Kong. Foreign casino companies have invested heavily since Hong Kong tycoon Stanley Ho's decades-long monopoly on the gaming industry ended in 2002. New "mega-casinos", which include major hotel developments, have replaced traditional gambling dens. China is unlikely to grant greater democratic rights unless consistent pressure is applied by pro-democratic campaigners.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right side of the road.  A valid driving licence or an International Driving Permit is accepted. Speed limits are generally sign posted. Most major highways are in good repair, but many secondary urban and rural roads are poorly maintained and lighted. Horse-drawn carts, livestock, dead animals, rocks, or other objects are sometimes found in the roadway. Some vehicles are old and lack standard front or rear lights.
Many drivers routinely ignore speed limits and other traffic regulations, such as stopping for red lights and stop signs. Drivers may make illegal left turns from the far right lane, or drive into oncoming lanes of traffic. The combination of speeding, unsafe driving practices, poor vehicle maintenance, the mixture of new and old vehicles on the roads, and poor lighting contributes to unsafe driving conditions. Drivers and passengers should always wear seatbelts in Macedonia.
countryOverview:
Macedonia, officially the Republic of Macedonia, is a country located in the central Balkan peninsula in Southeast Europe. It is one of the successor states of the former Yugoslavia, from which it declared independence in 1991. It became a member of the United nations in 1993 but, as a result of a dispute with Greece over it's name, it was admitted under the provisional reference of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonua.

Macedonia is a landlocked country bordered by Kosovo, Serbia, Bulgaria, Greece and Albania. The country's capital is Skopje with a total of approximately 520,000 inhabitants.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side.  A national driving licence is sufficient.  Car hire is not widespread and car hire agencies can only be found in the main tourist towns. It is advisable to make enquiries in advance about insurance requirements for car hire.
Since 2002, 3,000km (1,864 miles) of roads have been resurfaced. Tarred roads of varying quality link the main towns in the central highlands and continue to the most populous parts of the east and northwest coasts.
Many roads are impassable in the rainy season (November to March). The route from Antananarivo to Toliara has reduced travel time between these destinations from three to two days. There are isolated sections of tarred road, but dirt tracks are more common.
countryCurrency:
The pre-colonial Ariary (MGA). Malagasy Francs are no longer accepted.

Currency can be bought only at banks and official bureaux de change in hotels and at the airport in Antananarivo. The Ariary is non-convertible and cannot be exchanged back into tradable currency.

Major Credit/Debit cards are accepted at top-end hotels in Tana and the provincial capitals. However, outside of the main cities there is less acceptability. ATM's can be found in and around the capital and in some of the larger towns.

Travellers cheques can be exchanged in banks and major hotels. Travellers cheques in Euros or US Dollars are advisable to avoid additional exchange rate charges.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
The Republic of Madagascar (formally Malagasy Republic) is an island country located in the Indian Ocean off the southeastern coast of Africa.

After sometimes harsh French colonial rule, which included the bloody suppression of an uprising in 1947, Madagascar gained independence in 1960. The military seized power in the early 1970s with the aim of achieving a socialist paradise. This did not materialise. The economy went into decline and by 1982 the authorities were forced to adopt a structural adjustment programme imposed by the International Monetary Fund.

The World Bank has estimated that 70% of Malagasy live on less than $1 per day. Poverty and the competition for agricultural land have put pressure on the island's dwindling forests. The island has strong ties with France as well as economic and cultural links with French-speaking West Africa.

In January 2009 political unrest erupted into violence. President Ravalomanana resigned in March following a fierce power struggle with opposition leader Andry Rajoelina, who then assume power with military backing. Many areas of the country suffer from food shortages but it stands to benefit from a G8 pledge to write of the debts of 18 poor countries.

countryDriving:
Driving is on the left hand side.  An International Driving Permit is required.  Car hire is becoming increasingly available, with a number of companies offering a wide choice of vehicles. Standards do vary (even with the internationally franchised chains) so it is worth seeking a recommendation. Nonetheless, cars should be reserved well in advance as they are very much in demand. Chauffeur-driven cars are also available.  All major roads are tarmac and most secondary roads are all-weather.  Driving in Malawi can be hazardous. Drive carefully, always wear a seatbelt and avoid travel after dark. Potholes, animals, abandoned vehicles and cyclists can often cause serious accidents, as do vehicles travelling at night without lights.
_Malawi has a very high rate of fatalities on the road in proportion to the number of vehicles. The Malawi Police Service has introduced breathalyser tests, and regularly stops vehicles for speeding. Speed cameras are also operated on the main roads. Drivers caught drink driving or speeding can have their licences and/or vehicles confiscated on the spot, for return only after appearance before a magistrate. Convicted drivers face a fine and/or imprisonment. The blood alcohol limit is 0.08g per 100ml of blood, the same as in the UK.
_Fuel (petrol & diesel) shortages occur in Malawi from time to time and when they do,Êthere are often long queues at fuel stations. When driving in Malawi Ð a valid driving license should be carried at all times, as you may be required to produce it at police check points. Drivers are encouraged to slow down in all built-up areas. Traffic police often place speed cameras in some built up areas where there are no signs showing the speed limit. For such traffic offences, the police impose on the spot fines.
countryCurrency:
Kwacha (MWK).

Acceptance of credit and debit cards is very limited, although in Lilongwe and Blantyre and in main hotels, American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa can be used.

Travellers cheques can be exchanged in banks, hotels and other institutions. In remote areas, the Treasury Office of Local District Commissioner's offices will cash traveller's cheques. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars, Euros, Pounds Sterling or South African Rand.

The import of local and foreign currency is unlimited and the export of local currency is limited to MWK3,000. The export of foreign currency must not exceed the amount imported and must be declared on departure.
countryOverview:
The Republic of Malawi is a landlocked country in southeast Africa that was formerly known as Nyasaland. It is bordered by Zambia to the northwest, Tanzania to the northeast, and Mozambique on the east, south and west. The country is separated from Tanzania and Mozambique by Lake Malawi. The country has an estimated population of around 15.4m. Its capital is Lilongwe, the second largest city is Blantyre and the third largest city is Mzuzu.

The name Malawi comes from the Maravi, an old name of the Nyanja people that inhabit the area. The country is also nicknamed, "The Warm Heart of Africa". Malawi was first settled during the 10th century and remained under native rule until 1891 when it was colonized by the British, who ruled the country until 1964. Upon gaining independence it became a single-party state under the presidency of Hastings Banda, who remained president until 1994, when he was ousted from power. Malawi has a democratic, multi-party government. Malawi has a small military force that includes an army, a navy and an air wing. Malawi's foreign policy is pro-Western and includes positive diplomatic relations with most countries and participation in several international organizations.

Malawi is among the world's least developed countries. The economy is heavily based in agriculture, with a largely rural population. The Malawian government depends heavily on outside aid to meet development needs, although this need (and the aid offered) has decreased since 2000. The Malawian government faces challenges in building and expanding the economy, improving education, health care, environmental protection, and becoming financially independent. Malawi has several programs developed since 2005 that focus on these issues, and the country's outlook appears to be improving, with improvements in economic growth, education and healthcare seen in 2007 and 2008.

Malawi has a low life expectancy and high infant mortality. There is a high prevalence of HIV/AIDS, which is a drain on the labour force and government expenditures, and is expected to have a significant impact on gross domestic product (GDP) by 2010. There is a diverse population of native peoples, Asians and Europeans, with several languages spoken and an array of religious beliefs. Although there was tribal conflict in the past, by 2008 it had diminished considerably and the concept of a Malawian nationality had begun to form. Malawi has a culture combining native and colonial aspects, including sports, art, dance and music.

countryReligon: Muslim, Buddhist, Daoist, Hindu, Christian, Sikh, Shamanism
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive is on the left hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit is required. Car hire is available through international and domestic agencies.
The road network is extensive and major roads are well maintained. However, standards deteriorate outside the big cities, and road rules are followed erratically in rural areas, particularly in Malaysian Borneo. For this reason, it is best not to drive at night. Unsurfaced roads in the highlands are often impassable during the rainy season.
Most roads in the peninsular states are paved and signs leading to the various destinations are well placed and clear.
The north-south expressway spans 890km (553 miles) from Bukit Kayu Hitam (on the Kedah-Thailand border) to Johor Bahru is the main highway.
Speed limits are 110kph (68 mph) on expressways, 90kph (55 mph) on main roads and 60kph (38 mph) in urban areas unless otherwise posted. Seat belts must be worn at all times. The use of handheld mobile phones is prohibited when driving. Penalties for drinking and driving are severe.
countryOverview:
Malaysia is a federal constitutional monarchy in Southeast Asia. It consists of thirteen states and three federal territories. Land borders are shared with Thailand, Indonesia, and Brunei, and maritime borders exist with Singapore, Vietnam, and the Philippines. The capital city is Kuala Lumpur, while Putrajaya is the seat of the federal government. In 2010 the population exceeded 27.5 million. The country boasts one of Asia's most vibrant economies and it is one of key tourist destinations in its regions. It's human rights record has come in for severe international scrutiny as internal laws state that suspects can be detained without charge or trial.

The head of government is the Prime Minister. The government system is closely modelled on the British parliamentary system and the legal system is based on English Common Law. The country is multi-ethnic and multi-cultural, factors that influence its culture and play a large role in politics. Although Islam is the official religion, freedom of religion is protected by the constitution.

countryDriving: Denmark's roads are generally in an excellent condition and driving is on the right-hand side of the road.  Travellers require a valid European photo card-style driver's licence or an international driving permit (IDP) to drive in Denmark; insurance is required by law. The minimum age for driving is 18 years old; anyone who contravenes this can face a large fine and/or the impounding of the vehicle.  Use of seat belts is mandatory for drivers and all passengers.
countryCurrency:
Danish Krone (DKK).

ATMs are widespread and nearly all are connected to international networks such as Visa, MasterCard and Cirrus. Currency should be exchanged at banks since they offer the best conversion rates.

Credit cards and common traveller's cheques such as American Express and Thomas Cook are widely accepted.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local of foreign currency. However, amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or equivalent must be declared if travelling from or to a country outside the European Union.
countryOverview:
Denmark officially known as Kingdom of Denmark is a Scandinavian country in Northern Europe. The country of Denmark, together with Greenland and the Faroe Islands, comprises the Kingdom of Denmark. It is the southernmost of the Nordic countries, southwest of Sweden and south of Norway, and bordered to the south by Germany. Denmark borders both the Baltic and the North Sea.

Denmark has been a member of the European Union since 1973, although it has not joined the Eurozone. Denmark, with a mixed market capitalist economy and a large welfare state, ranks as having the world's highest level of income equality. Denmark has been ranked as the least corrupt country in the world.

Social Democrat Helle Thorning-Schmidt, Denmark's first female PM, took office 2011 elections ending a decade of centre-right rule. Denmark, an EU member, has rejected the Euro but pegs the krone to the single currency. Denmark has backed key international peacekeeping efforts and Danish soldiers are currently based in Afghanistan.

countryReligon:
Protestant 45%, Roman Catholic 33%, indigenous beliefs 10%, Islam 10%, 
others 2% (note - estimates vary widely)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. Local driving standards are very poor, with drivers likely to travel at excessive speeds and with unpredictable habits. Unpaved roads, potholes and poor vehicle maintenance also pose a threat to visiting drivers. Congestion in major cities are also common. During the rainy season, roads can become impassable, causing delays to drivers and in recent years there has been an increase in driving-related fatalities, especially with Kenyan long-distance bus services.
countryCurrency:
Kenyan Shilling (KES).

ATM's can be found in almost every bank throughout Kenya, and they are increasingly being installed in petrol stations, throughout the country. Major Credit/Debit cards are widely accepted, however Diners Club and American Express are less accepted.

Travellers cheques can be changed in banks situated throughout Kenya. It is advised that visitors take travellers cheques in Pounds Sterling or US Dollars, to avoid any additional exchange charges.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of both local or foreign currency. On the other hand, any amount greater than or equivalent to US$5,000 must be declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Kenya, officially the Republic of Kenya, is a country in East Africa. Lying along the Indian Ocean to its south-east and at the equator, it is bordered by Somalia to the north-east, Ethiopia to the north, South Sudan to the north-west, Uganda to the west and Tanzania to the south. Lake Victoria is situated to the south-west, and is shared with Uganda and Tanzania.

With its capital city in Nairobi, Kenya has numerous wildlife reserves containing thousands of animal species. It has a population of nearly 39 million residents, representing many different peoples and cultures. The country is named after Mount Kenya, a significant landmark and second among Africa's highest mountain peaks.

Following a referendum and adoption of a new constitution in August 2010, Kenya is now divided in 47 countries that are semi-autonomous units of governance.

The country is made up of a number of ethnic groups, some of which include Kikuyu (22%), Luhya (14%) and Luo (13%) being the largest three.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive is on the left hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit is required.  Car hire is available on urban Tarawa and Christmas Island only.  All-weather roads are limited to urban Tarawa and Christmas Island.  The road conditions in the country are poor.  However, the driving standards are reasonable.
countryCurrency:
Australian Dollar (AUD).

Credit cards have very limited acceptance. There are ATM's at branches of the Bank of Kiribati/ANZ in Betio, Bairiki and Bikenibeu (all on Tarawa atoll).

Travellers cheques are accepted in hotels, some shops and at the Bank of Kiribati Ltd. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take travellers cheques in Australian Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Kiribati is officially the Republic of Kiribati and is an island nation located in the central tropical Pacific Ocean. The permanent population exceeds just over 100,000 (2011), and it's composed of 32 atolls and one raised coral island, straddling the equator. The capital of South Tarawa consists of a number of islets connected through a series of causeways, located in the Tarawa archipelago.

Kiribati became independent from the United Kingdom in 1979. It is a member of the Commonwealth of Nations, the IMF and the World Bank, and became a full member of the United Nations in 1999.

Kiribati's economy is weak and is affected by rises and falls in the world demand for coconut. Fishing licences, foreign aid and money sent home by workers abroad also play their part, as does a trust fund set up with revenues from phosphate mining on the island of Banaba. It is also one of the low-lying Pacific island states seen as highly vulnerable to rising sea levels and global warming, and frequently lends its voice to calls for action on climate change.

countryReligon: Buddhism, Christianity and half of the adults profess no religion
countryDriving: Driving is on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driving Permit is required. Drivers must have more than one year's driving experience, be in possession of a valid passport and be over 21 years of age.Excellent motorways link all major cities, but minor roads may be poorly maintained. Road signs are usually written in Korean and English.  Some driving can be erratic and traffic congestion in large cities make driving a challenge.  There is a complex road system and traffic can be dense.  Drivers can be hired.  There are many car hire companies operating, including the major international ones.  Seat belts are mandatory. Speed limits are 100-110kph (62-68mph) on motorways; 60-80kph (37-50mph) for A-roads.
countryCurrency:
Won (KRW).

Credit cards such as American Express, Diners Club, MasterCard and Visa are widely accepted at major hotels, shops and restaurants in the larger cities. Credit cards may be difficult to use at small businesses and in rural areas. ATM's are available in all major cities, but not all of them will accept international cards. Cards with the Plus and Cirrus logos are the easiest to use and most widely accepted in Korea. Many of the ATM's in Seoul subways accept foreign cards as well.

Travellers cheques are accepted, but may be difficult to change in smaller towns. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding US$10,000 or its equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
South Korea is officially the Republic of Korea (ROK) and is a portion of the Korean Peninsula. It is neighbored by the People's Republic of China (Mainland China) to the west, Japan to the east, North Korea to the north, and the East China Sea and Republic of China (Taiwan) to the south. The Republic of Korea lies in a humid continental and humid subtropical climate region with a predominantly mountainous terrain. Its territory covers a total area of 99,392 square kilometers and has a population of almost 50 million. The capital and largest city is Seoul, with a population of 11 million. 

After the invasion of South Korea by forces from the North on 25 June 1950, the resulting war between the two Koreas ended with an Armistice Agreement, but the border between the two nations is the most heavily fortified in the world. After the war, the South Korean economy grew significantly and the country had transformed into a major economy, a full democracy and a regional power in East Asia.

South Korea is a presidential republic consisting of sixteen administrative divisions and is a developed country with a very high standard of living. It is Asia's fourth largest economy and the world's 15th (nominal) or 12th (purchasing power parity) largest economy. The economy is export-driven, with production focusing on electronics, automobiles, ships, machinery, petrochemicals and robotics. South Korea is a member of the United Nations, WTO, OECD and G-20 major economies. It is also a founding member of APEC and the East Asia Summit.

countryReligon: Muslim, Serbian Orthodox, Roman Catholic - Distribution unknown
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. European standard photocard driving licences are accepted, but drivers must also carry vehicle registration and proof of ownership documents. If entering Kosovo by road, the purchase of local third-party insurance is compulsory. Both major international and local firms offer car hire at airports and larger towns. Note that many Serbian car hire firms will not allow their vehicles to be driven in Kosovo due to security concerns.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

Visa and MasterCard creidt cards are sometimes accepted, but this can not be replied upon and it is known that Kosovo is largely a cash-based economy. 

There are no restrctions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. However, amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
Kosovo is a disputed territory following the collapse of Yugoslavia.

Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on February 17 2008. However, Serbia refuses to renounce its claim on the territory. Serb-populated northern areas are largely beyond the writ of the ethnic Albanian government. The EU is brokering talks between Kosoov and Serbia. NATO peacekeepers have been in Kosovo since 1999.

Atifete Jahjaga, was elected Kosovo's first female president by parliament in April 2011, after her predecessor, the Swiss-Kosovan tycoon Behgjet Pacolli, stepped down after only two months into his term after the constitutional court ruled his election unlawful.

countryReligon: Islam 85% (Sunni 70%, Shiite 30%), Christian, Hindu, Parsi, and Other 15%
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. And International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Kuwait.  Driving on Kuwaiti roads can be hazardous. The country may have an extensive and modern system of well-lit, well-marked roads, but excessive speeding, erratic local drivers and drivers ignoring traffic lights all pose a threat to travellers. Other attributes that can pose a threat to drivers include, camels and other livestock on major roads and highways.
Landmines and unexploded ordnance from the 1991 Gulf War pose a risk in desert areas, including Failaka Island. High winds and sand movement can expose landmines in areas previously believed to be safe.
countryCurrency:
Kuwaiti Dinar (KWD).

ATM's can be found throughout the country and accepted credit cards include, Diners Club, MasterCard and American Express.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted and it is advised that travellers cheques in Pounds Sterling and US Dollars are taken.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. However, amounts exceeding KWD3,000 or equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
The State of Kuwait is a sovereign Arab nation situated in the north-east of the Arabian Peninsula in Western Asia. It is bordered by Saudi Arabia to the south at Khafji, and Iraq to the north at Basra. It lies on the north-western shore of the Persian Gulf.

It is a small, oil-rich country situated at the top of the Gulf. Its oil fields were first exploited during the 1930's and since the development of the petroleum industry after World War ll and independence in 1961, oil has dominate the Kuwaiti economy, making up an estimated 90% of export revenues. Despite these large oil revenues, the economy has been badly affected by the global financial crisis. Analysts say economic policy-making has been held back by political squabbling.

countryLanguage: Official language is Kyrgyz. Russian, English.
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. Roads throughout the country are known to be poorly lit and poorly maintained, which can pose a threat, particularly at night. Local drivers have disregard for driving laws, with many known to ignore red lights and signals. There have also been many drink driving-related accidents, throughout the country, especially in rural cities. Throughout the winter roads, unplowed snow and ice pose a large threat to drivers. Roads in mountainous regions are often narrow and winding and petrol stations may not be easily located in urban areas. It is advised that the road between Bishkek and Almaty, Kazakhstan be avoided at night, due to poor weather and unsafe roads. There have been reports of police officers harassing visiting drivers, often demanding payments.
countryCurrency:
Kyrgyz Soms. (KGS)

ATM's can be found with relative ease in Bishkek, however they are limited in small, rural areas. ATM's may also distribute US Dollars, as well as Soms. Credit cards can be used in major hotels and restaurants in the capital city, however they have limited value outside the major cities.

Travellers cheques are accepted in some banks in the capital and it is advised that travellers take cheques in US Dollars. It is advised to take money, rather than travellers cheques.
countryOverview:
Kyrgyzstan, officially the Kyrgyz Republic is one of the world's six independent Turkic states (along with Turkey, Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan).

Located in Central Asia, landlocked and mountainous, Kyrgyzstan is bordered by Kazakhstan to the north, Uzbekistan to the west, and Tajikistan to the southwest and People's Republic of China to the east. Its capital and largest city is Bishkek. The area of the country is 199,900 square kilometres and the population is estimated at around 5.5 million.

The country is one of the active members of the Turkic Council, the Commonwealth of Independent States and the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation.

Kirgizia, as it was formerly known, became part of the Soviet Union in 1922 and remained an autonomous republic within the USSR until independence in 1991 when it seceded along with many other former Soviet republics. The first president of the newly formed Kyrgyz Republic, Askar Akayev, managed to remain in power for 16 years before being ousted in a landslide victory in 2005 following widespread demonstrations against high levels of poverty and alleged political corruption. The victor of this so-called â€˜Tulip Revolutionâ€™ was Kurmanbek Bakiyev, who served as president until 2010 when widespread violent protests forced him to leave the country. These same protests also triggered ethnic violence between Kyrgyz and Uzbeks in the south of the country resulting in hundreds of deaths and thousands fleeing as refugees.

countryDriving: Roads in Djibouti are often narrow, poorly lit and badly maintained. Roaming livestock are an additional hazard. The standard of driving and vehicle maintenance is generally poor. Police set up wire coils as roadblocks on some of the major roads, and these may be difficult to see at night. We recommend that you do not travel at night and that overland travel be undertaken in a convoy. In addition, landmines are known to be present in northern Tadjourah and Obock districts, and in the Ali Sabieh area of the south. Travellers should stay on paved roads and should check with local authorities before using unpaved roads.  An international driving permit is recommended, though not legally required. A temporary licence to drive is available from local authorities on presentation of a valid driving licence. Insurance is not required.
countryCurrency:
Djiboutian Franc.

Djibouti's economy is cash-based and only airlines and major hotels accept credit cards. You should assume ATM's will not be available.

Travellers cheques can be exchanged at major banks and it is advised that these are either Euro or US dollar based. Euro and Stirling cheques are not accepted.
countryOverview:
Djibouti is a country in the Horn of Africa. It is bordered by Eritrea in the north, Ethiopia in the west and south, and Somalia in the southeast. The remainder of the border is formed by the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden at the east.

Djibouti was a French colony until 1977. It is cuurently a multi-party democracy with a legal system based on French civil law though modified by traditional practices and Islamic (Sharia) law. Although exact numbers are unavailable, unemployment is estimated in excess of 50% of the working-age population. Over two-thirds of the countryâ€™s estimated 516,055 residents live in the capital, also called Djibouti. Modern tourist facilities and communications links are found in the city of Djibouti but are limited outside the capital. 

The country houses a large refugee population from neighbouring states, especially Somalia. Poverty, unemployment and the growing refugee population have resulted in many people turning to criminal activities to sustain a living, and crimes, mostly petty in nature, are becoming more prevalent, particularly in the capital, Djibouti. During the Gulf War it was the base of operations for the French military, who continue to maintain a significant presence.

countryReligon: Muslim 98% (Shia 89%, Sunni 9%), Other (includes Zoroastrian, Jewish, Christian, and Baha'i) 2%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Iran. Iran has a very high rate of traffic related deaths and accidents. Local driving standards pose the largest threat to drivers due to their ignorance of traffic lights and signals, and the excessive speeds at which they drive. Roads in major cities and rural towns tend to be poorly lit, posing a large threat to drivers after dark. Iranian authorities sometimes mount roadblocks in cities, creating delays for drivers. Women should be particularly cautious when driving alone at night.
countryCurrency:
Iranian Rial (IRR).

Holders of local bank account's can only use ATM's. MasterCard is accepted in a small number of regions and establishments, but credit cards should not be relied upon as Iran is cash-based country.

The import and export of local currency is limited to 500,000 rials. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, provided it is declared on arrival. The export of foreign currency is limited to the amount declared on arrival.

It is not possible to exchange traveller's cheques in Iran.
countryOverview:
Iran, officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country in Southern and Western Asia. The name "Iran" has been in use natively since the Sassanian era and came into use internationally in 1935, before which the country was known to the Western world as Persia. Both "Persia" and "Iran" are used interchangeably in cultural contexts; however, "Iran" is the name used officially in political contexts.

It became a unique Islamic republic in 1979, when the monarchy was overthrown and religious clerics assumed political control under supreme leader, Ayatollah Khomeini. The Iranian revolution put an end to the rule of the Shah, who had alienated powerful religious, political and popular forces. 

In 2002, US President George W Bush declared Iran as an "axis of evil". However, his successor, Barack Obama, has softened his tone but Washington still accuses Iran of trying to develop nuclear weapons. 

Conservatives have kept reformers at bay and retain power in the complex system of religious and democratic government. Iran currently holds 9% of world oil reserves, however a critical shortfall in jobs has hit the younger generation. The UN voted to impose further sanctions over the issue, regarding Irans nuclear programme, in June 2010.

The Presidential elections which were held on the 14th June 2013, resulted in a victory for Hassan Rouhani who was elected in the first round of voting with 50.71% of the votes.

countryReligon: Islam 97% (Shiite 60% to 65%, Sunni 32% to 37%), Christian or other 3%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Iraq. Car hire is available but not recommended due to the threat of car jacking and armed robbery. Roads are usually in bad condition and driving standards are poor. Travel remains dangerous due to the continued threats posed by ambushes, unexploded ordnance, roadside bombings and robbery. Frequent checkpoints, roadblocks and other safety measures can also make road movement unpredictable. Diesel is difficult to obtain and fuel supplies can be sporadic and may not be widely available.
countryCurrency:
Iraqi dinar (IQD).

One of the main Iraqi banks, Warka Bank, has 350 ATMs in 120 branches across Iraq in most cities and towns. The location of their ATMs are listed on their website: www.warka-bank.com.

Travellers cheques are not generally accepted in Iraq, though it is sometimes possible to do a deal with some merchants in city bazaars, however the rate will not be a good one. There are also Western Union branches available in main towns.

The import and export of local or foreign currency is limited to $10,000 or equivalent.
countryOverview:
Iraq, officially the Republic of Iraq is a country in Western Asia spanning most of the northwestern end of the Zagros mountain range, the eastern part of the Syrian Desert and the northern part of the Arabian Desert. It has a population of around 34.7 million and it is bordered by Jordan to the west, Syria to the northwest, Turkey to the north, Iran to the east, and Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to the south. Iraq has a narrow section of coastline measuring 58 km (35 miles) on the northern Persian Gulf.

Iraq was controlled by the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party from 1968 until 2003. After an invasion led by American and British forces, the Ba'ath Party was removed from power and Iraq came under a military occupation by a multinational coalition. Sovereignty was transferred to the Iraqi Interim Government in June 2004. A new constitution was then approved by referendum and a new Government of Iraq was elected. Foreign troops remained in Iraq after the establishment of a new government due to an insurgency that developed shortly after the invasion, with violence peaking in mid 2007.

Considerable tension remain between various political and sectarian factions in Iraq.

countryReligon: Roman Catholic 88%, Church of Ireland 3%, other Christian 2%, none 4%
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. In 2009 there were 239 road deaths. Road conditions in rural areas and major roads are good but roads may be winding and narrow in urban areas and congestion can affect major cities and towns. During the summer and holiday weekends the roads are more dangerous due to an increased level of traffic. The local police also set up roads blocks spontaneously to check for drunk drivers. There are no border controls between Ireland and Northern Ireland, allowing relative ease when travelling between the two areas.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

ATM's are available throughout the entire country. Credit and debit cards that are available include MasterCard, American Express, Visa, Cirrus and Maestro.

Travellers cheques are also accepted throughout Ireland.

There are no restrictions on the export or import of foreign or local currency. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 must be declared if travelling to or from a country outside the European Union.
countryOverview:
Ireland is the third-largest island in Europe and the twentieth-largest island in the world. It lies to the north-west of continental Europe and is surrounded by hundreds of islands and islets. To the east of Ireland is Great Britain, separated from it by the Irish Sea.

The island is divided between the Republic of Ireland, which covers around five-sixths of the island, and Northern Ireland, a part of the United Kingdom, which covers the remainder and is located in the north-east of the island. The population of Ireland is approximately 6.2 million people. Just fewer than 4.5 million live in the Republic of Ireland and just fewer than 1.8 million live in Northern Ireland.

Prime Minister, Enda Kenny, from Fine Gael leads a coalition that outsted Fianna Fail, which was the main force in parliament in 2011. In 2010, the country requested a rescue package from the IMF and EU after deficit and debt problems left the economy close to collapse. In the 1990's the economy began to grow, fuelled primarily by foreign investment, subsequently attracting waves of incomers. In 2009 its economy experienced one of the deepest recessions throughout the eurozone, shrinking by 10% and in November 2010, the EU agreed a financial rescue worth around â‚¬85bn.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in Israel and drivers have to be over the age of 21 years of age. Local driving standards are very poor, with drivers likely to drive at excessive speeds and with a reluctance to obey driving regulations and traffic lights. Drivers are prone to stop suddenly on roads without warning, especially on motorways. Israel has a very high rate of driving-related fatalities, with 315 road deaths reported in 2009.
countryCurrency:
New Shekel (ILS).

ATM's are widely available throughout Israel and all major credit cards are accepted.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted, and it is advised that traveller's cheques be taken in US Dollars, so as to avoid any additional exchange charges.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. However, amounts exceeding ILS90,000 or equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
The State of Israel is a parliamentary republic in Western Asia, located on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean Sea. It borders Lebanon in the north, Syria in the north-east, Jordan and the West Bank in the east, Egypt and the Gaza Strip on the south-west, and contains geographically diverse features within its relatively small area.

Israel is the world's only Jewish-majority state, and is defined as a Jewish and democratic state in its Basic Laws.

It has been locked in conflict with the Palestinians and its Arab neighbours over ownership of land considered holy by Jews, Christians and Muslims since its creation in 1948.

Palestinian resistance to Israeli control has been a key feature since Israel's establishment in 1948. Israel has a sophisticated and diverse economy and faces hostility from much of the Arab world.

countryAirport: Leonardo da Vinci-Fiumicino Airport & Rome Ciampino Airport
countryReligon: Roman Catholic approx. 90%, Protestant, Jewish, Islamic
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit is required and a special permit is necessary to have access to Rome city centre. Driving can be dangerous due to aggressive drivers and excessive speeding. Travellers to northern Italy should be aware of ground fog and poor visibility. The country has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle accidents and deaths in Europe. City streets may be narrow, congested and winding.
countryCurrency:
Euro (â‚¬).

ATM's can be found throughout the whole country. Major Credit/Debit cards are widely accepted as are travellers cheques.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted. To avoid exchange rate charges, it is advised that travellers cheques should be taken in Euros, US Dollars and Pound Sterling. 

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 must be declared if travelling to or from a country outside the European Union.
countryOverview:
Italy, officially the Italian Republic, is a unitary parliamentary republic in south-central Europe. To the north it borders France, Switzerland, Austria and Slovenia along the Alps. To the south it consists of the entirety of the Italian Peninsula, Sicily, Sardinia the two largest islands in the Mediterranean Sea and many other smaller islands.

The independent states of San Marino and the Vatican City are enclaves within Italy, whilst Campione d'Italia is an Italian exclave in Switzerland. With 60.6 million inhabitants, it is the fifth most populous country in Europe, and the 23rd most populous in the world.

Economist Mario Monti is the head of a government of unelected technocrats, appointed amid a mounting economic crisis. Even though Italy has the eurozone's thrid largest economy, it also has a huge public debt of 118% of GDP. There is large concern over the Italy's birth rate as it has one of the lowest in Europe and the problems linked with an ageing population.

countryReligon:
Protestant 61.3%, (Church of God 21.2%, Baptist 8.8%, Anglican 5.5%, 
Seventh-Day Adventist 9%, Pentecostal 7.6%, Methodist 2.7%, United Church 
2.7%, Brethren 1.1%, Jehovah's Witness 1.6%, Moravian 1.1%), Roman Catholic 
4%, other including some spiritual cults 34.7%
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road.  A valid home drivers licence or an international drivers licence is acceptable. Drivers must be aged 25 or over.
Jamaica's road network covers the whole island and consists of some 21,000km of roads. Extra care should be taken, especially after dark, as many of the islands roads are in a poor state of repair. There is a poor road safety record and pedestrians, animals and erratic drivers can all prove hazardous and petrol stations accept cash only.
Car hire firms can be found in major towns, hotels and airports and most offer unlimited mileage. A general consumption tax of 15% is applied to all car hire transactions, and it's recommended to seek a rental with inclusive insurance and breakdown cover. The Jamaican tourist board offer one of the most comprehensive road maps of the island.
Speed limits are 50kph (31mph) in built-up areas and 80kph (50mph) outside the main towns. Seat belts must be worn at all times. If seatbelts are available in the back then these should be worn for safety purposes.
countryCurrency:
Jamaican Dollar (JMD).

Jamaican law requires that local currency be used when paying for all goods and services, though that law is followed very loosely and the US Dollar is accepted almost universally. To avoid confusion determine which dollar unit is being quoted in the price prior to any transaction being made.

Major Credit/Debit cards are all widely accepted as are other cards bearing the Cirrus or Plus logo. Most Jamaican ATM's accept international bank cards and many banks give credit card cash advances. However, the island's ATMs are known to be unreliable. 

Travellers cheques in US Dollars are widely accepted throughout Jamaica.

There are no restricitons on the import and export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding US$10,000 or equivalent must be declared.
countryOverview:
Jamaica is an island nation of the Greater Antilles, It is situated in the Caribbean Sea, about 145 kilometres (90 mi) south of Cuba, and 191 kilometres (119 mi) west of Hispaniola. The island is known for its beauty, political stability and plentiful resources in the form of bauxite and sugar. However, these features contrast with widespread poverty and crime.

Since independence from Britain in 1962, power in Jamaica has alternated between the social-democratic People's National Party and the conservative Jamaica Labour Party. While elections have often been marred by violence, their results have always been accepted and, on the whole, political institutions have managed to retain their legitimacy. But political stability has not turned into social and economic harmony.

Contrasting with the luxury tourist resorts, there are also densely-populated and impoverished ghettos. The government has at times deployed army units to suppress violent unrest. There were more than 1,300 reported murders in 2006 and there have been accusations of extrajudicial killings by law enforcers. The police have secured outside help to deal with what is one of the world's highest murder rates alongside South Africa and Colombia.

countryAirport: Haneda International Airport & Narita International Airport
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive is on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit is required. The minimum driving age is 18. Many international car hire firms are present.
Understanding the road signs can be a problem as not all are translated into English.
Traffic in cities is often congested.
The Keiyo Highway, Meishin Expressway, Tohoku Expressway and the Tomei Expressway link Japan's major Pacific coastal cities, but there are high tolls for using them.
Seat belts are compulsory and speed limits on highways is 80kmp (50mph) although many drivers exceed this. In cities the speed limit is 40kph (25mph). The Japan Automobile Federation (JAF) provides an English-language 'Rules of the Road' booklet and offers 24-hour breakdown assistance for both members and non-members. In the case of an accident, the police must be informed (tel: 110).

Vehicles drive on the right hand side.  National driving licences are accepted if they have been issued at least one year before travel. However, an International Driving Permit is recommended. Visitors are not allowed to drive a vehicle with normal Jordanian plates unless they have a Jordanian driving licence.  The minimum driving age is 18 years.  Major international car hire companies and a number of local companies operate services in the main towns, including Amman and Aqaba; car hire is also available from hotels and travel agents. Drivers are available for the day.
There are three main arteries: the Desert Highway from Irbid to Aqaba (dual carriageway); the Dead Sea Highway (mostly single carriageway) from the Dead Sea to Aqaba, and the Kings' Highway, from Amman to Wadi Mousa.
These roads are reasonable but the traffic is often fast and erratic.
A 4-wheel drive vehicle is needed to drive off-road in the Eastern Desert and in the desert surrounding Wadi Rum.
All motorists should carry water in the summer and warm clothes in the winter.
Speed limits are 60kph (38mph) in cities, 80kph (50mph) on country roads and 120kph (75mph) on motorways. There are frequent passport controls along and around the Dead Sea Highway. The wearing of seat belts for all car passengers is mandatory.
countryCurrency:
Dinar (JOD).

Major Credit/Debit cards such are accepted in hotels, restaurants and larger shops. Accepted cards include American Express, Diners Club and MasterCard and Visa. ATM's can be found in most of the larger towns and throughout Amman.

Most foreign issued travellers cheques are accepted by licensed banks and bureaux de change. To avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars.

The equivalent of up to JOD15,000 may be imported as cash in foreign or local currency. A declaration is necessary for larger amounts.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. International Driving Permits are required. Roads are poorly maintained and damaged roads are not clearly signposted and can be hazardous in winter months. Outside the main cities access to petrol can also be limited. Other attributes that can cause problems when driving include, pedestrians, erratic, careless drivers and animals. Pedestrian crosses are not used efficiently and can therefore create problems to travelling drivers. Driving at night can be hazardous because of insufficient lighting and the Cyrillic alphabet is used on road signs, which can be problematic for travellers.
countryOverview:
Kazakhstan, officially the Republic of Kazakhstan, is a transcontinental country in Central Asia and Eastern Europe. Ranked as the ninth largest country in the world, it is also the world's largest landlocked country. Kazakhstan is one of the six independent Turkic states and is one of the active members of the Turkic Council and the TRKSOY community, which is currently being directed by the former Minister of Culture of Kazakhstan. The country is the size of Western Europe and has vast mineral resources and enormous economic potential. 

It is neighboured clockwise from the north by Russia, China, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and also borders on a significant part of the Caspian Sea. Although Kazakhstan does not share a border with Mongolia, its most easterly point is only 38 kilometers from Mongolia's western tip. The capital was moved in 1997 from Almaty, Kazakhstan's largest city, to Astana.
 
The people of Kazakhstan have to live with the aftermath of the Soviet-era nuclear testing and toxic waste dumping, as well as with growing drug addiction and a growing incidence of HIV/Aids. 

The president of Kazakhstan is Nursultan Nazarbayev and he has been in power since the fall of the Soviet Union. Kazakhstan gained independence from the Soviet Union on 25 December 1991.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is recommended. A valid foreign licence can be used to get a Temporary Visitor's Permit.  There is a 32kmph (20mph) speed limit in towns and villages. Visiting drivers must be between 25 and 65 years old and have had at least two years' driving experience in order to apply for a local driver's permit.  Motorists drive on the left in Dominica.
countryCurrency:
East Caribbean Dollar (XCD).

All major Credit/Debit cards, including American Express, Visa and MasterCard, are widely accepted and ATM's are located around the island.

Travellers cheques are accepted by most hotels and to avoid additional charges, travellers are advised to take travellers cheques in US Dollars. 

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding XCDâ‚¬10,000 must be declared upon arrival.
countryOverview:
Dominica, officially the Commonwealth of Dominica, is an island nation in the Caribbean Sea. To the north-northwest lies Guadeloupe, to the southeast Martinique.

Dominica has an estimated population of 72,500. The capital is Roseau. Dominica has been nicknamed the "Nature Isle of the Caribbean" for its unspoiled natural beauty. Dominica's economy is heavily dependent on both tourism and agriculture.

The island is a low-risk destination for travellers, and most visits are relatively trouble-free. The political situation is stable and there is no threat of conflict. Security in resort areas is very high and the government places a high priority on safe guarding foreign travellers.

countryReligon:
Lutheran Church of Iceland 85.5%, Reykjavik Free Church 2.1%, Roman Catholic 
Church 2%, Hafnarfjorour Free Church 1.5%, other Christian 2.7%, other or 
unspecified 3.8%, unaffiliated 2.4% (2004)
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is recommended (although it is not a legal requirement), if the driver does not have a EU driver's license.  In 2009 there were 17 road deaths in Iceland. Distances between towns can be great, roads narrow and winding, and speed limits are low. Driving conditions may be hazardous and roads impassable, especially in winter. Winter tyres are mandatory from 01 November to 14 April. Dipped headlights must be used at all times and talking on mobile phones is punishable by fines.
On 8 July 2011 there was a glacial flood from the Myrdalsjokull glacier, which resulted in a stretch of the Highway being washed away. 
Less than one-third of the country's total road network is paved, other roads outside the capital, such as those that run through the middle of the country, tend to be dirt or gravel. Most bridges are only one lane wide, requiring drivers to be cognisant of oncoming traffic. Driving through rural areas during the winter (October-April), when daylight hours are limited and weather conditions change rapidly, should be done with immense caution.
countryCurrency:
Icelandic Krona (ISK).

ATM's are available throughout the country. Diners Club cards, MasterCard, Visa and American Express are accepted.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted, it is advised to take travellers' cheques in US Dollars.

There are also no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Iceland also referred to as Republic of Iceland is a European island country in the North Atlantic Ocean on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. It has a population of around 320,000. The largest city is Reykjavik, with the surrounding areas in the southwestern region of the country being home to two-thirds of the national population.

Iceland is volcanically and geologically active. The interior mainly consists of a plateau characterized by sand fields, mountains and glaciers, while many glacial rivers flow to the sea through the lowlands. Iceland is warmed by the Gulf Stream and has a temperate climate despite high latitude just outside the Arctic Circle.

Social Democrat Johanna Sigurdardottir currently leads a centre-left coalition. The country is currently emerging from a recession caused by the 2008 collapse of its economy and banking system. It is believed that Iceland's well educated workforce and its extensive and largely unused natural resources are likely to be the key the reasons for its recovery. Iceland is not a member of the EU, however membership talks are currently being carried out and the country is hoping that the process will be completed by the end of 2012.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is required to drive in India. Road travel is very dangerous throughout India. Travel at night is particularly dangerous and therefore it is advised to avoid travel after dark. Roads outside major cities tend to be in poor condition and congestion is common. It is common for local drivers to ignore regulations and traffic lights, posing an extra threat to visitors. Rural areas are likely to have unpaved and poorly maintained roads. On motorways, vehicles are known to travel in the wrong direction. Many tourists are reported to be killed on Indian roads yearly.
countryCurrency:
Indian Rupee.

MasterCard, Visa, American Express and Diners Club credit cards are all accepted in major cities, however in smaller towns and villages, visitors are likely to find that only MasterCard and Visa are accepted.

In all major cities throughout India 24 hour ATMs can be found.

Travellers cheques are widely accepted and can be exchanged in banks and many of the larger hotels. It has been reported that some banks may refuse to change certain brands of travellers cheques, however others may be willing to do so. 

The import and export of local currency is prohibited, however the import of foreign currency is unlimited. Amounts exceeding US$5,000 or equivalent in cash or US$10,000 or equivalent in all forms of currency mut be declared. The export of foreign currency is allowed up to the amount imported, however it must be declared.
countryOverview:
India, officially the Republic of India, is a country in South Asia. It is the seventh-largest country by geographical area, the second-most populous country with over 1.2 billion people, and the most populous democracy in the world.

Bounded by the Indian Ocean on the south, the Arabian Sea on the south-west, and the Bay of Bengal on the south-east, it shares land borders with Pakistan to the west; Bhutan, the People's Republic of China and Nepal to the north-east; and Bangladesh and Burma to the east. In the Indian Ocean, India is in the vicinity of Sri Lanka and the Maldives; in addition, India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands share a maritime border with Thailand and Indonesia.

The Indian economy is the world's eleventh-largest by nominal GDP. Market-based economic reforms in 1991 led to India becoming one of the fastest-growing major economies. However, it continues to face the challenges of corruption and poverty. India is a nuclear weapons state and it has the third-largest standing army in the world and is ranked ninth in military expenditure amongst nations.

countryReligon: Islam 88%, Protestant 5%, Roman Catholic 3%, Hindu 2%, Buddhist 1% (1998)
countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving License (IDP) is required to rent a car in Indonesia and UK driving licenses cannot be used. It is advised that a driver accompany visitors where possible. Drivers and cars can be rented in many cities. Local driving standards are very poor, with drivers likely to avoid standard regulations and traffic lights, posing a significant threat. Congestion is very common throughout the country. Rural roads tend to be unlit and pedestrians are known to congregate on the road at night. If an accident occurs, Indonesians tend to blame foreigners. There have been reports of visitors being stopped on motorways and being robbed, by Indonesian nationals. It is advised to take extreme caution when driving through the Central Sulawesi region due to unsettled political situations, which can lead to roadblocks and travel delays. The same can be linked with the Maluku region and Aceh, as Aceh is emerging from a long period of internal unrest.
countryCurrency:
Rupiah (RP).

The most widely accepted credit cards accepted throughout Indonesia include MasterCard, Visa, Diners Club, American Express and Eurocard. 

ATMs are available in the major cities and larger towns, however they may not be located in the smaller, rurall towns and villages. 

Traveller's cheques have limited acceptance, and they are becoming less common and more difficult to exchange.

The import and export of local currency is limiteted at Rp5,000,000, however amounts exceeding this must be declared. The import and export of foreign currency is unlimited, however amounts exceeding RP100,000,000 must be declared.
countryOverview:
Indonesia, officially the Republic of Indonesia, is a country in Southeast Asia and Oceania. Indonesia comprises of approximately 17,500 islands and 33 provinces. With over 238 million people, it is the world's fourth most populous country, and has the world's largest population of Muslims.

Indonesia is a republic, with an elected legislature and president. The nation's capital city is Jakarta. The country shares land borders with Papua New Guinea, East Timor, and Malaysia. Other neighbouring countries include Singapore, Philippines, Australia, and the Indian territory of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. Across its many islands, the country consists of many distinct religious and ethnic groups with the Javanese beig the largest ethnic group, with around 41% of the population.

Indonesia is a founding member of ASEAN and a member of the G-20 major economies. The Indonesian economy is the world's eighteenth largest economy by nominal GDP and fifteenth largest by purchasing power parity. It also has vast areas of wilderness that support the world's second largest level of biodiversity.

countryCurrency:
Dominican Peso and US Dollars 

Credit cards are widely accepted and ATM's are widely available and accept international bank cards.

Travellers cheques are accepted by some banks. Banking hours: Mon-Fri 0800-1500, Sat 0900-1300. In shopping centres: Mon-Fri 0900-1900, Sat 0900-1300.
countryOverview:
The Dominican Republic covers the eastern two-thirds of the Caribbean island of Hispaniola and is the second largest Caribbean nation (after Cuba), with an estimated 10 million people. The capital city is Santo Domingo,
   located on the south coast of the island. Spanish is the official
      language. Though English is widely spoken in 
major cities and tourist areas, it is much less common outside these 
areas.

countryDriving: Traffic drives on the right in Ecuador and an International Driving permit is required.  The Pan-American Highway bisects the country.  It begins at the Colombian border in the Carchi province and runs south on to Quito, Riobamba, Cuenca, Loja and ending at Macará near the border with Peru.Part of the highway is toll-administered and while road conditions are generally good in urban centres, such as Quito and Guayaquil, roads in outlying and/or rural areas are often potholed, poorly-lit and lack adequate signage. Carjacking and armed banditry are also concerns on both inter- and intra-city highways, particularly at night when most incidents are reported.You should carry your driver’s license, vehicle registration and proof of insurance at all times.
countryCurrency:
US Dollar

Major credit/debit cards are widely accepted. ATM's are available at most banks in urban areas.

Travellers cheques are generally accepted in the larger cities and can be exchanged into currency at most banks and casas de cambio.

countryDriving: Travellers wishing to drive in Egypt require an international driving permit (IDP).  Traffic drives on the right in Egypt.  Driving practices and poor road conditions contribute to a high rate of road accidents, particularly outside the major cities, as cars, buses and trucks frequently drive at high speed.  International car rental agencies operate in Egypt; however, travellers under 25 years of age are not allowable to hire cars.
countryCurrency:
Egyptian Pound (EGP). British pounds sterling, Euros and the US Dollar are accepted everywhere although change may be given in Egyptian pounds.

All major Credit/Debit cards are widely accepted in large hotels, restaurants and shops. ATM machines are widely available. Travellersâ€™ cheques are not easily cashed. Most banks, including international banks, will not accept them
countryOverview:
Egypt lies at the crossroads between North Africa and the Arabian Peninsula and is bordered by the Mediterranean Sea to the north, the Gaza Strip and Israel to the northeast, the Gulf of Aqaba to the east, the Red Sea to the east and south, Sudan to the south and Libya to the west. The country has an estimated population of around 86 million and is thought to be one of the most populous countries in Africa and the Middle East. 

A constitution remains in control of the country following a referendum in January 2014. This was held following the ousting of President Mohammed Morsi back in July 2013 during a period of mass unrest that rocked the country. Egypt also experienced an increase in anti-government civil unrest throughout January and February 2011, resulting in the killing of dozens of demonstrators and the imposition of a nationwide curfew as the authorities attempted to curb the unrest. 

In addition to politically motivated civil unrest, tensions between the large minority Coptic community and Muslims also result in communal violence at times, particularly in secondary cities and rural communities.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  Both international and foreign driving licences are accepted for up to 90 days. Self-drive cars are available at the airport.
An all-weather road exists from Tegucigalpa to San Pedro Sula, Puerto Cort?s, La Ceiba and towns along the Caribbean coast, as well as to the towns around the Gulf of Fonseca in the south, otherwise road conditions are poor.
During the rainy season even major highways may be closed due to rockslides and flooding.
Driving standards in Honduras are generally poor and you should drive with caution. Road travel at night is inadvisable, not only for security reasons, but also because many vehicles travel without lights and animals often wander across the roads causing accidents.
When travelling by car, it is generally safer to travel on main roads between major cities and tourist destinations. Quieter routes and poor road conditions with fewer police patrols increase the risk of attack. Take simple precautions such as locking doors and keeping windows closed whilst travelling. Travelling in a convoy of more than one car may be safer. ÊRoads between the main tourist locations in Honduras are of an acceptable standard. In more isolated locations, roads are unpaved and four-wheel drive vehicles are advisable. Some minor roads are still being repaired after Hurricane Mitch in 1998.
All drivers and passengers must wear a seatbelt. The phone number of the Transit Police is 222.
countryCurrency:
Lempira (HNL).

Credit cards that are widely accepted include American Express, MasterCard, Visa and Diners Club. Some banks offer cash withdrawal with Visa or Mastercard.

Travellers cheques are accepted and, to avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Honduras is a republic in Central America. It was formerly known as Spanish Honduras to differentiate it from British Honduras (now Belize). The country is bordered to the west by Guatemala, to the south-west by El Salvador, to the south-east by Nicaragua, to the south by the Pacific Ocean at the Gulf of Fonseca, and to the north by the Gulf of Honduras, a large inlet of the Caribbean Sea.

Endemic poverty, chronic unemployment and the prospects offered by drug trafficking have contributed to a virulent crime wave conducted mainly by youth gangs known as "maras".Police officers have been implicated in high-profile crimes, and the police are thought to have been involved in the murders by death squads of youths and street children. 

Honduras was devastated by Hurricane Mitch in 1998. At least 5,000 people were killed and 70% of the country's crops were destroyed. The damage was estimated at $3bn, setting development back by decades.

Thousands of Hondurans leave the country each year, with most of them heading for the United States. The money sent home by the overseas workers is an important source of income for many families.

countryDriving: Vehicles drive on the left hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit (IDP) is recommended but not a legal requirement. Each yeah there is around 14,000 traffic accidents in the country involving pedestrians, drivers and passengers and traffic can become congested in urban areas.
countryCurrency:
Hong Kong Dollar (HKD).
 
There are plenty of ATM's that can be found throughout Hong Kong. Major Credit and debit cards that can be used in the country.

Travellers cheques are accepted in most places and it is common practice to take travellers cheques in Pounds Sterling, US Dollars or Euros.

There are no restirctions on the import or export of local or foreign currency.
countryOverview:
Hong Kong is one of two special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China, the other being Macau. A city-state situated on China's south coast and enclosed by the Pearl River Delta and South China Sea, it is renowned for its expansive skyline and deep natural harbor.

China ceded Hong Kong to Britain in 1842 after the Firsy Opium War and Britain later added parts of the Kowloon peninsula and the many smaller islands that surround Hong Kong to its holdings. 

With a population of seven million people, Hong Kong is one of the most densely populated areas in the world. Hong Kong's population is 95 percent ethnic Chinese and 5 percent from other groups.

Hong Kong's economy has moved away from manufacturing and is now service-based. The country is a major banking and corporate centre and a conduit for China's exports and its port is one of the world's busiest.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. Drivers must have an International Driving Permit (IDP). Driving is the easiest way to travel around the country and cars can be hired at airports. One act that is prohibited in Hungary is turning right at traffic lights. Congestion in Budapest can be considerable, and there are often problems with parking. Major roads are in good condition and fuel can be found with relative ease, however driving standards are poor. Animals, pedestrians and agricultural machines can be found mainly on smaller roads, these along with poorly lit and maintained streets can pose a major hazard. In 2009 there were 822 road deaths in Hungary. 
Drivers who wish to use motorways must have a special voucher (e-vignette). These tickets can be purchased in petrol stations, post offices and at other points of sale.
countryCurrency:
Hungarian Forint (HUF)

ATM's can be found throughout the country and credit and debit cards can be used to withdraw money from any ATM. MasterCard, Visa, American Express, Diners Club and Cirrus are all accepted. There are no restrictions on the import or export of foreign or local currency.

Travellers cheques are accepted in most banks and post offices.

There are no restrictions on the import or export of local or foreign currency. Amounts exceeding â‚¬10,000 or its equivalent must be declared if travelling to or from a coutnry outside the European Union.
countryOverview:
Hungary, officially the Republic of Hungary, is a landlocked, developed country in Central Europe. It is situated in the Pannonian Basin and is bordered by Slovakia to the north, Ukraine and Romania to the east, Serbia and Croatia to the south, Slovenia to the south-west and Austria to the west.

The capital and largest city is Budapest. Hungary is a member of the European Union, NATO, the OECD, and the Visegrad Group, and is a Schengen state. The official language is Hungarian, which is part of the Uralic family and is the most widely spoken non-Indo-European language in Europe.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban's centre-right Fidesz party won a two-thirds majority in parliament in 2010. In terms of Hungary's economy, it has an extremely serious public debt problem and it has recently turned to the IMF and EU for loans.

countryReligon: Catholics 83%, growing population of evangelical Protestants (1992)
countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road. An International Driving Permit is required.  Driving in El Salvador is hazardous due to poorly maintained roads and vehicles, inadequate lighting and the presence of pedestrians and vendors on roads and there is almost a complete lack of traffic law enforcement.  Travellers involved in serious accidents in El Salvador may be arrested until a judge can determine liability.  Travellers on highways from San Salvador to the north, south and east, and in the departments of Chalatenango, Cuscatl?n, Cabana, San Miguel and San Vicente, are at risk from armed ambushes, car jacking and attacks. Drive with doors locked and windows open to within 2 inches only.  Avoid driving after dark particularly on rural roads. Travel in convoy where possible.  If forced to stop by armed aggressors, DO NOT offer any form of resistance.  There have been recent reports of attacks on vehicles travelling in Santa Ana and on the route between Comalapa airport and San Salvador. 
As a result of past conflicts, there remains unexploded ordnance such as land mines in the countryside. Those going off-road should be aware of these potential dangers when visiting the more remote locations. You should take local advice and avoid travel to such areas if advised.
countryCurrency:
U.S. Dollar.

All major Credit/Debit cards are widely accepted. ATM's are widely available in main cities.
countryOverview:
El Salvador is the smallest and most densely populated country in Central America.

It has been wracked by civil war stoked by gross inequality between a small and wealthy elite, which dominated the government and the economy, and the overwhelming majority of the population, many of whom lived - and continue to live - in abject squalor. The war left around 70,000 people dead and caused damage worth $2bn.

countryDriving:
Vehicles drive on the right hand side of the road.  An International Driver's permit is required. If driving, carry the driving licence at all times.  Roads are mainly in a poor condition, particularly in rural areas. Road travel can be extremely hazardous due to poor or non-existent street lighting. Avoid travelling by road outside the main towns after dark, when the risk of accidents and robbery is greater.
The speed limit is 50kph (31mph) in towns and 80kph (50mph) outside of towns. Seat belts are compulsory and drink-driving is illegal. Car hire is available in Accra but extremely expensive, with or without driver.
countryCurrency:
Ghana Cedi (GHS).

Credit cards (mainly American Express, Mastercard, Diners Club and Visa) are accepted by leading hotels, restaurants, banks, businesses and some shops. Some banks may give cash advances against leading cards. However, those using credit cards should be aware that credit card fraud is common.

In large urban areas such as Accra and Kumasi ATM's are commonplace.

Travellers cheques are accepted but to avoid additional exchange rate charges, travellers are advised to take traveller's cheques in US Dollars or Pounds Sterling. Traveller's cheques can be exchanged in large hotels, banks and foreign exchange bureaux.

The import of local currency is limited to the amount previously taken out of the country and declared. The import of foreign currency is unlimited, but must be declared upoin arrival.The export of local currency is limited to GHS1,000.
